The sides were tasty, and help this place be a three star instead of a two star establishment. The mac and cheese was my absolute favorite. It was very nutmeg-y. The beans were made with burnt ends and tasted smoky and nice. The fries tasted like fries, but were sort of short and skimpy.

The red checkered vinyl tablecloths were a little sticky, but this is, after all, a BBQ joint and everything should be just a little sticky.

Well, the sauce wasn't thick enough. The fries weren't long enough. How can a place that serves up so much meat be so unsatisfying? As with my ex-boyfriend, I won't be making the long trip to put this meat in my mouth anytime soon.

If I were to ever return, I would try the ribs, and the spicy pulled chicken, both of which looked tasty.
author: Rachel H.

description:
5 stars, Stephy. Really?

No. 

Here's the thing. The food here is decent enough, but it really isn't worth 5 stars and definitely not worth over $20.00 for 3 beef ribs and two tiny sides and a beer. The first time I came here, I don't think I had really discovered GOOD BBQ, but after hitting up Texas and even Phillip's in LA, I will say that this is maybe more like a 2.5 or 3 star on a good day.

The one highlight to this place though, was some guy who was here last night who walked out and made it a point to say to me, "You are beautiful. I've been checking you out all night and you are beautiful!" Hell yes, I knew I showered yesterday for a reason :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
Memphis Minnie's Bar-B-Que Joint & Smoke House bills itself as "The Home of Swine Dining."  This could be because there's plenty of primo pork barbecued here daily (except Monday).  Or perhaps it's a fusion of "swell" and "fine."  The slogan is Truth In Advertising either way.

If you dine in, you'll notice a banner requesting that you not take a seat until you've ordered at the register.  Then you can help yourself to self-service beverages and sit and wait for your name to be called.  Pick up your order back at the counter.  Follow the same protocol for take-out ordering, except you'll have to wait standing up.

I will echo what others have said about the individual plates being pricey.  The food is excellent (see caveats below), but it's a better deal to order your meat (you don't want to be here if you're vegetarian) and sides by the pound if there are several of you.  If it's just you, go for the combination plates which let you taste two or three things.  Then you can tell your friends how much you liked it and bring them back with you to get the deal.

From the barbecue, I like the St. Louis ribs (beef), the beef brisket, and  the Memphis pork.  The cole slaw is the kind made with vinegar.  The beans and the mac & cheese are also very good.  I haven't tried the greens.

If you like burgers, don't miss the Minnie's Maxi Burger with bacon, cheese, and the seasoned fries.

Memphis Minnie's barbecues the meat dry over wood coals.  There is no sauce or rub on it when it is cooked or when it is served.  A selection of sauces is on your table (or packed with your to-go order).  Most of the sauces, while tasty, are more vinegary than the tomato-based sauce many are accustomed to.  That type of sauce is conspicuously missing here.  If that's what you like best, try the Red Sauce.  It's the closest in flavor.

Caveats:  "Street Parking in the Lower Haight" could be the title of a horror novel by Stephen King.  Take the Muni  or take a cab, but don't take your car if you can possibly help it.  You may think your friend who said "I'll find parking and catch up with you" has vanished into the fog.  Seating is insufficient at peak times.  You may find yourself with a plate of mouthwatering barbecue and nowhere to sit.  Beware of the earlier closing time on Sunday.  If you come close to closing, your order will be packed to go.  Another peril of coming late is that you may wind up with the drier edges of the cuts of meat - this could give you a false impression of what Minnie's food is really like at its best.  The iced tea is "sweet tea."  Diabetics and weight watchers beware.

Come well before closing and consider getting it by-the-pound to go.  Then invite your friends over to your place and make them think you cooked it.
author: Charlie G.

description: Great food. Fantastic staff go out of their way to help
author: Jason H.

description:
Whelp took the fam' down ta Memphis Minnies for some down home Tennessee BBQ. Just like Mom used ta make... OK!  I grew up in the bay area and if my Mom had made it, it would've been in a loaf form, burnt to a crisp and lacking any discernible flavor except for catsup!  (I kid Mom ;).  

So anyways, this place has some authentic charm and is in the right location. And anywhere where the guy taking your order asks you to hold on so he can go flip the meat on the grill is alright in my book!  The staff was friendly and attentive, but don't let that detour you!. Keep in mind that I had my 16 month old daughter along with me when I say that. 

But let's get to the nitty gritty here... The BBQ.  On a scale of 1-to-freakin awesome I'd have to give this about a 7. I had the rib tips, sweet pork, beans, sweet potatoes and an Anchor Steam. I also tried the brisket, sausage and mac n cheese.  I'd have to say out of all that the pork was far and away the best (especially slathered with some Texas red sauce). The sausage was spicy and about what one would expect. The brisket was good, not great. The mac n cheese was actually really good while the beans, sweet potatoes and rib tips fell short for me. Especially the rib tips which I found pretty bland and dry. Overall I was satisfied, yet not blown away by the meal.

While I've only had a small portion of what this place has to offer, I'd still have to say I've yet to find that ONE BBQ joint in the city that makes me wish I could move to the South, marry my cousin and spend my days playin the mouth-organ... but I know its out there.  And my cousins aint git'n any younger!
author: Sean H.

description:
Like the sign says -- bbq is like sex; even when it's bad it's still pretty good -- and granted, that much is true, my high hopes were dashed here yet again by the overly sweet que! Who put the word on the street that that much sugar makes it good? It doesn't and I don't get it. 

Served sans sauce I dug the smoked chicken which was plenty flavorful and quite tasty with the house mustard sauce which tasted a lot like the honey mustard vinaigrette I make for salads at home. The mac n' cheese was just a'ight and the greens, you guessed it, too damn sweet. Who makes sweet greens?! Has anyone heard of vinegar? 

Portions were plentiful and the whole thing was just about fifteen bucks, I just wished it hadn't been so, so... sweet!
author: dawson s.

description:
Not sure what the food is like, but if you like heaping piles of bad attitude and shitty service, I am sure you will love this place.   

I went in there Friday with two friends.  While we were waiting in line, a table opened up.  A sign on the table indicated that it was reserved for parties of three or more.  The few people in front of us were not in groups of three or more.  So, while my friends placed our order, I sat down.  A few seconds later, a hipper-than-thou dude-meister sporting a knife tattoo on his forearm testily asked me if I was ordering.  After explaining that my friends were ordering he puffed up his chest and claimed that others had been waiting for the seat.  When I politely pointed out that my friends were nearly at the head of the line and that there were no other groups of three or more he puffed up even more, made some sarcastic comment and angrily ordered me to get out of the seat.  I left.  

I am rarely surprised anymore by the I-am-too-cool- for-my job attitude that passes for "service" in this town, but for f____s sake!  Does it really have to be this bad?  And does this guy really think he is so special that he has some license to treat his customers like shit?  He's not.  Sadly, jackasses like him are a dime a dozen.
author: Merlyn G.

description:
We went during a Saturday there.....decent ribs, as everyone mentioned, they come dry (meaning no sauce). They have a variety of vingerette type sauces for your liking. 

What I enjoyed most were their mac and cheese and their beef brisket. Very tender. 

All in all, decent place, but not the "best" ribs we ever ate....like the sauces they have, but not in love with them.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I don't get everyone saying that we don't have great BBQ in SF and why this place doesn't have a higher rating.  I used to live in South Carolina and they are pretty BBQ crazy there, same with the folks in North Carolina.  I've had BBQ in Texas and the great city of Memphis, Tennessee as well.  I also went to school in SLO where everyone is BBQ crazy (home of tri tip).  I would put Memphis Minnie's head to head against any of those places.

I love how they have the sauces on the side at the table so you can try them all.  The sampler is a great way to try a little of everything.  The sides are really good too.  I think that my favorites are the pork ribs and the brisket.  Really good portions, good prices and good people that are really passionate about what they do.
author: Brian L.

description:
Living in Texas now I have come to understand the Kung Fu of BBQ.

Saying that, this is the only place I can think of in San Francisco and perhaps California that has real great tasting BBQ and honest to god, sweet tea.

Brisket was awesome.  Turkey good too.  Wish I had tried the ribs.

Service was good.  No complaints there.  In fact better than most places where you get that San Francisco Angst called customer service.    

I like it!
author: Jeff F.

description:
First of all, thanks to my local friends for taking the guy from Austin to eat BBQ:  really, folks, I can exist on something more exotic, promise.  That said, who knew that San Francisco, that culinary taste bud assault that is to be had in this city, there lurked BBQ.  Anyone who knows BBQ well (or has spent time with BBQ socially..you know how it goes) would tell you that folks tend to be particular regarding which sauce they like, whether they prefer brisket or pork (or chicken or turkey), and to Memphis Minnie's credit, there are plenty of options here, from the sweet to spicier, catering to regional tastes from the Carolinas to Texas and, well, all the way out here to the Bay Area.

My brisket (I am, unsurprisingly perhaps, a fan of Texas-style brisket) was a little on the dry side, but the sauce was good enough and it came served on bread that was roughly as thick as the doors of my car.  I've long noted that any bun thick enough for me to sleep on if I don't finish it is a good thing. But next go round? I'll likely opt for something San Franciscans can claim feels like home...their home.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Memphis Minnie's was quite a disappointment for me.  I don't really know why I had such high hopes for them.. I guess it could be the hokey sign, or maybe fact that it's in the lower haight (one of my favorite SF neighborhoods), or maybe it's because I just assume Memphis is synonymous with amazing BBQ.  

But my expectations crashed deep into the Mississippi when my BBQ taster plate came out with 3 small slices of brisket, dried out tri-tip, and 3 little pork ribs.  So sad.  I probably used half of the bottle of red bbq sauce they provide on the table to overcome the dryness of the meat.

I must say the ribs were pretty good, tender, but still not nearly the best I've ever had.  Also the cornbread and mac n cheese were tasty too.  

We also got a pulled spicy chicken sandwich that was well-seasoned and had a good kick to it.  It was served on a soft roll which is perfect for a pulled meat sandwich.  I hate when the bread is too chewy and all the meat comes out the other side.  Totally defeats the purpose of a sandwich.  

The guy taking orders at the counter was super chill and nice too so it kind of pains me to give them just 3 stars, but i'm sorry there's just no excuse for dry-ass tri-tip.
author: William S.

description: Wow! The meat was amazing! Didn't even the mustard or sweet barbecue sauce. Got both the pork and beef ribs. Yes, the meat was not super moist, but the smoking method of cooking made some really flavorful meat. I thought the meat was perfect! The sides we got were the baked beans, mac and cheese, and the collard greens. They were ok. The corn muffin was really good...wanted to slather some butter, but didn't want to add to the calorie burden. Looking forward to having another huge meaty meal here soon! Loved the smokey flavor!
author: Olivia A.

description:
This joint is along my running route.  After a long evening run, I decided to reward myself with a pulled pork sandwich. 

The people here are really nice and helpful when deciding which sauce I should use with my pulled pork sandwich.  Unfortunately, the pork was too dry.  Pulled pork should be tender and juicy not dry and flaky.  I ordered the slaw as the side, and the slaw was decent.  I liked the mix of peppers to add color and kick to a typical vinegar cole slaw.  Otherwise, the pulled pork was quite disappointing.

Next time, I'll just order the pulled pork platter, and hopefully the place will redeem itself.
author: Koh K.

description:
After watching KQED's Check Please!, Bay Area, my daughters and i drove to SF iso southern style bbq. I met the owner and he explained to me that the name of his place is a bit misleading: his mother's name was Minnie and she was from Memphis, HOWEVER, the bbq he cooks there is TEXAS style, not Tennessee. I shared with him that i am originally from Mississippi, and that my Aunt Minnie lives in Memphis! (We got a kick out of that!)

So to the food: we had the chicken (it was done, but couldve been cooked a tad bit longer), tri-tip (great), mac n cheese (mmm, not the best i'ved had. shouldve been cheesier and thicker), sliced sausage (good), brisket (great), greens (great), beans (okay), cornbread (horrible. dry and gritty!), pecan pie (good), sweet potatoe pie (okay), sweet tea (cool).

So, overall, it was good. i'd go back, lots on the menu i havent tried.  i have to say, being from the South and having been there as recent as '07, this is the closest bbq joint to authentic southern style bbq i've had since coming to CA in '87.
author: Karen K.

description:
I've had their food when it was catered, and it was always pretty good. Today, I finally walked in there, and it looked like a really fun place. Now my husband wants to find that pig head hat they have. The food was pretty good. I had the sweet pork, with mac and cheese, and a tangy slaw. I really liked them. The sauces could be a bit more thick, but they tasted great. My husband and I split a banana pudding, and that was just bliss in your mouth. Only thing I didn't like was the cornbread muffin, it was kind of dry and gritty. 

In short, the food was great. On to the service...freaking amazing! The staff were fun, charismatic, and very nice. They checked up on us throughout the meal, asking if we liked everything as well. I'll definately be coming back.
author: Katia T.

description: Fantastic BBQ place.  The pulled pork is great.
author: J. R.

description: Now this place is off the hook! The mac n cheese, beans are off the hinges! "That means really really really good". There bbq sauces they offer go so well with there brisket and pork/beef ribs. The meat is really tender and tasty with out the sauces but the sauce gives that extra ummph. Hhhmmmmmm now this is bbq
author: chris c.

description:
Yeah, dunno. I suppose the BBQ is decent but for some reason I've never found it altogether that great. Before you slather on the sauce, the meat usually seems pretty dry to me and I have tried going a couple of times. I do like the fact that they have 3 (4?) different sauces with varied different tastes like North Carolina spicy mustard, Texas whatchamacallit, etc. etc. so if you want to go for a unique sauce, it's a nice change of pace.

I've found the tables are usually dirty, not wiped off and thus sticky 50-60% of the time. 

I won't stop going there entirely because sometimes I need a BBQ fix after 8pm or on a Sunday when none of the other places I like are open.
author: Mike T.

description: Some of the best BBQ I have ever had in my life! Tried the beef brisket which is smoked for 18 hours... And then the sweet smoked pork. Both were phenomenal. Also had the Mac n cheese with corn bread sprinkled on top and the potato salad. Excellent sides to boot!
author: Leila H.

description: This is probably my favorite barbecue spot in the city, this is real barbecue! The corn bread muffin was so soft fluffy and warm. The baked beans are my favorite, perfectly spiced chilli beans and the flavor is amazing. I ordered the beef brisket and it was probably the best i have had yet .. so tender and juicy you can tell it was delicious smoked and slowly cooked because the meat just cuts so easily. The food is nicely put together and it smells so good. My husband ordered the ribs and the ribs were good too, the meat was tender and it just comes right off the bone with juicy flavor. We also ordered the seasoned Cajun fries and we couldn't stop eating those fries, they were so addictive. ..i still think about those fries. The customer service was ok.. a man at the register who also takes the orders was helpful ...i give this place two thumbs up!!! I cant wait to go again.  Oh the food is a little bit pricey but for great barbecue. .its worth it.
author: Christine A.

description:
I really like their Brisket. The sauce is OK., but the meet is really tender. 
I also love looking at all the pig figures they have displayed all over the place. It's fun for the kids as well. 
Another item I love here is the smoked salmon. It is sooo flaky and moist, just the way it should be. 
Better than that is the andouille sausage...umm! The best!!
author: lashawnte b.

description:
went there on a saturday night after the giants fan fest.  everyone at my table ordered the brisket which comes with two sides and 1 corn muffin.  the portions are good but i actually shared it with my boyfriend since i probably wouldn't have finished it on my own.  

the food:  the brisket was good and came not smothered in sauce since they have 4 different sauces at the table: a mustard kind, a very spicy one, a texas red sauce, and a vinegar.  sorry i can't remember the names.  i did not have the vinegar but the other three are great with the brisket.  my friend said that the brisket is the best here.  i can't attest to that since i don't eat a lot of brisket but the meat was good even without dipping it in a sauce.  it was tendered, well seasoned, and more meat than fat.  

our sides: 
greens: awesome with a mustard taste to it
bbq seasoned french fries: shoestring size, crispy, nicely seasoned, and not too salty,  
corn muffin: awesome!  i love corn muffins/bread.  this one was done just right.  not dry at all. i bet if they put some corn kernels in it .. that would good. 

so overall the food is excellent.  

service:
the owner (i think) walked around and talked to this customers.  that was nice especially since the place is busy.  he took some time to talk with us when he heard us talk about armadillo willy.  he shared his experiences with eating at different bbq places.  the food came out really quick too so that's a plus.

i took off one star and this is not really a fault of them but it's definitely a - 1 star/  they're just so busy that you can't help but feel rush to finish your food and leave.  they clear your plate as soon as you finish up your last bite.  there's always someone walking back and forth so i felt rushed.  some times it's nice to enjoy your food at your pace.  can't blame them though for being so good!
author: huong n.

description:
I'm just gonna do it. I've thought pretty hard about this but this is the closest food to my front door but they get 2 stars. Sorry MM but that's what you get. 

Say they start at 5 stars for selling tasty BBQ.  

They immediately lose 1 star for service. I'm guessing this starts at the top with the guy with the mustache but otherwise they have a high turnover and usually poor management.  The service has always been poor for the four years I've frequented this place. Its so cathartic to write about it right now! 

Another lost star for value proposition.  It just doesn't add up for what you pay for.  The two way-combo is enough food for one person but one person shouldn't have to drop $20 for BBQ.   The sandwiches are pretty good, but leave something to be desired.

The 3rd lost star is the experience. Whether its a line that moves slow or an inconsistent product, it always seems to be something. Somehow after more than 20 visits this place manages to underwhelm at a rate of more than 2:1.  I won't remember this place when I don't live down the street. 

Two big stars for meat, incredible sauce and a nice take at bbq sides.  The only trouble is the way these positives interact with the negative.  It leads to a decidedly two-star experience.  Its kind of squandered potential over at memphis minnies.  The worst part is that i'll certainly be going back
author: Mike T.

description:
MEHHHHHHHHH. Ok. 

1) I tried to order the turkey breast, which is ON THE MENU, but they didn't have it

2) Service is kinda sketchy - think condescending with a splash of blantantly rude

3) The sides were just whatevers. I admit that the greens were good - not what I expected - with a touch of sourness

I've had better... Probably won't go back.
author: Joanne T.

description: Still lovin' my Memphis Mini's! Their new pork rolls with the chipotle mayo is fackin' amazing!! I could have ordered two plates of those and called it a day. In addition, they recently added a BBQ chicken salad for those veggie thumpers.
author: Brandi W.

description: Oh BBQ you are so fantastic. Everything we tried was great. I learned from my years of living in the south that almost anything can be made to taste delicious with a stick of butter.  This may or may not be the case here but It was great. The sides, the meats all very good to great. The star of the show for me though were the sauces. Oh my the sauces were amazing. simply amazing and i am pretty sure they have no butter in them.
author: douglas B.

description:
I've been thinking about BBQ since the YELP- O-GRAM was sent.  Memphis Minnie's among others are listed.  So...offI go in search of the goods to quence the ache. Yes it ached.  

Memphi Minnie's it is. Found parking easily, that's a big plus for sure. It smells so good. Almost reminds me of Black's BBQ in TX (which you can order and they will ship and oh baby..it's worth it).   I decide on the pork rib, beans and potato salad.  I took it to go...which may have been a mistake, but good bbq lasts.   

I get home, and the ribs are looking really dry and overcooked. So either A. they were getting rid of stuff that didn't sell or B. they really do suck at cookin' the ribs...which I just can't imagine.  I got through one rib (there were about 5 or 6, my thought was they'd be good for leftovers) and had to stop. The meat was really too dry and no amount of sauce was going to change that.  VERY DISAPPOINTING.

I have to say the Beans were awesome as was the salad.  So...although I was really bummed that i had to take a drink of water after each bite, I think I will give it a 2nd chance and try the brisket or beef ribs. My fingers are crossed for a better experience.
author: Angela V.

description:
I came back to Minnie's for Dining Out for Life, and while my pulled chicken sandwich and potato salad were as delectable as my first visit, my friend said her smoked chicken on the smoked chicken plate was dry, and my friend who ordered the pulled pork sandwich wished there was sauce inside the sandwich. But she loved her sweet iced tea. Even though my buddies experience at Minnie's wasn't as delicious as mine, I'm still leaving the fifth star in memory of the dirty kitchen hipster who complimented me on my ugliest day since my Bat Mitzvah.



*********update*********




I don't get many compliments anymore. Sure I get a few from the likes of you Yelpers in email form, but actual spoken word compliments? Not so much.

I used to get me some compliments. Hella compliments back in college when I didn't have an office ass and the swimming pool in the backyard of my $345 rent home insured a nice golden tan. The compliments could have been caused by the over-intoxication of drunken frat boys, pre-striped shirt era....or I may have been getting these compliments because of the short shorts I loved so much that showed just a hint of ass cheek. Whatever the reason, the compliments were nice.

Fast forward 5 years to moving day 2007. 

Sammy is wearing her holy jeans, a sweatshirt I stole from my best friend (yes, if you become my friend you will no doubt lose a sweatshirt. Stealing them is my thing. Get over it), running shoes, no makeup, my hair in a ratty, thrown together bun, and the giant cystic pimple I've been regularly sporting these days. In other words, I was looking fly. 

Fly Sammy and her parents decide to take a break from organizing her new, very own apartment, and get some grub. And of course, my wannabe hipster, Marinite parents saw Memphis Minnie's on an episode of Check Please and just haaaaad to go there.

Super duper Fly Sammy and parent patrol enter MM's and are enthusiastically greeted by a dirty real, not Marinite, hipster working behind the counter. I smile at him as we make our way to look at the menu.

"Hey, you've got a great smile," dirty hipster sweetheart tells me. "I see a lot of smiles, and yours is a great one."

"Hehe, wow, thanks," says Sammy the pimple queen who hasn't been complimented since the 90s.

We order, sit, and eat. The food is fantastic by the way. My dad, who is known to repeat the same sentence over and over, such as "Wow isn't this picturesque? Look Sam, it's so picturesque" says about 10 times in a row that his brisket sandwich is the best thing he's ever eaten and would definitely come back here. Mac and Cheese is tasty, but kind of watery for my liking. Pulled chicken sandwich is amazing, slaw is tangy and delicious and I think mom liked her ribs.

"Hey, did you go to Denver University?" Most beautiful dirty hipster there ever lived asked me. P.S. the sweatshirt I sold says Denver University on it.

"Um no, my friend did." 

Which launched a whole new conversation about where he was from and how he gets excited when he sees people from Colorado, Wyoming, etc.

But the man looked at me! He looked at me a few times. And complimented me! He didn't point out my cellulite, no reference to my office ass, steered clear of bringing up my ginormous zit. The man earned his adorable little restaurant five zillion gold stars from Sammy because a compliment can seriously make your day.
author: Sammy S.

description:
The World According to Noelle
~Allergic Girl's Guide to Life~
Issue 214


                                               Noe in the Lower Haight.

                             Noe's  A Lovin Memphis Minnie's with 5 Yelp Stars.


Memphis Minnie's is a cozy restaurant in the Lower Haight. The first thing I noticed was the delicious smell of BBQ. Everything is bright and colorful at Memphis Minnie's. Tables on the right and people forming in line for food on the left. Collectibles of pigs adorn the restaurant. The menu is on a chalk board and the choices seem to be endless. I decided on the beef brisket sandie and a corn muffin. He's starving, so he orders a platter- beef brisket, sausage, mac n cheese and potato salad. I secure a table as he places our order and pays for our meal. While waiting for him, I pull out my macbook and check my email. Each table has a clear plastic table cloth and underneath are pictures drawn of pigs on napkins- very cool. There is free wireless here at Memphis Minnie's, I believe its called 'Free Web." He joins me at our table and I put my laptop away. Not a moment too soon and his name is called. Our order was up quickly and we were eating. The portions are huge! The beef brisket was cooked perfectly- so juicy melt in your mouth goodness. The corn muffin was oh so good! I had a bite of sausage- OMGoodness that was the BEST. The mac n cheese was okay- slightly on the sweet side (not sure why). The potato salad was exceptionally delish! 

Beef Brisket -------------------A-
Sausage------------------------A +
Corn Muffin--------------------A +
Mac N Cheese---------------B
Potato Salad-----------------A +

This place was packed, obviously a local's favorite. The staff was super friendly and helpful. They said hello and good bye to most everyone that came through the door. I noticed a sign above the door was we were leaving it read- "Low Fat = Low Flavor," lol, well written! I was stuffed so I didn't try the sweet potato pie- next time! As we were leaving I noticed everyone seemed pretty happy- family, friends, couples eating and laughing. The food was delish- I was feeling food coma coming on. So glad we had a nice brisk walk after lunch : ) I'm a lovin the cold weather!

Noelle's Notes
Some SERIOUSLY tasty BBQ in the Lower Haight!
My leftovers were still DELISH the next day- OMG.
Allergy Friendly, Noelle Approved.
Excellent & Friendly Customer Service!

Noelle's Post Secrets 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8R8Qvm24dbU

Half the time the world is ending  ~ Truth is I am done pretending

Everything will change ~ But love remains the same
author: Noelle J.

description:
the 18  hours smoked brisket gets 5 STARS and also the mac n cheese and smoked beans, brisket is like butter in your mouth

the wings is what brought our meal down, it looked so good but was very deceiving
author: yon t.

description:
Really, guess we don't have much great BBQ rest. in SF... how sad..... Memorial Day weekend, since we weren't invited for any BBQ party, we have to get our BBQ fix 

I first heard about Memphis Minnie from the KQED Check, Please! Bay Area show, so decide to give it a try, plus the 3.5 stars Yelp rating back up. This is definitely not the best neighborhood in town and parking wasn't that friendly either.  We ordered the Two Meat samplers - picked the beef brisket and pork ribs; while for the sides we had sweet potatoes and BBQ beans. 

Hmm... it was ok. Meat wasn't as flavorful as we hoped, but they are very tender, especially the beef brisket.  To be honest, I think the best thing was the beans and the corn muffin!
author: Prascilla L.

description:
I just ordered a pecan pie for Thanksgiving, but called in the middle of their lunch hour. The fella' who took the order was not rushing me at all and told me that the pie will be ready for pickup at 6:00 next Wednesday.

You guys really, REALLY need to try their pecan pie.
author: Horns D.

description: I use to LOVE going to Memphis Minnies, however lately since the new people have been working the customer service sucks... They always say " it will be ready in 15 minutes" and it takes 45 minutes if I am lucky! WTF this place is seriously getting worse which sucks because I love their food. But honestly can't we get the old guys back, PLEASE!
author: Lauren M.

description:
Who likes to kick a 65 year old man when he's down?

Who likes to do it with the sweet taste of BBQ pork on their breath?

Who likes to do it surrounded by 40 Marin ultra-elite and their huge frickin' diamonds?

I do, I do, and I do!

My dad's surprise birthday party was held last night at Memphis Minnie's, and it was a screaming success.  Not only was he surprised, stuffed full of various pork products, made to wear a T-Shirt that said "Best Butt in the Bay",embarrassed and drunk, but he was roasted like a poor lil' rack a' ribs. 

Good times for the geriatric set.  Collard greens require minimal chewing.  

What!?  It was his 65th BIRTHDAY.  He's one of the young ones.
author: Rachel G.

description: Best BBQ and they deliver. The brisket was fantastic.
author: Ryan T.

description: Don't twist the handle on the bathroom door. Just pull it straight towards you.
author: Craig T.

description:
Memphis Minnies is one of my many guilty pleasures.
especially the BBQ pork eggrolls. 
i could eat them all day!

I had the brisket last time with the mustard BBQ sauce (S.Carolina I think??)

I also love their greens.... really sweet and vinegar-y.  they forgot my greens once and I was super bummed... I almost went all the way back...but I was hungry.. so I let it go...

the guys working behind the counter are always very nice.
author: Karlee D.

description:
I've heard this place can be hit or miss.  Unfortunately for me, I went in on a miss day.  There were three of us getting take out for a bigger group back at Toronado because Rosamunde was closed.  I got the combo with ribs, tri tip, greens and fries.  The tri tip was ok but the ribs were dry, dry, dry.  The greens were too tangy, the fries were fine and the cornbread was also dry.  

I hear they have an excellent sake event once a year which sounds weird but I saw a flyer so I believe it.  I don't care about sake though (because I'm Korean).
author: Seong P.

description:
Pros:
- pulled chicken sandwich, coleslaw, mac n' cheese
- the sauces are quite good

cons:
- call ahead 'cause the line and wait can be a bit long
- staff can be a bit rude: I see them yelling at chefs sometimes and don't dare sit down before you get your food or face the wrath
- the burger is basically just that: meat in between a bun (no condiments). Sure, this might be traditional BBQ (I have no idea) but I love lettuce, tomato, and pickle on my burgers.
author: Captain B.

description:
Standing out in the self-consciously Northern California Haight neighborhood like a bagel in a bucket of grits, Memphis Minnie's is the San Francisco place for  swine Southern style Bar-B-Que dinning. No doubt about it, MM's is the closest thing  to eating in the volunteer state that doesn't require buying a ticket or working as a roadie for Willie Nielson.

If you like Memphis style bar-b-que, everything on the menu is great (seriously, you can not go wrong). If you don't, stick to the burgers, desserts (um, Pecan Pie) or the fried catfish. I personally love their pit-smoked plates. $13 or so buys a  large serving of smoked meat (pork ribs, brisket, turkey, tri-tip,or chicken, to name a few), a corn muffin  and two of their excellent sides like pit smoked beans, Deep South Sweet Potatoes, or Tart 'n Tangy slaw. You'll leave full and very likely with enough leftovers to make a nice lunch the next day.  Expect a tab for two with beer and a split desert to be around $35.00.  You order and pick up at a counter, so service is quick and there's no pressure to tip 20%.  No pressure to tip at all, come to think of it.

In its singular acknowledgment of San Francisco, MM offers a variety of Sake, together with a good assortment of draft beers available by the glass or pitcher. Personally I don't see "Kuru No Hana" or "Dewa San San" with Canjun Andouille Sausage, but then again, I've never tried it and whoever thought of bringing this bit of the South to San Francisco obviously  has a flair for successfully mixing the incongruous that shouldn't be lightly dismissed.

Parking can be a little tight, but its not too bad -  its never taken me more than ten minutes to circle for a place right in front or park a few blocks down and walk, and usually much less.  Pastrami is available on Wednesdays only. In case you were worried, Memphis Minnie's is a country-music free zone.
author: Bill S.

description:
I came here with two Texas transplants, fully expecting them to find their accents and bag on little California's piddly attempt at BBQ. Then I prepared for the Texas vs. California argument that never came, mostly because we were stuffing our faces the whole time.

I'm newish to "real" BBQ, so my dining partners offered some tips.

California: (pours some Texas Red BBQ sauce on tasty-looking sandwich and BBQ fries)...My sandwich is dry.
Texas: You're doing it wrong.
California: ...
Texas: It needs to drip. All over your hands.
California: Hmm. OK. (Pours. A lot.)
...

Perfect.

My (perfectly) slow-smoked Texas beef brisket sandwich on a roll (with well-paired fries) had that ideal combo of smoke and good sauce, and was manageable as a large, single meal. I must have used half a bottle of the Texas Red sauce just on my own.

Two sandwiches and a pitcher of Sierra Nevada Pale Ale ran around $30. Not bad at all for a good, casual meal in a fun setting oozing with pig-related kitsch and t-shirts from BBQ meccas around the country. They have a roll of paper towels PER table. This is important. Perfect location near bars (Toronado, Mad Dog in the Fog). I can't wait to go back and try out my now-refined BBQ sauce technique.

Update 6/08: I tried the banana creme pudding this time, complete with Nilla wafers. Best!
author: Tara R.

description: I drive 50 miles round-trip just to eat here. I have to say this is one of the best barbecue joints I've discovered yet (but of course there's better) . Flavorful meats, endless entrees to choose from, and they sell SAKI. I never thought I'd experience such a thing but yes, they offer a variety of Saki and other alcoholic drinks to go with your meal. I usually order a whole barbecue chicken with a side of sweet yams, macaroni and cheese, and 3 sides of cornbread. Glutinous you say? I've gotta make the drive worthwhile somehow!
author: Anthony W.

description:
I usually avoid BBQ places because the likelihood of being able to order any dish other cold slaw is pretty darn slim. However, I pulled a horribly funny yet mean prank on a friend of mine so when he said BBQ. I was still laughing but managed to squeeze out a nod. 

The bbq smelled oh so good in Memphis Minnie's which got me a little excited and upon discovering Memphis had cat fish on the menu I felt a rumbling down south (my stomach, sickos). Ordered the cat fish with cold slaw, fries and corn bread. 

My Cat fish tender but bland. 
Corn bread - bad. bad. bad. (I'm a corn bread queen)
Fries - nothing out of the extraordinary. 

Overall pretty disappointing - just stick to Tommy's Joynt if you want good meat. That place smells ten times better.
author: MJ T.

description:
Just walked in off the street into Memphis Minnies. I was apprehensive about getting BBQ (especially in San Fran), but I decided to give it a shot. 

Being from Chicago and having traveled throughout the south via a beaten up car looking solely for BBQ, I've had my fair share of BBQ--the good, the bad and the ugly.

Memphis Minnie's was stupid good. Stupid good as in my serotonin levels go off the charts in such a way that I felt like I was fucking stupid when I got done eating.

Without the sauce, the meat (pulled pork) had a great rub, sexy smokey flavor and made me drip with saliva. Delicious. My only rub with the place was that they could give you more (i wanted to take some home!). But I was STUFFED at the end of my lunch. Corn muffin was fantastic (love it when there are bits of corn in it), and the mac & cheese just hit the spot.

The sauces were fantastic (loved the NC Vinegar--and I'm not a fan of vinegar), mac & cheese was fantastic and the pork tasted like crack.

holy.shit.

thank you.
author: Brien B.

description:
"I'd even go to a dive bar dressed like this!" This I had to see. I turned around to find out what the Marina-accented little giggly-girl behind me was wearing.

She was sitting at one of the few tables that line the wall, opposite the counter that I was ordering from. After keeping a few comments to myself, I noticed all of the kitsch hanging on the walls.....pig kitsch, BBQ kitsch, and Southern kitsch. Pig and pork stuff everywhere, which distracts you as you agonize over the wait for your food.

I ordered the sweet pork, brisket, tri-tip, PORK ribs, and sausage. Beans, greens, cole slaw, mac and cheese, and cornbread rounded it out. I'm a sucker for Pecan Pie, so I had to give that a try, also. It was a lot of food to order, but I had never been before and my procrastinating ass may never make it back.

I had ordered the food to-go, and was informed that I was getting the last of the styrofoam containers in the store. They hadn't really decided what they would replace them with, but no more styrofoam from then on. That made me feel special. Waiting FOREVER to get my food made me realize that I was not special at all.

Once I am on my way with the Big Bag o'BBQ in tow, I follow the Psuedo-Dive-Bar-Scenester-Marina-Girl through the narrow dining room to the street. After another lingering glance at her attire and a few thoughts of what would happen if she ever ran into me at a dive bar, I moved on to go enjoy my meal.

When I order food to go, I don't like to have to think too much. Order, carry, eat. It should be that easy. Not so at Memphis Minnie's. They make a brisket and tri-tip that needs to be cut with a knife, but they don't provide you with one. They also substitute BEEF ribs for PORK ribs when you are not looking.....or they can't tell the difference. 

That was just the beginning. The food is mediocre, at best. I don't know what all the hype is about this place, but the food lacked flavor. All of it. It made me look forward to the pie. 

Thank God for pie! 

No need for a knife with pie.....I'll eat pie with my hands, or with my hands tied behind my back, or I'll smear it all over my body and absorb it through osmosis if possible. I'd have sex with pie if I were the only one eating it.....or if interested parties already acknowledge that it's OK for me to fuck the pie.

Here's the breakdown:
1 star for atmosphere.....smells great, even if there is pig shit all over the walls.
1 star for the staff.....down to earth and friendly - just a little slow.
1 star for variety.....the menu is amazing - the food, however, is not.

In retrospect, I should have invited the Psuedo-Dive-Bar-Scenester-Marina-Girl for a threesome with my pie, but I don't think she's ever been DP'd.....yet.
author: Big J.

description:
I don't understand how everything here can be so dry. The brisket was dry, the cornbread muffin was dry. My meal could've soaked up more water than a sheet of Brawny. 

It makes me wonder if I just had bad timing coming here since there are a lot of really positive reviews of this place. All I can say is that the meal I ate here wasn't anything close to great BBQ. The sauce didn't blow me away either. I'll have to wander in here again at some point and give them another try but I'm not going to rush back.
author: Aaron V.

description:
I read the Yelp reviews. I like good BBQ. This was NOT good BBQ. 

Perhaps I visited them on a day when things weren't quite right, but I wasn't impressed. When I visit a BBQ joint, I always do the beef brisket and fries. I'm partial to a Texas-style brisket that is flavorful, juicy & served HOT. 

I entered the place, obviously a newbie. I stood their staring at the menu, trying to figure out how the ordering process worked. 

And I was being stared at. By the counter person. With a look of 'I hate you, newbie'.

So I tried to make conversation when he did not...

Me: "Sorry man, I'm new to this place."
Dude: "Hm. (akward silence) What would you like?
Me: "Umm...Texas Brisket?"
Dude: "Side."
Me: "Huh?"
Dude: "What side do you want?"
Me: (looks up for sides on menu) Fries.
Dude: "Drink? Coca Cola products? Water? Beer? Wine?"
Me: "Soda is fine."
Dude: "Your total is blah blah blah, it will be up in a few minutes."

(do all service people in Lower Haight act like this? I've noticed it before...)

It took about 5 minutes, and my food was ready. The brisket was already cold when I got it! Is that how Minnie's usually serves it? The meat was totally dried out too. 

Thankfully, their so-so BBQ sauce was readily available & I poured out about half the bottle on my brisket to make up for the lack of awesome in the sandwich. The fries were too salty and were only a touch warmer than the brisket.

Because I love  BBQ, I will come back and give this place another chance, but I was really dissapointed in my first experience. Johnny Cash covering Merle Haggard on the stereo at this place  merits an immediate two stars.
author: matt m.

description:
Let me start with my thoughts on heart health.

I know the general consensus is that greasy gooey BBQ is not heart healthy and could actually, maybe, be bad for you? I for one disagree whole hearted (get it...hearted) with this "theory." I feel that the greasier and the gooier the BBQ the better for your body! It lubricates the joints, helps the blood to flow easier through said heart and generally tastes good and feels good going down.

So now having educated everyone on proper BBQ health benefits, let's talk about Memphis Minnie's. Fantasy Football draft 2007, my house Sunday August 26. I am responsible for feeding 8 guys that will be in my house talking about football. I naturally think BBQ! 
I head down to lower Haight and walk in. The gentleman behind the counter asks if he can help me and off we go....

First off, I appreciate that they know how good there food is and that they are still happy to be serving me, not acting like I'm the lucky one for being there. I explain the situation, fantasy football draft, bunch of the fellas at the house, we need to eat. The gentleman behind that counter suggested that a pound per 2-3 people is good, so I say let's do 2 pounds per person. What about sides? "A pint for 2-3 people usually is fine. Will we be doing a pint per person?" "You're god damn right we will!" I finish my order and in ten minutes everything is in a box and they include a stack of plates, napkins and utensils.


Items Ordered:

Side
Pit Smoked Beans- Beans with beef? KILLER!
Potlikker Greens-I love me some greens and these were off the hook!
Minnie's Macaroni & Cheese- Like mom used to make, very good.
Corn Bread- Once again, very very good!

The Goods
Pork Ribs-PHAT
Beef Ribs- Good
Memphis Sweet Pork- I wanted rub this all over my naked body it was so good
Texas Beef Brisket- Also on the naked the body with it's goodness
Smoked Whole Chicken- Fantastic!

Sauces:
HOT-And this means hot...no f-ing around
Mustard- Very good with the pork
BBQ- VERY NICE
Vinegar- Once again...very nice!

All in all, this was a great experience. The service was great for take out, the food tasted incredible and they were fast and helpful.


The next day:
I now do realize that BBQ may possibly not be so good for the heart. I woke up this morning, gasping for air and holding my chest like Fred Sanford. Was it the BBQ, well, I won't go that far. I also had a few beers to wash said BBQ down, so, I'm not sure it's fair to point fingers. I just thought I should point out, I'm not a doctor and you may want to come up with your own ideas about health.
author: JR H.

description:
Went to Memphis Minnie's once and ordered a 3-way combo. My friend also ordered a 3-way but somehow my bill ended up $4 less than his. Not sure how that happens but maybe if you order it as a "3-way" instead of as a "taster" you earn a street-cred discount? I don't know.

They have Shiner Bock beer here which I like. The brisket -- which so frequently disappoints me at other BBQ joints -- is tender and tasty. Tri-tip and ribs are also above average. A good place.

BTW, 3-way plate + beer was around $22 I think.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Sorry Phil, I just couldn't resist. . . 

I could hear my arteries screaming at me on my way in the door but I listened to my hangover and pushed ahead. This is BBQ done right and authentic to it's Memphis roots.

I did just come into MMs ready for some artery clogging goodness and I'm sure I wasn't disappointed, but arteries are hardly chatty so who can know for sure until it's too late really?  It took a good 10 minutes of debate to figure out a) what we wanted and b) what we could handle.  I'm glad we were a bit on the prude side, as sharing just one Minnie's Taster was just fine for the two of us.  Ribs, pork and brisket - with the most delicious bbq seasoned fries and mediocre mac n' cheese.  The sauces were good and messy and vinegary and saucy and just like they should be.  I bow down to the brisket, but I was a bit "take it or leave it" with the rest.  Next time - brisket and beans.  Oh yes.  Not the best bbq I've ever had, but the best I've had lately.  I even splurged and had root beer.  Hell yeah bitches - that's when you KNOW I'm goin' crazy.

Don't expect a high five if you see your cardiologist inside, but if you're looking for great comfort-laden, authentic Memphis bbq, Minnies is the place for you. 
^ /plagarism ^
author: Jennifer D.

description: I have been passing by this place for 6 years without ever visting, but last night I did with my friend and I am so glad. I was skeptical at first of the size of the beef brisket I ordered, but when I was done eating it I was full. The flavor of the wood & smoke was so characteristically strong, it was a taste I seldom find. I live off of Geary near Roadhouse BBQ, where I have been a bunch of times, and Minnies definitely had better wood bbq flavor. We'll be visiting here again. A word of caution: watch out for their "Beezlebub" sauce, it's dangerous even for pro's who like hot sauce.
author: Aaron R.

description:
I wish I had a digital camera.  There is this great authentic crayon drawing by a little kid with a picture of a cute little pig, a giant equals sign, and some sizzling bacon.  The pig has a think bubble above his head that says "I'm yummy".

Five stars on that alone.

The fact that they have some of the most delicious BBQ in the bay is secondary!

The "It's Stupid Hot" bbq sauce is awesome too.
author: Rocco B.

description:
I see that this place already has so many reviews, but I must also chip in my 5-star rating because this is my most favorite restaurant in the Bay Area.  Yes, that's the conclusion after living here for one year and a half, after dining at Ritz, Gary Danko, etc. 

Their rubbed, dry roasted meats are superb!   I am in tears eating the tri tips and roasted turkey (which is only available on weekends -- WHY??).    Their passion towards sake is cool too, although sake does not really pair well with BBQ.   

What I love about them:
1) I love their meats, especially tri tips and roasted turkey as mentioned.
2) I love their side dishes, especially cole slaw and yams.
3) I love the fact that they have REAL hamburgers.  Freshly ground on the site, and limited garnish to really make you savor the meat.
4) I love their mascot pig -- swear I will get the T-shirt one day.  
5) I love their generosity in offering no corkage. 
6) I love everyone who works there.  They are just so nice and humorous.
author: Mami T.

description:
I am giving them 3 stars for the food (ribs & pie only) because the "customer service" if you want to call it that sucks!

Ok, here are the high points (see I am nice, I started with what's good about the place instead of my 1st instict...lol):
1. The ribs (pork) were good - the meat was quality and though I like my meat drippin in sauce, they did taste good.
2. The filling (yeah not the crust) of the sweet potato pie was yummy and the cream really did "top" it off!
3. The cornbread was good.

Ok so here are the low points for this joint( and there are many):

1. The guy (Steve) who takes orders on the phone put me on hold 5 times (each about 1min+) and then hung up on me before I could give him my dessert order, the call pretty much went like this: 

(Me) Hi I want to place an order for pick up 
(Steve) ok can you please hold? 
(me) Sure....1-2min pass...
(Steve) ok what would you like? 
(Me) I would like the rack of pork ribs, 
(Steve) can you hold please for 1min I have to check if we have a rack of pork ribs.
(Me) Ok.....1min pass 
(Steve) Ok, I think I got that for you, what else would you like? 
(Me) What sides do you have? 
(Steve) Can you hold for a min please? 
(Me) Sure! 2min pass.....click, click, click 
(Steve) ok we have (rattles off the sides)...
(Me) Ok, potato salad, greens and 1 cornbread and for dessert.... 
(Steve) Can you hold one more min please? 
(Me) Yeah ok! 1min+ goes by. 
(Steve) Ok what desserts would you like? 
(Me) Sweet potato pie (2)....hello? (At this point he hung up)  I call back - (Steve) Thank you for calling MM, this is Steve can I help you? 
(Me) Yeah I think you just hung up on me! 
(Steve) What desserts would you like 
(Me) 2 Sweet Potato Pies! 
(Steve) ok. Anything else? 
(Me) Nope!

Ok, moving on....to the other low points..

2. 25min later...I go pick up the food. I get home and those ^&(*$#@ shorted me 8 ribs (and I know this because I called before and asked how many they give you for (or call) a rack) WOW! I mean I pay $46 get 3 sides, a piece of cornbread and 2 desserts and get shorted 8 ribs! 

3. The crust for the pies were under cooked. Not good.

4. The I guess you would call it BBQ sauce was not even close to what I would call BBQ sauce. I just could not use it and the honey mustard sauce was ok, but NOTHING special.

5. The Mac & Cheese (which I ordered when I walked in to pick up the food - and oh Steve was so very happy to take my money and no way was so busy I had to be put on hold for all of 8min and hung up on) was mediocre - I could have done WAY better myself.

6. The greens - WAY too sweet - almost rancidy sweet.

7. Potato Salad - bland. Nothing special.


All in all I have to sum it up with this: 
Bad service - edible food for the most part - nothing special but the meat on my ribs which gets my desire to give them a 2 - bump to a 3. I don't plan on going there ever again and can't say I could honestly recommend them to anyone. On the other hand my S/O liked the ribs, agreed with me on the greens, potato salad and mac & cheese but liked the sauce & pie (the whole pie) so I guess to each his own.
author: Bella B.

description:
As a Native Texan, I'm very picky about my BBQ, and it's sometimes difficult to give the proper credit to the Southern style BBQ, but I must say Memphis Minnie's always fills my BBQ craving every single time!  The sauces are off the charts as well. My friend who turned me onto this place also said their reuben and hamburgers were some of the best in town, but I never can myself to pass on the BBQ. 

The manager, Ben, was very friendly, accommodating, and extremely knowledgeable, not only about the BBQ, but had an answer for every food question I threw at him like catfish (always get the frozen over the fresh as technique on flash frozen on the boats is legit and "fresh" is usually brought in from the catfish farms in the South).

I will go across town in rush hour traffic anytime for this taste of heaven.
author: Sloan W.

description:
not a bad BBQ, though I liked brother in law's better back with the original owners.  I like my carolina pulled pork and beef brisket thoroughly smoked though... and theirs wasn't.  but the bbq sauces were good, and overall the food was still good.  A little on the pricey side, but hey, they were open after Rosamunde closed.

I wasn't really there for alcohol, because I was just getting a bite before I went back to the toronado across the street.

Good, prompt,  friendly service, a decent BBQ, and convenient location across from the toronado makes this place a solid 4 stars.
author: Fong L.

description:
Some of the most disgusting bbq that I've ever had. 

- the roasted pork was bland. very soft, but still bland. 
- chicken was SUPER dry
- mac and cheese wasn't even edible
- coleslaw tasted like japanese style cucumber salad

The only good thing that came from this place is their Southern Style Sweet Iced Tea.
author: Jen D.

description:
Good barbecue is hard to find in San francisco.  I've looked high and low, but finally found something decent in the Lower Haight.  

On a sunny Saturday afternoon, we wandered in with slow-cooked meat on our minds and were not disappointed.  Two of us split the platter that gives you a choice of three meats, two sides and cornbread. The folks at Minnie's are big proponents of Q paired with sake, which sounds great, but I didn't try it.  I'll give it a shot next time and update the review, but as for this venture, I can assure you that the soda fountain is fully functional and they don't balk at you taking the liberty of freely refilling.

The food is served up fast, and there is a trio of house sauces on every table.  I had the brisket, pork ribs and some other pork dish.  The brisket took the cake, but the all other meat was nearly as sweet.  The sides were a mixed bag.  The mac and cheese was sub par, and the cornbread didn't thrill me, but whatever they do to season those fries is magical.  Portions are definitely substantial and a good deal for the price.

The people behind the counter are friendly and fun, crack jokes and don't get impatient when you stand and stare at the menu board for a half-hour.  One gent was so friendly in asking if we were done that we thought he wanted our table, but it turns out, he was just offering the clear off the plates for us.

I'll be honest:  this isn't Memphis and this isn't Kansas City, but it is the best BBQ I have found in the city to date.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Ok, so full disclosure first: I automatically give 3 stars to any restaurant that I can crawl to from my home.  In my pajamas.  And I am not a strong crawler.  

But the sweet tea and brisket at Memphis Minnie's deserves that 4th star.  And I heart the 4 pack of different sauces on the table (every bite can be a different flavor!).  Love the texas red sauce, which is not too spicy, a little on the sweet side.

The guys who work there are super friendly, and will let you take the pitcher of sweet tea to your table if you show up at the end of the night.  R loved beer on tap to go with his meat.

Bummer about the ribs, though.  They have been on the dry side the last few times I have been in, and the corn bread muffin consistently tastes like a hockey puck.
author: Lorin Y.

description:
I've been here twice now - once to stay and eat and once as take-out.  Both times I had a decent meal but not an excellent one.  Here's my take on it.  Once, a long time ago, Memphis Minnie's was the toast of the town... a veritable foodies delight!  Frankly it is rather hard to get good BBQ meats in SF, so MM must have been a shining beacon of meat-hood!  But now, alas, the place is coasting on its reputation.  

While the ribs and brisket were tasty, they really should have been better.  The ribs were too dry and very burnt (I mean charred BLACK).  I know that smoky wood taste is what people crave, but MM seems to rely too much on the smoky flavor to hide some pretty shabby cuts of meat.  But, that said, the brisket, while a bit too fatty, was quite tasty.  Also, the baked beans were very very yummy... I would go back just for them!

As mentioned by other reviewers, the place is a mess.  It's dirty and in great need of a new paint job and just a good top-to-bottom cleaning.

The staff seem very hard-working and efficient if a bit gruff - but you are there for the food, not the dainty 5-star service, right?
author: Jim S.

description: The BBQ at Minnie's is legit and the sauces, especially the mustard sauce, are amazing. I'm an E Coaster who lived in San Fran for 5 years and now I'm back in PA. Both my kids were born in SF. One night at Minnie's my infant daughter started choking and Danny Glover, who was sitting next to her high chair leapt up to save her. She choked up the chunk of cornbread just before he was able to apply the Hiemlich. Thanks Danny.
author: RW ..

description: This is officially our new BBQ spot. We tried the Texas Beef Ribs and pork ribs and it was really good. The meat is tender enough that you can actually eat part of the bone. The beef ribs were on point but I felt that the ribs was just a tad dry. That's being picky because the three sauces they had at the table brought the meat to life. We will be back.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
In the immortal words of the velvet one, Neil Diamond,  "hello again,hello"!!!!!
Just dropped into this joint after years of not going and all I gotta say is that the mac-n-cheese here is F@CKIN RETARDED. After eatin it I felt like everybody's favorite basehead Flava Flav...... twitchin and screamin "YEAH BOIIIIII" 
I guess the bar-b-que was all right but all I'm writing about is the mac. nothing else. I'm sure some d!ckhead on yelp is gonna be like "their bar-b-que sucks" or " the mac-n-cheese blows" but to them I say: if you even dream of tellin me that while I'm eatin you'll get a piping hot plate of mac all over yer face.
THE END
author: santiago g.

description:
I have three theories:

1) Pabst Blue Ribbon does bad things to my sense of judgment.
2) I really like sake.
3) I have no taste.

While the majority of my Friday night drinking / dining companions at Memphis Minnie's came to the conclusion that sake should not be consumed with BBQ, I rather enjoyed it. I thought that the gentle sweetness and smooth character of the sake counterpointed the irony, hearty flavor of their meat. Memphis Minnie's beef brisket is decent, but can't hold a candle to many east bay joints. (Yes, I'll happily take you to someplace with good BBQ. Yes, I'm talking to you.) I tried a few different sides (sweet potatoes, beans, and mac'n'cheese), and none were phenomenal, but all were passable.

I'm going to hold a candle of self-respect, and say that I do, in fact, have taste. And I'm not going to blame my enjoyment of this odd pairing on the PBRs I had been drinking earlier, since the following day's out-of-doors activities started with a few pints, and that was a spectacular and well-executed day.

So, um, I think I just really like sake. I'll go elsewhere for BBQ, if I have that option.
author: Paul B.

description:
I really, really wanted to give Memphis Minnie's a better review.  I ordered the pulled pork sandwich with corn bread and an order of their appetizer ribs.  My buddy ordered the pulled pork and some seasoned fries.  Total came out to around $40, so not too bad for a BBQ place in SF. 

If this review was just based off their pulled pork it would be 4-star worthy.  The pork was tender and the roll they put it on was great.  Butttt......the rest of the food was blah.  It was criminal how bad the ribs were.  You go to a BBQ place and expect at least passable ribs.  These were dry, tough and just plain gross.  It almost looked,felt and tasted like beef jerky.  I know ribs are hard to make but I would be embarrassed to serve these ribs to anyone I wanted to stay friends with.  I got delivery and I know the food won't be as good as eating there, but there is just no excuse for how bad these ribs were.  The cornbread was very dry as well but I'll chalk that up to getting delivery.  I wasn't the biggest fan of their sauces but I know that is more of a personal thing then anything else, my buddy seemed to really like both the basic BBQ sauce and the more mustardy BBQ sauce.  We asked for a ton of sauce on the side and they were not skimpy at all, they probably gave us 10-12 small containers of it, which was great.

One side note with customer service, I hate to pile on a restaurant when they are trying to do their best but you charge $3 for delivery (the dude rides a bike, I totally get charging money for it) but then I tipped on top of the delivery charge and when I closed the front door I hear the delivery guy say "three bucks???".  That kind of rubbed me the wrong way.  You want me to tip you $10 to ride your bike 8 blocks??  If the food was awesome I could overlook a little attitude, but when you deliver mediocre( at best) food, then cut the BS.  

I would go back for the pulled pork in a heart beat but skip everything else that has to do with this place.  Step up your BBQ game Memphis Minnie's.  As one of the only BBQ places in SF I was hoping/wishing you guys would be my go to for some good BBQ but I guess my search continues.
author: Mark M.

description:
If you've got a craving for BBQ and beef, this is the place to go. I ordered the Tri-Tip Steak Sandwich and had a few bites of the Pecan Pie. Mmm! Hits the spot. 

Sidenote: I feel a little nostalgic here, 'cuz it kind of reminds me of an old San Diego favorite of mine- Phil's BBQ.
author: CHERiE Y.

description:
I was really excited for some great BBQ. This just wasn't it. I had some sort of pulled pork sandwich. It was so dry and probably about 85 degrees when it was served to me. 

The onion strings or whatever tasted ok at first but as soon as they cooled down they were just sopping with grease and kind of nauseating.

I won't be going back here.
author: Sara L.

description: Crap crap crap food. Safeway has better BBQ in there deli.
author: Bill N.

description:
THE ORDER
Pork sandwhich w mac & cheese
2 way combo - Beef rib & brisket w fries


YIIPPPEEEE
This is the best BBQ i've ever had!!!
Its perfection. Smokey moist & tender
BBQ sauce on the side. 
     Thank you very much 
     I want to choose how much & how spicey
& 4 sauces to choose from (mustard, vinegar, spicey, mild they've got it)


BOOOO
Its Haight parking takes patience
This place is small. 
      if your in a big group its doubtfull u'll sit together
      & seating might take awhile
& i SSSOOOO want 1 in LA

WORD OF ADVICE
Dont sit down before u've ordered. We learned the hard way & where asked to get up by a staff memeber. That's how popular this place is u can only sit if u have food.
author: Foo F.

description:
This might be three stars if it weren't called MEMPHIS Minnie's.

But it is, therefore by doing so, the owners are claiming to accomplish the extremely difficult task of replicating not just any barbecue, but the best in the world, Memphis barbecue.

And they failed. The dishes were overpriced, the sweet tea wasn't sweet enough, the pork was decent texture-wise, but lacked flavor completely. The beans were veyr good, but not as amazing as what I've had in Memphis. Also, no Memphis barbecue sauce? WTF?
author: Mark A.

description:
i'm going to have to piss you off and pull out the annoying "you really can't get good barbeque in San Francisco" in the same tone I give to these big men at my work who don't know how to push this one door open. I push it for them, and in a really crappy tone, say "you just have to push it hard."

It's good, but very san francisco-fied. Like in price (obvs), sizes, and ingredients, including hard rolls on their BBQ sandwiches. (??!!)

I hate how people are all about declaring what food things are only good in NYC/Europe/run's house. But in this case, we're talking about how superior BBQ is in Texas. Texas! They have nothing! They are embarassed to be there and they do not even know it! So here, you have BBQ.  Way to go, Texas!
author: Shannon V.

description: I have had better bbq at many other places. the taste and flavor of the bbq was just not there. if you don't smell smoke at a bbq joint dont go in.
author: Frank S.

description:
In the past I have satisfied my chicken wing craving at Hooters.  This does not always provide the ideal atmosphere for me to stuff my face with greasy fried chicken goodness...Memphis Minnies has good wings too, friendly staff and a place where I don't feel as silly chowing down.    

The wings here are pretty delicious.  I wish we had gotten only wings though, the ribs were a mistake.  These weren't so much traditional buffalo wings, they were seasoned with a sweet yet tangy bbq sauce, not the spicy grease that Hooters wings have.  Different but delightful all the same.

I also tried the Sweet Tea here since Evan L. constantly raves about the marvels of this beverage.  I am a sucker for the sweets so this was right up my alley.  Cool, sweet and refreshing.  Plus you get free refills.  

If you really want some good wings you should try this recipe: http://www.thatsmyhome.com/mainstreetdeli/buffalo-chicken-wings.htm .  Seriously these wings are the bomb, they will blow your mind.  Granted they'll take about an hour to make, but my gosh are they worth that hour of toil.  Don't fry them though, they taste just as good baked and it saves you the hassle .
author: Katherine C.

description:
This place is pretty darn good! Ordered take-out and was happy that I didn't eat there. We went to pick up our food and the place was crowded and loud! But lot's of interesting stuff on the walls, and props to the chipper gentleman who took our order for having to deal with all of us. He even gave us a shot of the sake he had to step away to pour for another table. 

My boyfriend and I got a two-way combo each:
He had the tri-tip and the chicken, collard greens, and cole-slaw.
I tried his greens and they were good! Especially considering he had gotten them by accident. He tried to order beans and they heard greens( blame it on the noise level in the joint)

I had the sweet smoked pork and brisket, mac n cheese, and beans.
The smoked pork was delicious! Not a fan of the brisket and unfortunately it never got eaten, the mac-n-cheese was awesome!!! I think that it had crumbled corn bread in it. yuuummm! and the beans were great as well. Top it off with a corn muffin and I'm good to go!

This isn't the kind of place I'd be craving all the time, but I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Brandi B.

description:
After watching Check Please Bay Area yesterday I new I had to get off my b-double-o-t-y and get to this place quick.  Everyone from the cab driver, to the architect, to the stem cell researcher loved it, and judging from the line to get in this place, so did everyone else.

Everything I tried was pretty good.  The brisket, the smoked chicken, the pulled pork, the smoked beans, the fries...all tasty.

There are 3 sauces on each table, the Texas Red Sauce, which tasted sweet, the No. or So. Carolina mustard sauce, and some No. or So. Carolina vinegar sauce.  Fortunately the meats were pretty tasty on their own (smokey and slow cooked), because none of the sauces really did it for me.

I also had the fresh sweet tea and the banana pudding with Nilla wafers.  They were out of the scratched pecan pie so I went with the pudding which was really good -- really sweet -- but good.

The parking sitch is a bit hectic, but it was def worth it.  People were friendly, had to wait a few before getting a table (tables are limited), but it all worked out.  Think between $10 -$15 per person.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
2 appetizers and a dinner were $30.  :-(

Memphis Minnies makes a pretty decent potato salad. Of course, I didn't order potato salad, I ordered cole slaw take-out. But when I opened the bag at home, there was the potato salad.

The fried cheese grit sticks are pretty darn good. They're fried, how can you go wrong?

We ordered the 2 meat dinner. The guy at the counter said that wouldn't be enough for 2 people, but it was waaay enough food. The beef rib was tender and good. The tri-tip was fine. The pork rib appetizer was fine.

However, a big  reason one goes to a barbeque joint is for their signature sauces. One of the sauces they gave me was a thin, tangy, mild vinegar sauce. The other was a tangy, thin, mild mustard vinegar sauce. Sound similar? They were. :-( Both lacked depth and subtlty. There were no hot, spicy, mild, or sweet sauces. 

Curiously, all the meat came only with a dry rub. There was no sauce except for what was in the little containers. Not liking any of their sauces, I made my own.
author: Lee S.

description: Oh my god, everything was so delicious! All of the sides were superb. The coleslaw was fresh and crispy and tangy and NOT full of mayo. The beans were phenomenal, and so were the fries. I didn't try the cornbread, but my kid told me it was the "best cornbread ever." Price very reasonable. Service very friendly. I had the special, which was rib tips with two sides (I got the beans and fries) and a hunk of cornbread. The portions are generous, and it was only $8.95 for the whole delicious plate! My husband got the Texas brisket sandwich with coleslaw. Nom nom nom
author: Valkyrie H.

description:
I'm grading on a curve here, meaning I'm comparing it to San Francisco BBQ, assuming that's how people make their dining decsions. 
   I've eaten at all the places in Memphis TN and many in Texas, and most of them are are better than this. But MM is better than most places in SF, though the newer Baby Blues BBQ is giving them a run for their money. Based on the so-called "meal" I had at Da' Pitt, I can't believe MM is rated just a bit better.
   In both cases, it seems to point to inconsistency, I guess, but I've had a lot of good meals at MM so 4 Stars for this SF BBQ (and their tasty porky greens).
author: Brian C.

description:
Here's the thing about Memphis Minnie's: I can't say it's bad food, but I can say that this is not the way I like my BBQ. I don't really care how it's "supposed to be", I know what I like, and I like my ribs to come in a brown paper sack, drenched in hot BBQ sauce, with a side of sliced bread and a grape soda. That's probably why I eat ribs at Brother N' Law's more often than I do at Memphis Minnie's. But, like I said, I can't say that the ribs here are bad, just not my style.

MM does have some damn good sandwiches, though. The brisket is a pleaser, in either pork or beef, and on wednesdays, they have a great pastrami sandwich special special. 

The one thing that is not to be missed at MM, though, is their brunch. SO good. The french toast is ridiculous. The brisket omelet is OMFG. Brisket hash is also damn fine. The salmon croquettes are nice, but kind of over seasoned for my taste. If health were of no consequence, I would eat brunch here as often as possible.

UPDATE: They stopped serving brunch! Dammit!
author: Tom H.

description:
If you want good barbecue and want to save yourself the cost of a ticket to the southern states, Memphis Minnie's is the place.  

They barbecue all their meats dry and you put the sauce on the meat at the table. Because the meat comes unsauced, you really have an opportunity to taste the flavor in the meat before deciding whether or not you want to add the sauce.  

This place isn't cheap, but it is well worth it.
author: Adam E.

description:
I tried to get into the place.  It's kinda a neat neighborhood joint that made the big time after being featured on "Check Please".  Our first effort to go was right after it aired on TV and we struck out because they ran out of meat.  

We finally made it there and all but 2 side dishes were made with onions!  Hans hates the onion.  I had the special which was deep fried pork ribs, they were deep fried after being smoked.  It wasn't worth the hype, it wasn't worth the price.  I do think I chose the wrong item for my taste.  The 2 stars come from the sweet tea I had there.  The tea was great, but shouldn't have been the high light of my dining experience.
author: Hans F.

description:
Barbecue gone fusion?

Premium sake list?  Check.  BBQ pork egg rolls?  Check.  Texas and Southern style both from the same counter?  Check.

Healthy vegetarian option, classical music, focaccia bread, a side dish without bacon?  Wine steward?  THANK GOD, NO.  IS THERE ANYTHING SACRED FOLKS?

Solid, down home barbecue, all the things you would expect -- pecan pie, sweet potato pie, whacked out decoration (mostly whimsical pigs  but some cows and chickens).  Beans, mac&cheese, greens, fries, potato salad.  Corn bread.  Ribs, brisket, chicken, pork, sausage on sandwiches, plates, and by the pound.  A little cleaner than most.  Counter service.  Fill your own sodas.  Long community tables with red checker tablecloths.  Western-style country music.  Meals a touch expensive but alcohol is cheap ($3.50 wine or draft beer).  I wish the sauce were thicker and spicier and the rolls better, that would give it an extra star.  If you want your brisket chopped you do that yourself.

I can't promise you it's the best in town as they claim but if you like barbecue it's a lovable place that makes you want to come back.

Yee-ha-san!
author: Gil S.

description:
What is out of place here? Good BBQ in SF? WTF? Where did this place come from and why didn't I know about this sooner? 

Now I have lived in the South and I have had great BBQ all over the country but the one place on the planet where I did not expect to find truly good BBQ is in SF. That said, I went in a skeptic...had the Pulled Pork Sandwich and came out a believer...excellent selection of tasty sauce and the Mac-n-Cheese is fucking delicious (yeah, it was good enough to warrant an F-bomb and I am hard-ass when it comes to Mac-n-Cheese).

Bottom line - Memphis Minnie's serves a damn good plate of BBQ!
author: Todd E.

description:
MMMmmmm... meat.

Mmmmmmm... bbq.

mouthwaterting bbq meat.

mmmmmm....
author: Tangerine L.

description:
I know I shouldn't do this, but I'm gonna do it anyway.  There's just no avoiding it.  I hold any barbeque place to a rather high standard because - well, I'm Texan.  It's like another tier on the food pyramid for us (right next to steak, bacon, potatoes, and beer).

I kid, of course - somewhat.

Another fellow Texan took me to this joint because she told me that it was pretty good.  Overall, I think she was right.  I got the beef brisket, which was a pretty large portion (very nice) but it was rather dry (not so nice).  After drenching it in the red sauce (you can't miss it, it's the one with the least amount of all three bottles on the table because it's the most popular) it was quite enjoyable. 

I recommend getting fries as a side, mostly because the macaroni and cheese is dry and flavorless, and quite below par of the good 'ol blue box from the grocery store.

The only major props I give this place is the nice people, and their sweet tea.  It was quite delicious.  It's not the same as the joints in Texas, but it's...aiite.
author: Shay F.

description:
Went here for my first time recently during a lunch and booze session with work. 

The guy dishing me up my pulled pork sandwich looked like one of  the "evil" hill people from that movie cabin fever. Obviously he didn't slice me up, and he was a cool guy. 

I don't know if it was the four beers I had before getting there or what. But that sandwich was pretty epic. The sauces really made it adventurous, and helped mix up the flavors with every bite. The sides were pretty generous too and helped fill in all the gaps. Two pitchers between the four of us probably didn't hurt either.

I wanna go back someday when I'm not toasted, and then re-review. But it's gonna be hard when Rosemonde is right there, grabbing me by my balls, and dragging me in to eat a beer sausage.
author: Tom G.

description:
I.  Love.  BBQ.
"When I'm happy, I want BBQ.  When I'm sad, I just want BBQ more."

I've done a lot of traveling in the south, so I've had me some good BBQ.  I love it in every regional derivation, so long as it's cooked with an eye to tradition.  Anyone who tries to create some modern, 'fusion' BBQ should be roasted alive in his own smoker.  And yes, there is a difference between grilling something in your backyard (I don't care if you do call it a BBQ) and real smoked BBQ.

The boys at Memphis Minnie's know BBQ.  Everything from the little pigs everywhere to the music (I think they were playing the soundtrack to 'Oh Brother, Where Art Thou' when I was there last) screams BBQ.  The food was great - we tried ribs, chicken, brisket, all kinds of sides.  Nothing disappointed.  The staff was friendly and courteous - southern gentlemen by character, if not by birth.  Awesome.
