author: Anthony R.

description:
Shall I compare thee to a summer's BBQ? Thou art more tasty and more fucking awesome. 

If you find me better slaw than Minnie's, I'll give you my left kidney (but not the right one, don't ask for the right one). 

Especially love their selection of sauces, amazing fries, fabulous pulled spicy chicken sandwiches, kitschy decor, great beans. I'll say the corn bread is good but a little dry.

In a city known for farm-raised organically locovorous non-dairy broccoli healthshakes (fair trade, of course), it's nice to pig out on guilt-ridden, sauce-slathered, stick-to-your-arteries BBQ. Mmm, culinary masochism!

Go Memphis Minnie's! Actually, I'm going there right now. Peace!
author: Andrew K.

description:
1. I didn't know it was possible to fuck up greens. 

2. Why does it look like Disneyland in here? Will the Hill Country Bears be                         
     performing later?

3. Who drinks sake with bbq? 

4. Oh, I get it. This isn't bbq.
author: Chelsea T.

description:
Napkin-dependent, artery-clogging finger-licking delicious food.

Highlights
- Weekly pastrami sandwich:  Very nice flavor, and went well on the grilled bread.  Huge portion
- Mac & Cheese:  Very heavy, but extraordinarily cheesy.
- Sampling the three BBQ sauces on everything I was eating to see what went best with what
- Southern hospitality

Cons
- I didn't like the vinegar BBQ sauce.  It seemed like it needed to be shook up more as there was a lot of sediment on the bottom
- Lack of seating.  Often feels crowded even though there aren't many people.
- It's real BBQ and it will sit in your stomach as such.  I probably should have eaten less than the whole portion.
author: Jeff A.

description:
I frickin' love this joint.  I can't believe that I lived in the city for almost two years, rolling past fillmore and haight all the time, and never stopped in.  After having to go back to Texas and esp. Houston for a year or so, BBQ became a staple, and now I don't see how I could survive the city without Minnie's.

I'll agree that lunch specials are not all that great, but I don't care much about sides, and the place is small.  My girlfriend and I can split a pound of brisket for $13.99, just two dollars more than it would cost in Texas, but it is far more tender and lean.  In The South(tm), BBQ places are bigger and cheaper because they do volume in low-rent shacks and even sometimes cook outdoors.  So, these guys have gotta pay their rent in the haight, and we all knew we were going to lose a few square feet when moving from the South - esp Texas - to the bay area, that apparently includes the BBQ joints.

I like the meat at Minnie's with and without sauce, their Texas Red is pretty good but honestly, they could stand to pick up a case of Stubb's from Austin, which is available here in the city at Whole Foods (hint, hint).  As so many BBQ connoisseur will say, and you may read on some newspaper articles on the tables, it's not about the sauce, it's about the meat, and Minnie's do a good job.  For one, also, if you like to go low carb, sauce is not so great for you, but brisket, grilled chicken, etc.. fit the bill right off the fire.

As to those who knew what to expect and did not like it, I say give 'em another try.  I've had it be acceptable-good on some days and amazing-good on others, like April 20, when they were packed.  BBQ is about soul and there is no up without down.
author: Justin R.

description:
Took a crazy cab ride across town to lower Haight for lunch.  Walking around I saw all the pretty colors on the Memphis Minnie's sign.and decided to go in.

Tiny little restaurant, with a big booth-style seat running alongside the wall and tables sitting in front of it.  I chose to sit on the booth side.  You get to choose from 3 BBQ sauces, a gross mustard yellow one, a gross vinegar brown one, or a gross red one.  I went with the gross red one, called Texas Red Sauce, which makes it seem like a hot sauce, but it's just a regular BBQ sauce.

We got a 2 entree plate, which consisted of any two entrees we wanted, a corn muffin and any 2 sides we wanted.  Chicken, St Louis style ribs, mac&cheese and mac&cheese.

The ribs were good.  The meat was tender and juicy.  Although it didn't exactly fall off the bone, it easily tore off the bone when I pulled.  The chicken was dry.  I was only able to eat it after drowning it in the gross BBQ sauce, which in itself has some texture (not something I enjoy in my sauce).  The mac&cheese was good.  It tasted homemade and better quality than my former college budget would allow Kraft box.

Worst BBQ I have ever had in my life.  It's worse than what I thought was the worst (a place in San Diego county).

If the food was good we would have gotten more.  But it wasn't.  This restaurant should not be fortunate enough to have such high reviews on yelp.
author: Brooke R.

description: Nothing too fancy about this place. Its straight up BBQ which I may not be qualified to review since I am a vegetarian. I can say that the fried cheese grits sticks with tartar sauce are very indulgent and good. Crispy with cornmeal crust on the outside and moist and creamy on the inside. The macaroni and cheese was also pretty good, even if the sauce was reminiscent of a box of Kraft. My friends seemed to enjoy the ribs, pulled chicken, and collard greens as well. Corn bread muffin was moist but a tad flavorless. Like I said, from a vegetarian standpoint, don't go out of your way, but then again this place is all about the BBQ meat!
author: Mr. E.

description:
Meat. Meat. Meat.
What more can you say? Its an extravaganza. I like meat. I used to like the smell of cooking meat.

But now that MMBBQ has a new, or needs a new vetilation system, the smell of smoking meat is literally like being smoked myself.

My whole block......My building smells constantly of smoking meat. My apartment smells constantly of smoking meat. My hair, my clothes, my friends clothes. Even my clean laundry. Even the laundrymat! Don't those usually smell like fresh laundry? Every day and every night I have to close all my doors and windows so that my eyes stop burning from the smoking meat. It never ends. All this smoking must be why the food is so dry. Is this a restaurant or a jerky factory?

I can make my own pulled pork or brisket, or chicken and not burn out the eyes and noses of my entire neighborhood. Or even the neighbors in my building.

It really sucks when a business has no respect for the neighborhood its in, and the people that live in it. Memphis Minnies is that sort of place.

I gave them one star because I had to.
Baaaaad juju
author: Marz W.

description:
You can take me out of Texas, but you can't take Texas out of me. We are fortunate to have a place like this in San Francisco because it's so un-San Francisco.

Stepping into this place, you'd have thought you were back in Hardeeville, South Carolina, or Shreveport, Louisiana, or Rocky Top, Tennessee or Valdosta, Georgia. The place is black and white and red all over with pigs everywhere; flying pigs, caricature pigs, pigs in a blanket, pigs in the smoker, pigs on T-shirts on the wall.

The tables are long communal style with the obligatory red and white checkered cloths and paper towel rolls in lieu of napkins. There are three sauces: the North Carolina vinegar sauce, the South Carolina mustard sauce and the Texas red sauce. Guess which one is the best? Try them all and decide for yourself but let's just say there is only one Lone Star state. 

The beef brisket is what it's all about here. The ribs are OK but they can't compare to the brisket. The sides are all really good and remind me of my grandmother's cooking growing up. That is a huge compliment. The sweet tea brings attics full of fond memories rushing back, and the banana pudding just solidifies a place in my heart (and belly?) for Memphis Minnie's. 

So yes, this place brings a little slice of my bass-ackwards hicktown in Texas into my life out here in the cultured, vegan, organic world of San Francisco, and for that I am grateful.
author: ashton c.

description:
Memphis Minnies is the Fisherman's Wharf of BBQ.  

I grew up in Arkansas with absentee parents.  Most of my food growing up was smoked meats prepared by African Americans who know what a pig is supposed to taste like.  If you want to be authentic, be authentic, don't spend half a gazillion trying to look authentic.  All that kitsch hanging from the walls, looks like they are a T-shirt shop in Nashville.

When you approach a BBQ joint you should smell it several blocks before you get there.  The smokehouse is your advertisement, the only one you should need.  The pork will have crispy skin and there will be a black line on the meat where the flesh and smoke have married and absorbed all that yummy goodness.  You will not find any of that at Disney on the Haight.  The pork is dry and bland which likely means they have turned up the heat to increase production.  More heat, less smoke, bad pig.  BBQ, real good BBQ, is as much art as science.  It takes time and love.  And it does not cost twenty bucks for three ounces of bland pork, a spoon of beans, a spoon of collard greens and a beer.  

Good Q ought to stand up by itself, the sauce is a condiment, not the main event.  Mix enough of the Minnie's sauce with your meat and you will get something like a pork flavored cole slaw.

Oh, I liked the greens.  On the other hand, it is damn near impossible to screw up a pot of greens.
author: Cheezy P.

description: First off...the BBQ is alright and a little ovepriced for what I ordered. I had the beef ribs (3 pieces to be exact) and two side. I was lucky to find parking on a Saturday, because if I had to hunt for a parking spot and what I know now about M.M's; it would not be worth the trouble. Head over to "Sam's BBQ" in San Jose, more beef and more bang for the buck. (hell, they even serve prime rib on Fri. and Sat. nights) For the same price, I got 6 beef ribs and 2 sides...go figure.
author: Dan P.

description:
MM's is a great neighborhood place.... we're lucky to have A BBQ joint nearby.  

The BBQ is good.  Brisket is good, ribs were good.  (one would expect greatness from a BBQ joint in this region) Sauces are a bit weak.  Greens have too much tang.  The Mac & Cheese is pretty, meh.   All at the over-the-top price of 14.75/plate.  Portions were average.

In these challenging economic times, one would expect a bit more value on the plate.  I wondered why the place was empty.  37.00 for two average meals is the reason I won't be returning.
author: Roger M.

description:
Being an Englishman Southern BBQ is  something Im not overly familiar with but am absolutely growing to love.

I've been meaning to get out to Memphis Minnies for some time and I have to say it was worth the wait. I had the 18hr brisket and  the beef bones along with a few sides. The brisket was simply amazing - so damn good. I wish I could say the same for the ribs but alas they were average at best.

Im heading to Austin in a few weeks so Im interested to see how it compares however i know if Im ever looking for a quick fix in the city this will more than suffice.
author: Ben W.

description:
I have been craving Memphis Minnie's for awhile now even though I have never tried until recently.  So I don't know what conjured up the mouth watering, tummy growling cravings to eat at Minnie's.  I have just heard so much good word of mouth about this place that I had to have myself a piece of their bbq.

Pork ribs were fall off the bone good.  Mix the Texas Red and Mustard sauce for a perfect combo, but the sauces on their own are not to my liking.  The brisket disappointed.  I think it was an off day for them because it was really dry.  It had a good crust on there, but unfortunately it might have been sitting in the spit for too long because it was charred dry.  Like eating jerkey.  

The corn muffins I actually liked, although dry.  I really like their mealy, grainy texture.  A slather of butter helped moisten up the courseness.  Now the sides... poopah!  I like my sweet potatoes mushy and even mashed with brown sugar.  Seems like they bake/steam? it just until it isn't raw.  Vinegar slaw... meh... different, but didn't care for the peppers.

There are some places so knock your socks off good, you crave it again and again.  Ironically, even tho I craved this even before my first visit, I don't see myself craving it any longer.  The sandwiches and catfish catches my interest, but I don't see myself getting the latenight munchies and wanting to gorge myself on Minnie's 'que.
author: Chris T.

description: I enjoyed the Memphis Minnie's experience on Haight Street. It felt straight out of the southeast USA. However, I am dropping a star because they charge people for a serving of fries, and that makes no sense to me. I had a BBQ chicken sandwich. The interior is raw and old school, but fun. They have an extensive menu, but I might not go there again in San Francisco.
author: Denise C.

description:
My friends and I were crashing an ex-co-worker's birthday Potluck BBQ on Haight so we decided to stop by Memphis Minnie's to pick up some stuff before heading out to the party.  We got a pint of potato salad ($5.00), a pint of mac n' cheese ($6), half a dozen of smoky mountain wings ($5.75), and six corn bread muffins ($.75 each).  

I really liked the potato salad, it didn't taste like mayonnaise at all like others I've tried before.  Using red potatoes is definitely a plus.  The mac 'n cheese was a bit dry and overcooked, but it tasted good.  Smoky mountain wings are do die for... made me want to eat chicken again and think about why I ever gave up chicken in the first place -- the sauce is just so delicious, crispy on the outside and the meat is tender that it just falls off the bone.  Yum!  The corn bread muffins are really good, too -- perfect texture, light, but not crumbly. Everyone at the party loved the food we brought and it didn't take long for it to be all eaten up :-)!

We decided to leave the party a couple of hours later, grabbed some smokes and started craving for chili.  Since we were parked right next to Memphis Minnie's, we went back in and got some chili... Texas Chili to be exact.  I was disappointed, just not what I was expecting to get.  The chili was all meat... yes, meat and no beans.  I really wanted some beans... would have happy if there were beans.  Oh well, at least it was still tasty and my friends seem to have enjoyed theirs.   

Great BBQ place.  Two beers (Sierra Navada and Anchor Steam) on tap, fun atmosphere, cool people.  They also have merchandise for sale; shirts, hats, and sauces :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Usually, when I barbecue, I use this thing called FIRE.  Don't know if y'all have heard of this stuff...basically, it cooks things and makes things HOT.  

Apparently, the folks at Minnie's have not discover the wonders of the flame.  My girlfriend and I got the pulled pork (I got the platter, and she got the sandwich).  There was a heaping pile of meat, and I put some of the red sauce on it, stuck my fork in and took a bite.  COLD!!!  Not lukewarm...COLD!  I thought it was the sauce, but i took a naked bite and it was still cold.  My mac and cheese was cold, and my gf's fries were probably out since lunch!  NASTY!

I like my barbecue, well, barbecued!  I LOVE BBQ!  I felt duped!  I couldn't wait to write my scathing review!  We left Minnie's and as we were going home, this review began to take form in my mind...

I was planning on giving it 2 stars, because I did like the red sauce.  I decided to sleep on it.

Then....

At 4am...

I woke up in a horrible sweat from a nightmare...It was like the scene from "Alien" where the alien thing bursts from that dude's stomach...horrendous!  Then I realized that it wasn't a dream at all...it was Minnie's Revenge....

Never going again....
author: John K.

description:
While wandering the lower Haight, we discovered MM and went in for a bite.  It was
really great.  Very tasty and generous portions, with 4 different sauces placed on the table for you to choose when, how and how much to use.  The ribs seemed to be a good quality, and cooked perfectly.  We will return!!!
author: D'oh S.

description:
In a word: unimpressed. Everyone within a 30 mile radius talked this place up like it was the 2nd coming of BBQ. It is not. I thoroughly enjoy the fact that a large majority of people who give Minnie's a five star rating qualify their rating by claiming they lived in Texas for ___ years. Fine, you may have lived in Texas but you have the taste buds of a Canadian if you think this is great/amazing/stellar/awesome/ (insert hyperbolic adjective of choice) BBQ.

I ordered the Memphis sweet pork sandwich this Tuesday. Coincidentally, my feelings toward the sandwich were quite similar to my feelings for the day. Thank god it wasn't Monday, but it was a far cry from Friday. 

The sauces were good (particularly the sweet mustard) - but they can't make up for a half-assed sandwich. I will note that I did love the side of macaroni and cheese. However, for my $12.00 meal, I would've greatly appreciated more than a thimble full. I would bet that even those Texans handing out 5 star ratings like hot cakes would agree that sides are not meant to come in containers more akin to a shot glass than anything else. (Unless, of course, you ordered a side of tequila). 

In my mind, the biggest knock against Minnie's is not it's food - because it's not bad, it's just not great - it's the failure to meet expectations. A ton of San Franciscan's claim this place is excellent and unfortunately, they're all wrong.
author: Tom C.

description: The 5 - 6 times I've gone to Memphis Minnie's in the past have been fine.  The last visit, however, was such an unpleasant experience that it cancels out any positive feelings the previous visits inspired.  After ordering, my friend and I sat down at a table with our sodas to wait for our food.  After 30 minutes or so (and several people who were behind us in line received their orders), I got back in line to inquire about our order.  When I asked the cashier if our order had been forgotten accidentally, I was told burgers take a longer time to prepare.  I am not quite sure why that means at least two parties behind us in line should get their food way before we did.
author: Amy K.

description:
Porkgasm. 

Full disclosure:  I've never spent more than a two-hour layover in the South, I'm not a barbecue purist, and I don't know (or want to know) where the hock comes from.  

For a long time, Memphis Minnie's was my Sunday hangover destination.  Luckily I only discovered after I moved out of the neighborhood that it was just as good outside of the context of a debilitating case of the shakes.  Everything that I've tried there has been the 'best thing ever,' including the 'low country grits,' which I probably should've regretted ordering later (it appears to be a artery-reinforcing combination of gravy, fry, corn and shrimp).  Winners include: pulled pork sandwich, brisket and cornbread. 
They also claim to have an extensive sake menu -- how's that for authenticity? 

As the sign above the door says, "fat is flavor."
author: Phil K.

description: Caveat: I have a fear of ketchup and I love BBQ sauce. I HATE when places put the word "ketchup" in their ingredient for BBQ sauce. I thought this place was extremely overhyped and overpriced. Wasn't disgusting, but c'mon San Francisco, you can do better! And, change the ingredients.
author: Andrew K.

description:
moist...tender...succulent...dry rub pork ribs....cheesy grainy macoroni 'n' cheese.....bountiful seasoned fries...."tangy" greens....bit dry rough grainy corn bread....3 sauces for the saucy at heart....mustard, tangy bbq or vinegar(?)...perhaps the vinegar is for the fried fish....

price is bit steep for fast food bbq joint....shy over $15 for a plate...make it $20 with a drink....hearty meaty sandwiches for about $10 and some change....

*sake also available....odd?...yes...very
author: Hen A.

description:
spent a standard dinner at the HOME OF SWINE DINING last night! i wasn't expecting that this bbq joint can get really busy on a tuesday night and to find a table is not that easy, for most of it was taken. Luckily, we got this corner spot by the door to feast upon a plate of: PULLED SPICY CHICKEN SANDWICH with a side of BBQ SEASONED HAND-CUT F/F and a ST. LOUIS SMOKED PORK RIBS with POTATO SALAD, BEANS & CORN MUFFIN.

i would say that the sandwich was satisfactory, i really liked the sauce they used and the chicken were tender. the smoked pork was average, potato salad was also ok, as well as the beans. the corn muffin was good. the f/f was excellent, that i finished the whole portion of it!!! 

the three big plastic bottles of their very own VINEGAR, MUSTARD and BBQ SAUCE was watery!...the consistency was thin!! not a good thing for a place known for their smoked, brisket items. it was really dissapointing.

however, i found the varieties of PIGS/PIGLETS figurines showcased in the middle counter between the cash register and prep-table quite cute and attractive.

also, they serve bottomless soda, which you help yourself in their soda fountain located at the back.
author: Nelle A.

description:
There's a special bond between a person and the restaurant that saves them from starvation.  In a typical moment of San Francisco naivete, we walked into Suppenkuche at 8:30 on a Friday, hungry as all get-out and thinking we could get seated in a reasonable timeframe.  Nope, 1-hour wait.  So now what?  Well, we were gonna go drinking in Lower Haight anyway, so let's hit up Rosamunde's.  Uh-oh, that's got a line out the door, and obviously nowhere to sit.  Hmm.  So I called my lifeline Random J and he recommends Memphis Minnie's.  We take a look in: free tables galore!  What's more, the food was ready in literally 30 seconds.

Make no mistake: this is not the be-all-end-all of BBQ.  In particular, the ribs aren't as moist and tender as they ought to be.  Fortunately there's a ton of interesting sauces you can pour on them to mitigate this, including a spectacular South Carolina mustard sauce.  Another complaint is the tantalizingly small portions of sides.  The mac & cheese and baked beans will definitely leave you hankering for more.

It's the beverages that really set this place apart, though.  First off, you've got the sweet iced tea.  This was called out in SF mag's Best Of list last month, and it totally earns it.  Ah, iced tea...my old standby at restaurants, until the day I turned 21.  Finally a good reason to start drinking it again.  And then there's the Sake.  Like most people who walk in here, I thought, "BBQ & Sake?".  Indeed, they have a board which purports to explain how this works, but it doesn't.  So...I'll order Sake with BBQ just as soon as someone here actually explains to me why I should.  I mean, yes, I like irony, but I'm not daft.

Overall, I'm torn between 4 and 5 stars.  I definitely plan to be back, which usually means 5 stars, but there's obvious room for improvement, so 4 stars it is.  In the meantime I'll roll on out to Johnson's to continue my quest for a suitable SF alternative to Uncle Frank's ridiculously good ribs & brisket down in Mountain View.
author: Wes M.

description:
I love me some Q! 

I've been having a hard time finding a good joint to get my Q on, and so far, Memphis Minnie's has been the best.  

The BF took me to Nate's last week, raving about how great it was, and I really wasn't impressed.  I remember eating at MM's a couple of years back and enjoying it, so thought it was time to give it a shot again.

We shared the ginormous three meat platter that came with 2 sides, your choice of meats and some cornbread.  The BF chose the tri tip, rib tips and pork ribs for the meat and mac and cheese and fries for the sides.

The meat was just the way I like it - tender, juicy and with the smoke house flavor I like (unlike Nate's).  The platter was heaped over with meat, there was no skimping here!  The tables have three different house sauces available, and the counter up front has a bottle of hot and spicy "Beelzebub" sauce...I tried them all and it was hard to pick a favorite (if I had to, it probably would have been the mustard sauce).

The sides were okay.  We had the mac and cheese and the fries.  The mac and cheese was tasty, but not was "cheesy" as I usually like it.  The seasoned fries were tasty, but at times the seasoning became quite overwhelming.

Cool decor, and the owner was there working away.  The folks behind the counter are actually nice and the service is super fast.  

If you want to get your Q on, this is the joint to hit up!
author: Christy L.

description:
On a typical cold day in July, me and my friend decided that it was time for a little Minnie's to counteract the events of the day. Our reason for going to Memphis was to enjoy comfort food on a day that required more comforting. As always, the staff is friendly and the place is pig-licious and the sweet tea...yummy, however our LAST visit to Memphis was unsatisfactory. 

 I ordered the same thing I always order, rib tips and memphis sweet-smoked pork with greens and BBQ fries. Rib tips a little on the tough side, the sweet smoked pork was decent, the greens were too sweet and sour (and not in a good way) and my fries...what could go wrong with the fries...NOTHING, they were good. My friend decided to have some kind of roasted meat, which was a small portion of meat with gravy over it. Nonetheless, we ate as much as we could before feeling like it was time to unbutton the top button on the jeans. I was feeling a bit barf-ish, but blamed it on the amount of meat we just ate. 

That night I went home and the feeling was even worst. Cramping in the stomach and a somewhat vomit-ish taste in my mouth....ewwww, i know, gross...right?  The following day, I called my friend and she said the same thing....cramping and barfy...except, she actually barfed that morning. 

We ordered different things...and still, we got the same feeling. Either we got food poisoning from this place or...we're on the same barf cycle. 

We're not going back...sorry Memphis Minnie's...we loved you before, but don't any more.
author: Mace B.

description: I haven't tried a lot here yet but I will definitely come back to try more. The Spicy pulled chicken sandwich was good but it isn't spicy so I added some "stupid hot" hot sauce to it and it made it all better. My favorite side is hands down their mac n' cheese! So the best. I can eat that by itself all by myself and be happy for the day. I also LOVE their banana pudding. Thinking about it makes me ache a little :)  A great, fun place to eat and have a good time! Staff is really nice, too! :)
author: Mel P.

description:
Hey, the 200+ people who gave Memphis minnie's a glowing rewiew! Where's your integrity? Where's your sense of reason? Have you all lost it?

I, too, was once like you, cowed in believing minnie's was the best bbq place in sf. But beyond the shine and gloss of the reviews in the media, minnie fails to deliver great bbq. 

Memphis Minnie's is nothing more than an overpriced, overhyped bbq restaurant, where 15 dollars gives you shoddy food, rude service, and sticky tables brimming with unsanitary pork, beef, and sandwich juice. Yum!

What's not missing is Minnie's apparent disregard for good tastes. Im shocked that im saying this, but their ribs resemble the shit found Nate's BBQ: underseasoned, overcooked, hidden by a cataract of their "famous" bbq sauce. While it's presumptuous to assume that a bbq house, known for their brisket, serves ribs that fall off the bone, but given the amount of money and hype surrounding minnie's, i expected -- at the very least -- for the ribs to be juicy. Juicy? nope. More like yucky.

The briskets, however, wasn't as bad as the ribs. Kinda tender, kinda juicy, but way too little in proportions for the amount you're spending. 16 dollars for a dinner? With two measly sides? uh, thanks for ripping me off!

And, oh, the sides! So many shortcomings: coleslaw, gross;  uninspired corn muffin, super bland, and mac-n-cheese -- a reason why my tastebuds, today, hate the shit out of me.

To your credit, minnie, you're way better than Nate's bbq.
author: Richard L.

description:
I went to Memphis Minnie's for the first time.  It was nothing special about the BBQ.  
I had better BBQ here in San Francisco.  The price was too expensive for just a sandwich.  I will not go back there again .  Thank you.
author: ann d.

description: Phenomenal brisket. Just the right amount of tasty fat. BBQ was very unique and had some great flavor complexity.  I will eat Herr again for sure.
author: Patrick P.

description:
We are only rating the Mac and Cheese here....

I heard the mac and cheese was suppose to be awesome.  So we ordered it togo and took it across the street to noc noc.  And it was just all night...plain jane mac and cheese, a lil dried out and not as cheesy as i would except a southern place to be...i wanted to have a heart attack....from all the fat and cheese but didn't...i probally would order it again though cause it was still very tasty but just not what i expected.
author: Tara S.

description: Oh lord just give me the sauce!!!!
author: Susy C.

description:
If you like dry-rub BBQ, Minnie's is for you.  However, if you like juicy, finger-lickin' BBQ, maybe not.  I had the pork ribs, smoked pork, and brisket, and while they were all tender and well cooked, I thought they were all pretty bland, and definately on the dry side.  I had to squirt a bunch of the red BBQ sauce on everything to make them juicy and tangy enough.  Sweet potatoes are definately southern style - very sweet.  Slaw was average.  Cornbread was a bit unusual, but nothing really special.
They've got beer.
author: Don H.

description:
No beef or pork ribs?  No more sausage?  What the EFFFFFFFFFFFF!!!

I really wanted to love this place.  Raised in VA (albeit Northern VA, Wash. D.C. metro area) and I'm still in search of good BBQ in SF. Didn't find it here at Minnie's.  

Ended up ordering:

Two way combo with pulled pork and beef brisket - PULLED PORK was more like CRUMBS OF MEAT.  Brisket and pork were incredibly dry and had to be doused with BBQ sauce to choke it down.  BBQ should be long pieces of juicy meat that fall off the bone and leave sauce on your chin and corners of your mouth.  MAJOR DISSAPOINTMENT (*very sad face*)

Fried catfish - done well, fried to a crisp in cornmeal (the only southern way to prepare catfish), but the pieces were just so darn small.  Looked more like 3 fish nuggests.  Soul food should be heaping, falling over your place and dripping over the side. 

Mac n cheese - not southern at all (chicken and waffles in oakland have it right)

Greens - NIGHTMARE TIMES INFINITY!!!  served in the south this way, they would be strung up by their toe nails.

I was thinking about coming back to try the ribs, but the sides sucked butt nuggets I can't bring myself to visit again.  Major bummer :(
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I have always been a fan of Memphis Minnie's.  The food is always good, my husband usually orders a pound of brisket & rib tips (to go).  The sides are so-so, but I don't really care for sides with my BBQ.  

The last time the hubby & I dined in, the service was good, nothing special.  But we're not there for the service, we're there for the BBQ and it was good!

I continue to recommend Memphis Minnie's to family & friends.
author: S S.

description:
12/14/06
I was craving BBQ all week and this place hit the spot.  I love how the service is quick.  You order first, then sit and in a few minutes it is ready.  And they deliver. 
Meats wear great and so tender they just fell apart as you ate.  I got the beef brisket, and my only complaint is the edge of fatty grizzle along the edge that stayed on my plate as a messy heap.  They have a large menu with lots of options and the sides are carefully crafted and not sloppy mayo coleslaw or soupy beans.  The sauces come on the side so that you can use the amount you want.
The place is really cool looking and fun!  My friend was greatly satisfied with the atmosphere and food and I will be back to try more!
author: Julie R.

description:
Wow. I was expecting a lot more. 4 stars and 200 reviews!?! People, come on! I thought the rib tips were okay, some were hard and dry, some were extremely fatty, but there were a few that were delicious. And for those few, I licked the bone clean. They were out of the french fries, which was very disappointing, so I settled for mac & cheese and sweet potatoes. Again, both were okay. 

Also, the prices were a little higher than I would've liked.

I liked the neighborhood -- love lower haight, and the feel of the place, but the food just didn't live up to my hopes and dreams. I prefer Brother's in Law (now Lily's BBQ) over this place any day of the week. 

Yeah, I said it.
author: Defne A.

description: Yum. I heart their beef brisket, pulled pork, sweet potatoes and curly fries. I bought their hot sauce for $6 something and made my own BBQ at home. Delicious. They do delivery now, awesome! Minimum $25. I am not a big fan of mac & cheese, but I love the mac & cheese at Memphis Minnie's . I highly recommend this place!!
author: SS s.

description:
Reasonably priced Southern food in SF!

Really - any reasonably priced food in SF is a miracle.  I've been so disappointed by the fact that people will pay gobs of money for mediocre food in an area where ever other person is a self-proclaimed "foodie" that  I was pleasantly surprised to enjoy a lunch here with some friends from the South.

No, it's not the same quality as some of the BBQ I had while trapped in Kentucky or North Carolina for school, but I bet it's a close as you're going to get and it was pretty good.  If you like your pork pulled, then you should come in for a meal.

Try the fried cheese grits - a novel spin on a Southern favorite.
author: Surf R.

description:
My partner and I had dinner here tonight and were sorely disappointed.  Perhaps it's a cultural distinction, but we found the BBQ to be bland albeit nicely smoked.  We are accustomed to choosing among mild, hot and fiery sauces and Minnie's offers none of those.
My greens tasted too much like pickle juice and my slaw lacked any creaminess.  My partner's sweet potatoes were bland and not sweet enough and his potato salad needed sweetness and salt.
Signage is also lacking - we had to figure out for ourselves that orders are placed at the back of the restaurant.  The order-taker was also too busy preparing desserts and answering the phone to take orders efficiently.
Food service was quick, however, and the bus boys kept  tables cleared quickly.
All in all, we prefer Everett & Jones in Fruitvale by a country mile!
author: Philip C.

description:
I walk into a down home Barbeque joint and I feel like it's Christmas and I'm five.  So with all the glowing Yelp reviews, I entered Minnies like a shrine.  I really wanted to like this place.  

I rate BBQ on two things- pork ribs in a nod to the south, and brisket out of respect for the Texan's contribution to the culinary art of 'que.  I threw in some chicken because we're on the west coast here and we can call any meat BBQ.  All were decent, none were outstanding.

The ribs:  perfect texture, they were succulent and fall off the bone tender.  They had been cooked to absolute perfection.  Unfortunately, they weren't flavored to perfection.  The taste of the smoke came out nicely, but Minnie's needs to do a better job with their rub.  It just didn't penetrate the meat enough to tickle my taste buds.

The brisket:  disappointing, especially after reading that Gourment magazine once called this brisket the best in the state.  The smoke ring (a pink ring just inside the surface area of the meat, it's formed by the smoking process and  indicates great smoke flavor) was too thin.  The flavor of the smokiness shone through pretty well and the outer edges were charred nicely, but the brisket meat was dry.  Brisket is hard to cook well, but Minnie's has a reputation and I don't feel like I should be getting dry meat there.

The sauce:  Like all great BBQ joints- Minnie's serves the sauce on the side to showcase the flavor of the meat and allow you to decide how much to add.  I added because the bland pork and dry brisket demanded it.  The traditional sauce was well balanced between the vinegar and the sugar.  The mustard sauce was the bomb!  I smeared it on everything, including...

The chicken:  surprisingly my favorite dish here.  Well cooked, and a great herb-based rub.  

Minnie's was alright but I was surprised that it has garnered such a following.  I'll come back again to make sure it just wasn't a bad day out in the pit.
author: wineporn S.

description:
Memphis Minnies--Best Barbecue I've had since Texas....

Unfortunately, it's still a far cry from a great overall dining experience

Due to it's popularity, It's super crowded.  Because of this, it's nearly impossible to get a seat--forget about waiting in the restaurant, there's barely a place to stand. Long, long lines!  Insanely drunk foreigners walked away with my food before it was delivered to me, and the waiter offered to remake my food since the freaks manhandled it.  "uh, yes please?"

Meat was definitely on the fatty and dry side(oddly enough), but that was ameliorated by copious amounts of their Texas Red sauce.  The sweet tea was great, but they ran out after one glass, and an overly surly and just-plain annoying waiter said "There's no way I'm going to go through 3 more gallons of sweet tea in 45 minutes" and refused to give me any more (free refills, ha!).  Still thirsty, I tried three more taps (Coke, Sprite, and Root beer) and they too were out.  

The restaurant had a definite ambiance, however, I think they felt that in order to get an authentic BBQ house experience, they needed plenty of filth as well.  Tables were barely washed off in a rush to get the next crowd of people seated, and as a result, the tables were sticky, and oddly glistening.  Time to break out the Purell!

Overall, the food was decent, but between the waiters with attitude, the crowds, and the filth, I came out of there smelling of barbecue, and disappointment.
author: Steve A.

description:
On a recent trek to Rosamunde's, fate played a funny trick on me and vacated the parking spot right in front of Memphis Minnie's BBQ just as I pulled up.  Since I had already planted the seed of Rosamunde's in the brain of my boyfriend, I felt bad even looking at Memphis Minnie's from the car window because I knew that the first words out of my mouth were going to be something like "Hmm ... I've never been to Memphis Minnie's before.  Have you?"  And then I knew he'd suggest we try it if I really wanted to, then we'd have a six minute conversation about which place we should go to ... then we'd end up going to Rosamunde's anyway since that was the plan.

We went to Rosamunde's and Toronado and inhaled sausage and sucked down pomegranate cider like they were going out of style.  So damn good!  

Then...

After Rosamunde's as we were walking back to the car, I asked if he'd wait a sec while I ran up to peer at the menu.  No problem, he said.  Took me a while, so he walked over to the menu to join me.  I then asked if he'd wait a sec while I ran inside to take a look and maybe get a side of macaroni and cheese for a snack later on.  No problem, he said and joined me inside.  

When it was my turn at the register, I had to ask about the pastrami sandwich since it happened to be the ONE day per week that they serve it.  The guy said I HAD to get it.  Even though the Rosamunde sausage I had just inhaled a couple minutes before still was working its way down to my stomach, I ordered the pastrami sandwich with a side of macaroni and cheese to go.  

After a few minutes of waiting, my meal was ready to go.  I was eager to get home so I could have a taste before everything got cold.  Funny thing is, not one whiff of pastrami or cheese or anything leaked from the bag into the car.  The food didn't smell like anything.  I just figured they did a good job of packing it or something, but when I got home and opened it ... I needed a microscope to locate the slivers of beef (very bland ... didn't even taste like pastrami) hidden between the large pieces of bread.  My macaroni noodles were bloated (although a nice curly shape that I liked), and the sauce was flavorless.  The sauces that they included for me to taste were unlike any BBQ sauce that I've ever had.  Very thin and "raw" ... like they needed to be boiled or something to enrich the flavor and thicken up.

They people who work here were very nice, and it seems that they have a loyal following.  I can't believe that everything they serve is as disappointing as their pastrami was.  Perhaps I should have ordered the ribs despite what the counter guy recommended?

Two stars.  One for the friendly service.  Another because I'm an optimist today.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I could hear my arteries screaming at me on my way in the door but I listened to my hangover and pushed ahead. This is BBQ done right and authentic to it's Memphis roots. 

We shared a few main dishes, a 12er of the pork ribs, the pulled pork and about five sides. Everything was excellent the greens and beans of  particular highlight from the sides and both the ribs and pulled pork were cooked to rich delicious perfection. 

Don't expect a high five if you see your cardiologist inside, but if you're looking for great comfort-laden, authentic Memphis bbq, Minnies is the place for you.
author: Phil M.

description:
This is my current favorite barbecue in the area.  Meat is nice and juicy and comes with a choice of KC or Memphis-style sauce - definite plus for the regional sauce variations.  

Best part: BBQ brunch!!  The two best meals in the world got together and had a baby...a sweet, succulent baby you can devour on Sunday mornings!
author: Polly Enmity P.

description:
The prices here are outrageously high. For $17.xx, I expected to have so much food, I'd have to take some home.

For $17.xx, I got two very small (but delicious) sides, one diet coke, a dry piece of unimpressive cornbread and 6 conservative slices of brisket. The meat was tender but the taste was just alright. I preferred the sides though most people don't seem to like them. 

Perhaps I'd say this place was alright if it was $4.00 a plate but at $17+ for lunch, you'd better give me something to make me happy. The three bites of sweet potatoes and collard greens didn't do it. Then again, I didn't even bring the leftovers home. I walked away from 3 pieces of meat and not because I was full. I'm pretty sure I went home and ate cereal after my dismal lunch here.
author: Chrissy Q.

description:
I must give thanks to the Food Network for their frequent BBQ shows.  In combination to you and Memphis Minnie's I now understand that great BBQ does not come from the McRib or Costco.  

Memphis Minnie's is terrific for that smokey flavor and that chorcoal black stuff it can leave on your fingers.  I had the Pork Shoulder and St. Louis Ribs, both so tender that the meat fell off the bone.  A great sign for a BBQ place.  The decor leaves a little to be desired, but hey its a BBQ place, so I let that pass.  

The cornbeard wasn't too great either, but the fries were awesome and so was the service, a greeting at the door no less.  

5 stars to my new favorite BBQ place in the city!
author: patrick o.

description:
I miss their brunch.

I am a Southerner, and this has to be one of my favorite places to eat BBQ in the Bay Area, no disrespect to my fellow Southerners.

The brisket is tender, the chicken is good, the spicy fries and mac n cheese and dr. pepper in a bottle were my comfort food after I quit one humongously awful job. And also the banana pudding and pecan pie. Mm mm mm.

The music playing is always good: Aretha, Johnny, Ray, Elvis, etc. A sides, B sides, good good good.

I love the down home feel - checked table cloths, the help-yourself bottles of sauce: Texas Red, Carolina Vinegar, and the other one. And of course, the roll of paper towels that sit atop the table. As my mama would say, "Community property."

Go to Memphis Minnie's - it will do your soul some good.

(Supposedly, they are known for combining BBQ with sake, but I have yet to try it.)
author: elaine m.

description:
The food here is excellent, although it loses a 5 star rating because there's never any room to sit down, and the wait to get your food is getting longer and longer each time I go..I remember going once a few years ago and getting my sandwich and side within 5 minutes of ordering it (not even that fast), and recently (about a month ago) I went in after ordering ahead on the phone to avoid waiting and still had to wait another 20 minutes in addition to the 15 I gave them before I even showed up...all that for a barbecue sandwich in a styrofoam tray!? Comeon! 
The food is the only thing that keeps me coming back--that and the memory of the time I saw the girl from mythbusters in there...even more tasty than the 'que.
author: Peter F.

description:
Best BBQ I've ever had. Combo pulled pork and smoked turkey breast with greens and mac n cheese. Had the banana pudding, tasted like Gerber. Next time I'll have the pecan pie and maybe try a sake.

There's a line out the door for a reason!
author: Michelle P.

description:
I've been delaying my review of Memphis Minnie's for almost a year, because I wanted to try a wide variety of meats before offering my verdict, but now that I've been here at least a half dozen times, I can say with confidence that while this place is cool (it's got that hole-in-the-wall mom 'n pop feel), it's definitely not my favorite place to have ribs or BBQ meats.

My biggest complaint about Memphis Minnie's is that all their meats are on the dry side. Even my favorite, the Texas Big Bones, is a little dry. Yes, yes, I understand that you're supposed to drown the meat in their special sauce, but you know what? I don't really like their sauce. *GASP* 

Don't throw rocks at me, but I think Tony Roma's is better; the meat on their ribs falls right off. I haven't experienced that yet at Memphis Minnie's (I've tried both their regular ribs and their baby back ribs) and for $10-14 per plate (comes with two sides and a cornbread, which is really hard and cold, by the way), I just don't think it's really worth it for me to keep coming back and getting disappointed. 

I'm sorry, I really wanted this to work out.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Stumbled upon this place on a visit to SF and so glad we did!!!!!  The food is great. Loved the cole slaw!  The pork is delicious!!!!!  So is the chicken. The price is reasonable and food is delicious!!!!!!!
author: Cheree C.

description:
forgive me for being a five star guy - I guess I'm just easy.  But this place is good.  Damn good.  I had a rib plate here last night.  Granted I was 5 beers in, so my shoe would have tasted good, but still, I've never experienced such heavenly ribbage.  It just pulled off the bone like it was meant to be mine.  "these ribs are meant to be in my belly" I was saying to myself.  It was love at first burp.  I had beans and greens for sides - phenomenal also.  

I'd give it 48 stars if god dammed yelp would let me.  

so now that's three reviews for Memphis Minnie's:  

1 star
1 star
and 4,800 stars from me.  I'm going back soon, punks.
author: chris o.

description: I'd been told that I needed to visit this place many times over the years and this past Friday night I finally did. Since the art walk was happening they had a grill set up outside for tri-tip sandwiches. They also had their ribs sitting on the side staying warm. I tried both and fell in love. The rub on the ribs is excellent and the bones are soft so you know they took their time. They have a choice of sauces for the sandwich and Ms. B got the Carolina style which is full of vinegar. Just like home. Can't wait to go back and try everything. I really look forward to the sides.
author: Corey V.

description: I have only had the pork riibs here, and although they were not as good as the ones you can find in Nashville or Memphis, they were the best I have ever had here in SF..
author: Jim B.

description:
It's ok for a quick to go meal especially when there are few BBQ places in SF. The pork is probably the best thing they have but the brisket is ok too. I am not a huge fan of the sauce and the sides are mediocre.

If you are craving BBQ, there are not a whole lot of options in the area so suck it up and enjoy. At least the atmosphere is inviting and fun.
author: Scott M.

description:
I love this place.  We always get the same thing when we order: the ribs, the pulled pork, the brisket, greens and beans, and it always hits the spot.  The meat is flavorful and tender, and practically melts in your mouth.  They have awesome sauces and the sides are delicious.

They also have Shiner Bock.  And pictures of pigs everywhere.  Overall, it's the best barbecue place in the City.
author: Masha B.

description: In a city that is lacking in the BBQ department, Memphis Minnie's is a nice treat! Reminds me of Austin a bit, but honestly if you want good BBQ SF isn't really the place to find it.  That being said I still enjoyed it although it was a tad expensive for what it is. So if you're craving something carnivorous this is a great option, but don't expect to find red state style eats in our decidedly blue city.
author: Nathan J.

description:
I haven't actually set foot inside Memphis Minnies but they provided all the grilled meats for the 6.6.6 party at Idle Hand last night.  Just on the food alone I can give this place 4 stars for their BBQ.  The ribs were a bit tough but they still tasted good.  The meat that left the biggest impression on me though was the brisket.  Easily the best brisket I have tasted and I've had BBQ in Kansas City, Atlanta, Austin, and have even attended the National BBQ Championships in Washington DC 3 times.  Someone mentioned to me that if I thought the brisket was good I should make it a point to go early and try their bacon.  My mouth is watering just thinking about how good their bacon tastes.

I finally ate at Memphis Minnie's for brunch yesterday.  I know that I should have probably tried something that I hadn't eaten already but I couldn't pass up the beef brisket in hash form with two poached eggs and a cornbread biscuit.  I got a side of bacon too!  The brisket has some serious flavor going on.  It's just unreal how much flavor is packed into each bite.  I can't imagine any sane person putting any kind of sauce on the brisket.  With some nice poached eggs on top they are just that much better.  The cornbread was pretty damn good too.   Now the bacon was just great.  This was some real meaty and flavor packed bacon.  It wasn't a slinky strip of fat with tiny meat bits attached.

One thing to consider is that they don't have a whole lot of seating so you either want to get there before the crowd comes in or take it home.  Being that I live in the East Bay I'm going to have to make sure I get here early when I come for brunch.  Oh, they have house cured and smoked pastrami on Wednesdays, if I remember correctly.  I might have to get down there for lunch one day to try one of those!
author: Luis M.

description:
The neighborhood is dodgy, the joint divey and some of the customers questionable.  If you enjoy or can disregard the ambience, it's a reasonable BBQ joint.

Order at the counter.

I tried:  the beef ribs, the hot links, the mac & cheese, the corn bread and the baked beans.

The beef ribs were smoked and a little dry.  Nothing to write home about and definitely not drip-off-the-bone tender.  Perhaps I prefer braising or other cooking methods.  The hot links were good and spicy.  The mac & cheese was baked in a small cub and delicious.  The corn bread and baked beans were fairly standard.

In all, I just don't love the area, and the food was rather average.
author: Joon-Soo K.

description:
I don't think San Francisco is the place for BBQ and Memphis MInnie's just doesn't cut it.. The meat was dry and smoky, and the sides were very amateurish..  Don't get me started on the sauce.. Watery..

The place has the feel of a great BBQ joint but it just doesn't deliver the goods..I'd hit up Everett and Jones...
author: Carlo M.

description:
Overrated.

Me thinks it only gets raves because there is no other BBQ joint worth mentioning in SF.

Memphis or Texas BBQ it ain't.
author: Jim O.

description:
I was super skeptical of this place when my friends said there was an "amazing" BBQ place in the Lower Haight. I was like "Lower Haight? What are they gonna do? Serve pork shoulders on Descendents LP's and put sweet tea in a hookah? How does that add up?" To me saying anyone in San Francisco had good BBQ was just poor math. You might as well try to make Chocolate and Pine Cones add up to Unicorn.

BUT, this place is amazing. I feel qualified to say that because I fucking lived in Memphis and have spent time in the BBQ dungeon that is the internationally renowned Rendezvous. I have licked my fingers clean of the sticky blood of many fallen rib warriors that have bowed before my mandible's voracious killspree. And I'm a wet BBQ man myself, but this place's table sauce offerings are so perfectly flavorful that you can douse a dry pork chunk in them and it's like some sort of weird dry-wet hybrid I like to call water-rock. Yeah, water-rock. Doesn't that sound like an awesome new off-road vehicle or stupid Burning Man jam band. It does, cause it's awesome.

I recommend no matter what you get a cornbread muffin with whatever you get. Those things are sweeter than Wonder Years re-runs on a rainy Sunday afternoon, when you're girlfriend wants to make you cocoa and warm up left over chili.
author: Justin L.

description:
YUMMY YUMMY YUMMY YUMMY IN MY TUMMY!

My first experience, and hopefully not my last, with Memphis Minnie's was when a co-worker brought some in to the office one day.  He brought in beef brisket, pulled pork, bbq turkey, mac n cheese, collard greens and some corn bread. 

Most people would say since I'm a California girl born and raised I have no idea what good bbq is and this could be true, but I do know that the food we had from Minnie's was off the hook!! I know yummy when I taste it!

I had some collard greens, turkey and beef brisket. Holy crap that brisket was so good!! nomnomnomnom  Sadly there was no corn bread or mac n cheese by the time I got to it...oh well I guess I'll just have to take a trip to Minnie's and get some and check out the rest of the menu.
author: Kel E.

description:
I think they cater heaven. 
Never had a bad meal from brunch to dinner to desert.
They should bottle the smell and sell it as perfume.
author: Marcus R.

description: Very good beef brisket sandwich and homemade baked beans.  We ate here at Outside Lands, and it was so good we went back again.
author: J. G.

description: For substantially less than $20/person, Memphis Minnie's serves excellent southern BBQ. The decor is delightfully tacky inside; you can also take it to go. Try the mustard BBQ sauce.
author: Ben S.

description:
I have a bright yellow flyer from Memphis Minnie's indicating they deliver.  I called.  They would not deliver.  No problem... moving onto I'll go pick up.  Tried to order.  The guy was just not cooperating.  This was out.  That wasn't do'able.  When he said that I had to order a sweet potato pie a week in advance - I finially got it - they don't want my business.  What should have been a $150.00 order to them became a no order and I'll never try again.  I was bending every which way to make this work and Memphis Minnie's was all about saying no.
Too many other great places in San Francisco to try this hit and much too frequent miss joint.
author: Donna M.

description: Another really good Barbeque place that's on my list now. I had the rib tip plate with mac n cheese and the tart and tangy slaw. The rib tips were full of great smokey flavor and I tried each of the sauces with them. The mac n cvhees was pretty good, but the tart and tangy slaw was different and interesting and really good, very fresh with great flavor. Small place but worth the wait. Really good BBQ in San Francisco I must say!
author: Chris B.

description: Memphis Minnie's may not world class bar-b-que, but the BEST in san francisco. A good selection and really edible bar-b-que, unlike the more famous place down by the central freeway. Ribs are good and you can get pulled pork. Great viniger sauce. Meals and meat by the pound for takeout
author: Carol Y.

description: I haven't eaten here since 1996, but I am damn glad to see it alive and well. This is the best BBQ joint on the entire West Coast. Trust me, I should know, I've eaten at them all. With that said, I do remember the slaw not being of the traditional: onion+cabbage+cream+sugar+vinegar variety thus I was somewhat disappointed. The argument against New Yorkers' simulating Southern cuisine.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but the food ended up being pretty bland. The side of beans was the only redeeming quality. Also, for the price, I was expecting much bigger portions. 

I would've liked to try a sandwich but they were out of bread. 

This place might have earned 3 stars in another city, but in San Francisco when the amazing food choices are plentiful, I can't really see myself going back here.
author: Kenny L.

description:
If you've read any of my reviews, you know that I'm nostalgic. If you haven't read them, I just told you.

I grew up in Texas, eating mostly crap and barely edible things. Barbeque is practically health food where I come from.

I've been a transplant now for more years than I lived in Texas willingly. That makes me, well, not quite a Californian, but definitely an ex-Texan. Still, I miss barbeque Texas-style, and, until tonight, hadn't found it in the Bay Area.

I had to hold onto my proverbial hat as I walked in this joint. The smell brought it all back in a split second. Aroma de smoked meat everywhere. Gawd damn!

The space is decidedly not Texas-size, but more one of these long, skinny restaurants, a row of tables on one side, kitchen and ordering line on the other. I got a Cajun andouille sausage sandwich with a side of "potata" salad, and Tara R. got the slow-smoked Texas brisket sandwich and BBQ-seasoned, hand-cut fries. We sat down to wait on our food, and noted that each table is equipped with its own paper towel roll and a bevy of sauces, including North Carolina vinegar, South Carolina mustard, and Texas red. Just seeing that bottle of Texas red made my heart even warmer.

We doused our sandwiches in said Texas red, per my childhood, and ate in utter delight. Even Tara, who's not from there, saw what joy good barbeque can bring.

I will definitely go back here often, and would give it a 4.5 if possible.
author: Jeff H.

description:
After taking a long hiatus from Minnie's, I gave it a shot again this week, and was relieved that the food was as good as it has ever been. For a while, sometimes the food seemed a little assembly-line, but yesterday, no such plight. 

Memphis Minnie's wont satisfy the most demanding of Southerners, as I can attest, but for those of us that long for at least an honest stab at the smoked delish of our childhood, they come pretty damn close. Barbecue was never about haute cuisine anyway, but roasting meat is definitely an art form. 

I've had about a dozen things on the menu over the years - some things like the pulled pork will blow your mind, and others might leave you feeling underwhelmed. 

Oh, and one more thing - SWEET TEA.
author: Brandon B.

description: Update - meat was mostly gristle, and every member of my party that ate meat got sick
author: Nawlins B.

description: Best BBQ in SF. Ribs, Sliced Brisket oh so good.
author: E R.

description:
My first experience with Memphis Minnie's is blurry.  I was at Molotov's playing dominoes with some friends, or maybe it was cards, who knows, and then went to Memphis Minnie's because I heard someone talking about and eating their pork egg rolls...well, I was sorta buzzed, and it seemed like a great idea!

Turns out it was!  I got two orders, and ate them in about 17 seconds.

If anything, I give them four stars for those...insanely good.

their sides are good, their sauces exceptional, and you can tell that the staff likes their own food!  :)  I have been here a few times, and love how easy it is to get a table.  The bbq meat is also good, can be dry at times, but the sauce is there to cover that.

For dessert I have tried their peach empanadas and the slice of pecan pie (I know, I'm a lush when it comes to dessert).  Both were good, but the pecan pie was worth going back for.
author: Kristin E.

description:
Came here as a stop along our quest for the best BBQ in the Bay Area.  And I liked it.  Kind of a random spot for a BBQ place, but the decor definitely makes up for it.  Got a brisket sandwich and corn bread muffin.  The corn bread muffin made me frown because it was so hard and dry.  The brisket was decent though, especially with their arsenal of sauces.

And I don't really get the whole pairing with sake.  Kinda weird.
author: spiff e.

description:
The GF and i went there for sunday brunch.  The place is a total dive in lower haight.  You order your food at the counter and find a seat (only aroung 20 seats too (tiny).

The bbq is exceptional.  I loved it.  it's an open kitchen on the other side of the counter and all the cooks look like their having a good time and are really friendly with customers.

The brisket you could eat with a spoon and is packed with flavor.  their mac and cheese side is a party in your mouth...really.

the ribs, the sausage, the bbq sauces are sooooo good.  the bill was soooo cheap too.  you have to go to this place if you like good bbq with no pretense!!!
author: Luis O.

description:
C'mon...This place is DEEP.

You know it.  I know it.

I read some other comments and while I would agree the staff can be somewhat, well...snooty, just order the Tri Tip sandwhich ($8) and douse each delectable bite in as much sauce as you possibly can.  It goes like this:

Mustard, Vinegar.  Mustard.  Texas Red Sauce, Mustard.  Vinegar.
author: Justin P.

description:
My Dad loves the food here and requested it specifically, so I went in on a Sunday night about 6:30 to pick up an order I had called in (they forgot about the call the first time around so my husband called back from his cell phone on the way).  

We ordered two slabs of the pork ribs, which my Dad would definitely give 5-stars, a pound of the sweet pork (which was not sweet or seemed to be particularly seasoned at all, but very tender) and corn muffins (I didn't like them - too dry and crunchy - but others eating with me liked them just fine with butter slabbed on).  They quoted us 20-minutes and then we got there it was ready to go - - - minus the corn muffins, but we caught it and added it in to the order.

They didn't give us enough sauce IMO for the amount of meat we ordered and my Dad had to open up a bottle of some other kind of sauce he had in the pantry - not a big deal.  But, since it was for my Dad's birthday I should have bought a bottle of sauce to make sure he 100% enjoyed his meal.  

Service is super friendly but you will wait a while to order during the dinner rush.  Not a place to go for a "quick bite," but such great BBQ and if you are dining in, it's worth the wait.

P.S. FYI, my Dad also asked us to get red beans and rice from Popeye's (Divisadero & Hayes).  His favorite side for BBQ!  Can't beat the price and the flavor was actually not bad!  Happy Birthday Dad!!!
author: TC C.

description:
recommendations:
 - beef brisk (but don't like their bbq sauce)
author: Way L.

description:
Oh. My. God. 

Let me set this up for you. I'm not from here. I'm from the south. A place where sweet tea flows like water, where pulled pork is served no less than once a week. 

I came to San Francisco nearly eight months ago, and while I've had some fantastic food here, I haven't had any real barbecue. 

Thank God for Memphis-effing-Minnie's. The menu had me at "sweet tea." At long last, REAL sweet tea. (Not that crap they try passing off as sweet tea at McDonald's). It sounds lame, but I knew I was in a real BBQ joint when I saw tables covered in sticky plastic checkered tablecloths.

I had the pulled pork plate with sweet--are you ready--"POTATAS," sweet coleslaw and cornbread. Finger-lickin' good. 

Okay, the cornbread was a little dry, but the pork was phenomenal. REAL pulled pork. The barbecue sauces was great. I had Heidi's Fried Peach Pies for dessert. Anything fried and covered in powdered sugar is going to get an A+ in my book, so no point in reviewing that one. I drank sweet tea to my heart's content and made sure to clean my plate. 

It's like a little piece of home right in the Haight.
author: Todd H.

description:
Not sure what all the hype is about.  Really was overrated.
I got a platter with a choice of three things: ribs, pulled pork, and brisket.  The only good things was the brisket.  Ribs were not tender at all, and really skimpy on the meat.  Pulled pork was WAY to sweet, and rather boring.
Brisket was very good however.  It melted in my mouth...the only thing worth getting.
Poor beer selection as well.  And waaay overpriced for the quality of food.  It is in no way good enough to charge that much.  Don't think I will be going back, and I suggest you don't waste your time either.
author: Anya W.

description:
If dried out old food with BBQ sauce is what you're after, then by all means...

And I had quite a craving.  What a disappointment.
author: Mike W.

description:
So my family's from the south and every Fourth of July when I get to visit Lousiana, my family cooks up a whole mess of somethin...so i don't want to be too harsh about the bbq.  I'll leave it at this...it was good and I would go back.  

However, don't go in a big crowd expecting to sit down.  Get the ribs to go and walk up to Alamo Squre for the view . DO NOT, I REPEAT DO NOT order the sweet potatos as a side!!  They weren't totally cooked, and there sure as hell wasn't anything sweet about them.  I was highly, highly disappointed.  If they dismiss the rest of their sides like they did these, then grab the bbq and go home and make your own sides.
author: Jachyn D.

description:
I am a red meat eater, and this place has the best ribs I ever had! 
It is a bit pricey, though, that may be the only downside. 

I got their three item combo (ribs, chicken, brisket) and with a soda, it was around $20. (I guess that's not bad for a good bbq in the City). 

Their meat has an authentic smokey flavor to it, and has been slow roasted to perfection.
author: Nancy K.

description: This place looks and taste pretty similar to the BBQ I've had in Memphis. Although the BBQ places in Memphis dont have sake on the menu. It can be slightly on the pricey side, but most BBQ usually is. The food was delicious and came promptly, this place has beef ribs, which can be hard to find some times. Overall I would definitely go back!
author: Joe D.

description:
T'was a Thursday afternoon and Haight was empty.  Minnie's was one of the few places open and it was bustling, so we went in.

We had the chicken, potato-salad and mac n' cheese (both which the server recommended) with a cornbread muffin to share.  The muffin was whatev, but the other sides were good.  It was a good portion and the chicken was tender and o-so-smokey.   

So yes, I'd come back.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Mac & Cheese.

Sweet potato pie.

Pulled Pork sandwiches.

Choice of different quality sides and BBQ sauces.

Kitchy interior.

The occasional dry order and ambivilant staff keep this from being a 5 star recommendation in my hood.

You have to be in the mood for MM and if you are you'll most likely be satisfied every time...most likely.

Oh, yeah...no parking.  Welcome to the lower haight.  Keep driving.
author: Chris D.

description: I heart their food, so much.  The only thing that keeps this place from getting 5 stars is the owner bitching out his staff right in front of everyone and loud as hell (has happened every single time I've been in but just now reviewing the place).  Not cool, kinda awkward.  I really don't want to listen to the drama and it just makes him look like an a**hole.  Especially when he turns to a patron immediately afterward, with a completely fake tone, and asks how they are doing...yes man, we just heard you.
author: Jennifer T.

description: I'm from the south where Bar B Q is king. I've lived in San Francisco for almost 6 years. Never found good southern bar b q till now. Memphis Minni's is addictive. Great smoked meats, greens, sweet tea, and banana pudding.  Gotta try it!
author: Mark S.

description:
This is a real find for " Q " eaters.  The place has a down home, get comfy feel, with plenty of signs honoring their beloved pig . It is a very simple matter to both order -- at the counter -- and take a seat , in this clean well tended little restaurant.
Despite previous posts about negative service, I discovered the counter staff to be patient, attentive and super courteous.  Not unlike a visit to a typical Dallas BBQ.

While a long way from Texas, the meat here just screams authentic.  I can't stop ordering their brisket -- which is fraught with an aromatic smoky taste you will not soon forget . The slaw was also tasty , but a little lean in the portion. I suggest their cold pints of beer to complement the experience of some super BBQ.

If they gave you a Kosher pickle with their plates, I would have to reward a FIFTH star.  Great place for BBQ, with friendly service.
author: Jon H.

description:
Delicious!

Atmosphere is perfect for the type of food they serve (a "Never trust a thin cook" sign is prominently displayed).  The BBQ is of course excellent, but what also makes the place unique is their IHOP-esque selection of BBQ sauces: one that's a kind of vinaigrette, another that's a kind of mustard, and of course a classic BBQ sauce.  Each was tasty with the dinner.

Also, it may just be me, but I think they've got the syrup/fizzy water ratio perfect with their soda fountain!
author: Corey C.

description:
I guess this isn't the BEST place to go when you are on a cleansing diet *DOH*.  Yet, even I found something on their menu to enjoy (smoked turkey).  

I've been here twice.  Once over two years ago and once last weekend.  Both times were enjoyable.  The first visit, I ordered the bbq shredded pork sandwich....talk about finger lickin' good.  This go around, I opted for the smoked turkey, which was VERY GOOD.

I think that starting off with quality meat, good aging, bbq-ing technique and ultimately, seasoning and sauce makes ALL the difference when it comes to making tasty southern bbq.  I like that this restaurant  give you CHOICES in what to put on your meat.  My favorite, OF COURSE, is the NC BBQ sauce.  This is what I grew up with.  

Overall, I've been pleased.  I was raised in North Carolina and it takes a LOT to impress me with regards to BBQ.  So, the fact that there is a resto in SF that even offers me an option for some "down home Southern cookin'" and for some Que is great.

I haven't been there with enough frequency b/c SF has so many dining options, but I think that this has been a solid place from the two times that I've been there.

I went there with 3 other people (including my boyfriend) and I think that we were all pleased.  

The bill came out to be around $55 for 4 people w/o tip.  P.S.  Seating can be limited, parking in the area is hard to find, and it can be a long wait if you come around 7-8PM.  They do allow take out orders and Credit Cards are accepted.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
It's not often I throw away a 5/5 after only one visit, but after investing $10 bucks into a pulled spicy chicken sandwich, fries, and an ice-tea, its pretty obvious that these guys did their homework, and know how to serve a mean lunch.

Fries 5/5 - some awesome spice on there.
Sandwich - also perfect

Not the healthiest food on the planet, but who cares when it tastes this good.

I will be back, probably too frequently!
author: Lee M.

description:
being from the south i have a certain fondness for bbq and minnie's has never failed to satisfy my cravings. PLUS they have sweet tea. do you know how hard it is to get sweet tea outside of the south? (read: impossible!)

my only complaint about minnie's is the price: it's frigging expensive! so minus one star.
author: Greg A.

description:
Love this place...it's a cool little spot for some bbq...I normally get the pork ribs with a side of mac n cheese.

The mac n cheese is delish..I love how they have bits of cornbread in it!

AND I heart the mustard bbq sauce - it's my fave!
author: Jade B.

description:
Came here today for an early dinner. The service was really good. All of them were nice.

However, the food was so-so. I was really looking forward to eating here, but I was a bit disappointed. The tri-tip was dry, the pork ribs weren't fall-off-the-bone tender and weren't as moist as I expected. On a good note, the brisket was delicious. I'd go back for that.

The potato salad was ok. The mac and cheese was ok. The sweet tea was delicious. The sauces were ok. I liked the mustard one the most.

Overall, I probably wouldn't come back here for anything other than the brisket. I suggest Rib Shack in San Bruno. A small drive from the city with parking and delicious meats.

Hats off to the service, though. They clean-up after you if you dine-in. And when you try to give them the plates back, they tell you that they'll take care of it.
author: Diana Lyn Z.

description: I'm not a meat eater. Some weeks I can be considered a vegetarian, but on those off weeks, it's because of Memphis Minnie's. The service is a little brisk, you better not take a table before you've ordered (what a genius concept!) or else you'll be called out in front of the entire restaurant. The brisket and tri-tip are my absolute favorite. The mac n cheese, fries and sweet potato pie are all divine. The potato salad eh, not so much. The only creepy thing is that there are hand drawn pigs on paper towels adorning the tables. It is a constant reminder that I'm eating an animal, but I can deal with it for BBQ that literally falls apart in my mouth.
author: Heidi S.

description: Very impressed with this joint. Try the ribs and Memphis meat combo with a side of sweet potatoes and beans.
author: Matt P.

description:
Pretty solid.  

Love the atmosphere here. Low down Texan diner style.  

Only had the Texas beef brisket here and enjoyed it.  Melts in your mouth and the addition of the bbq sauces make it even better.  

My only complaint, some of the pieces were especially chewy and fatty.  But other pieces were to die for.  

Price- Half pound of brisket for $7.85 Pretty good deal
author: Chase F.

description:
I went to this place because they catered one of my BFF's wedding receptions (yes, they had BBQ, get over it).  It rocked then, and it rocks now.

The food is decently priced and is melt in your mouth yummy.

If you don't like the neighborhood, get it to go......

It would get more stars if it changed locations (i.e. to HayesValley) and if it were cleaner.
author: David S.

description:
Their banana pudding alone is a 5 star review.  The only place in the world I'd pay $5 for banana pudding.  It's SOOOO good.  Skip the barbecue and order 2 of them.  

Well, actually the BBQ is pretty damn good too and so is the sauce.  And their fries.  Actually, everything I've had there is tasty.  And the first time I went there Samantha Bee from the Daily Show was there.  And I was eating with about 10 other bears and she was a little scared.  Good times.
author: Andy G.

description:
Stopped in for lunch after reading some great reviews. I had the sampler with greens and mac & cheese. Very good BBQ, better than most I had on a trip to South Carolina earlier this year. Nice smoke ring ,the ribs held together until you bite into then they give way and fall of the bone. The brisket was good although a little dry.The staff was very helpful and when I said it was my first trip in, asked if they could make some recommendations. which were spot on. The sauces were very good and on the table where they belong not on the meat. 
When your inside this joint it's hard to believe your in San Francisco and not somewhere in the deep south.
author: Mike P.

description:
There were 2 really good things about this place: 
1) the brisket - excellent. meat was tender and delicious. i would make the trip out here just for this. 
2) the stoopid hot hot sauce - it's spicy and sweet and oh so good. being korean, it doesn't qualify as "hot" to me, but it sure does have a kick. after you finish eating, all of a sudden you start to feel the burn on your lips. 

my bf and i shared the 3 meat combo. the sausage, ribs and brisket. it was more than enough to feed the both of us. the sausage was pretty tasteless, nothing special. the ribs i have to say were terrible. they tasted like they had been sitting there all day and then served out to us. we figured, since it was 5pm, it was the last of the lunch meat. not good at all. i actually wished we hadnt ordered those 2 meats and just got an ultra huge helping of the brisket. 

mac and cheese side was pretty good and potato salad was better than most bbq joints. corn bread was nothing special. just some plain bread would have been better. 

i didnt care for the vinegar sauce. the mustard sauce was ok. the texas  sauce was just an inferior version of the stupid hot sauce. 

3 item combo plate $18.00 with 2 drinks and an extra cornbread came to a total of $25 (including tax).
author: Karen B.

description:
probably some of the best BBQ I've ever had. fast service. great meats. fantastic sauces. good value. place gets crowded easily though.

I got the fries as a side dish, but I don't recommend them if you have an uneasy stomach.
author: Mark B.

description:
I checked this place out a few days ago after seeing all the great reviews on yelp. Having tasted bbq from some of the champs like Big Bob Gibson BBQ, i can say that Memphis Minnie's definitely holds its own. The place is a no frills, order at the counter kinda place, which is fine since no one's there for the ambiance. 

Our group tried out the rib tips, fried cheese grit sticks, brisket, pulled pork and St.Louis style ribs, andouille sausage and sides of mac and cheese, coleslaw, and just for good measure... the fried peach pies and banana pudding. In general everything was great, my only disappointment was the mac and cheese....not very cheesy, a little on the mushy side. Besides that, a great overall first impression. The service is great and speedy and the place has a cool quirky style that works well. Would definitely recommend.
author: Pretesh D.

description:
I have lived in SF now for 12 years under the assumption we simply did not have good barbecue in our town.  I stand corrected.

While this is by no means the best barbecue I've had (you need to go to Birmingham, AL for that), it sure as hell runs a good second.   The meat is succulent and flavorful.  Sauce is served on the side as it should be.
