The side dishes leave a little to be desired.  I like the mac&cheese (althouth not as good as Hard Knox), but the greens left a great deal to be desired.  

All in all I'm giving them 4 starts just cuz it's great to have BBQ in SF.
author: Russell D.

description:
If you like perfectly cooked meat that has not been seasoned, then this is your place. The boy and I went there for lunch today and were both extremely disappointed. We tried the brisket, tri-tip, and ribs. The texture of all the meat was very good - obviously slow cooked and smoked. But, the dry rubs left a LOT to be desired, and we didn't like any of the sauces on the table. The sides did not help at all. Mac and cheese was tasteless, greens and slaw were swimming in vinegar, corn muffin was tough and chewy. We didn't get fries, but they did look tasty on other people's plates.

Stick to the meat options, and bring your own bbq sauce!
author: Corinne R.

description: Rib tips were so dry and hard they were inedible. Mac and cheese had some kind of cornbread crumble on it yuck. greens had this sweet and sour taste to the disgusting. only decent thing was the fried peach pie. I will not go back just not worth it. blahhhh
author: Tiffany F.

description:
I have been wanting to come here for over two years and finally made it there today. I had seen them on Check Please Bay Area and was excited to hear all the great reviews. I'm a BBQ lover and seek out the best BBQ whenever I can. And since this place is only a few blocks from where I live, even better. Unfortunately, I didn't like it. 

From the start, I was greeted at the register where you place your order by some dreary guy who seemed miserable and talked like a slow robot. That aside, I ordered my BBQ pork sandwich with coleslaw; I like to put the coleslaw on the sandwich itself. When my order was called I picked up my sandwich. 

The initial appearance looked fine. The bread was probably the best part of the sandwich though. I was quickly disappointed to see that the slaw was vinegar based; I really love the mayo versions better on my sandwich. That aside, the sandwich was served dry so you could choose from 4 sauces that were on the table. I thought that was pretty cool and quickly did a sampling of all four. Unfortunately, I didn't really like them. 

The vinegar based sauce was too wet and just tasted like vinegar. The mustard sauce tasted just like runny generic yellow mustard. And the weirdest one was their standard red BBQ sauce. It was a bit too sweet but even weirder, it had this odd taste of curry! I couldn't really pin point the spice, but it had very aromatic undertones of curry. It was not good! 

So how can you enjoy a BBQ pork sandwich without a good sauce! And with the vinegar cole slaw I just did not enjoy it. I was really torn to get the brisket. It may be better, but the sauces will still suck. Maybe I'll order it to go and use my better BBQ sauces at home.
author: Philip D.

description:
This is an awesome Tennessee-style BBQ joint. 

Pros: I always get the St. Louis pork ribs and they are always very tender and full of smokey flavor. The homemade sauces are all great (Note: None of them are typical BBQ sauces Californians are used to. They are purely Tennessee style with lots of vinegar and mustard). Service is pretty friendly. Most of the sides are pretty good, the mac n cheese is the best.

Cons: Parking is HELL near Haight Street!!! This is really the main reason why I don't go more often then once every few months. My boyfriend loves eating the food, but he always pays for it later with major stomach problems. I don't seem to have problems but he is not the only one I know who has had these complaints. Not all the sides are good, example the sweet potatoes are usually undercooked.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I have been wanting to come here for a while and I finally made it here today. I think the impression I got from this place is that it is good BBQ for someone that has never had good BBQ before. But for me, with my fair amount of experience with good BBQ, this is just average BBQ.

My girlfriend and I both got the pork sandwich. The pork wasn't dry but it wasn't especially moist either. The slaw was nothing special (not creamy enough) and the sauces weren't great either. The North Carolina sauce (vinegar) was too watery, the Texas sauce (regular BBQ sauce) was too sweet, and the South Carolina Sauce was good, but not something I generally want on my pork. I found a decent mix with the North Carolina + Texas sauce.

The mac and cheese was decent but unspectacular. In general the sides were too small and the food was overpriced ($7.50 for sandwich + small side). I'd give this place 2.5 stars if I could, but even after all I complained about above I would say that I did enjoy my lunch, so it gets 3 stars instead of 2.
author: Stu M.

description: I am reiterating my 5-star review. This is one of my top 5 eateries in SF. It is fantastic. How can it be less than 4-star average is saddening me. Guess where I am going for lunch? To put my money where my mouth is.
author: Elsa T.

description:
Im from the south and have spent a great deal of time in Memphis, KC, and Texas, and over the years, i've become somewhat of a BBQ connoisseur. 

No, Memphis Minnie's doesn't have the worlds best BBQ, but they DO have the best BBQ in SF. Their meats are actually excellent, i just dont love their sauce choices. If they had good sauce, a definite 5 stars, but today i couldn't figure out which sauce i hated the least. 

Luckily for them, their meats are just as good without sauce. Also, their staff is wonderful. Everyone is always so friendly. I should start going here more often.
author: Bennett C.

description:
Food is a solid B but the service is mediocre and slow. 
Food is gratuitously smokey. I like smoke but too much is just that. 
Sauce is ok but is way to watery
Pastrami wood be great if it wasnt so salty and overly smokey.
author: John S.

description:
I have been a loyal Memphis Minnite for a few years now, eating there once every couple weeks.  It has always been my go to "i'm stressed and therefore need pork" joint.  Over the years they have had a few off days but for the most part , especially lately, they have been great.

Now I must say - they have been AMAZING.  On the most important day of my life they came through with the best BBQ I have ever had.

MM's catered my wedding.  I interviewed loads of "wedding" caterers and realized they were overpriced and would be serving half-assed hotel style food.  We decided to go BBQ.  It was going to be a stressful day and I would need pork. 

It was a risky decision.  Half my guests were coming from Britain and had no idea what Southern BBQ was, not to mention my now husband is a vegetarian!  What would he eat?

Aside from marrying my husband, MM's was the best wedding related decision I made.  I can not say enough about John and his crew.  They even wore starched white chef jackets!!! The BBQ was amazing, pulled pork and brisket with loads of sides that were veggie friendly.  Perfect.  I wish I had eaten more but my dress was prohibitive.  Many of my guests said it is the best wedding food they have ever had.  People are STILL talking about how good it was. 

Inexpensive, outstanding, professional.  God, I wish I had eaten more.
author: Monkeyfaced E.

description: I went for the St Louis Ribs - no sides. It was good BBQ. Sauces were weaker than I expected, especially when one of the sauces had a scull and cross bones on it but was not even hot as Tabasco.  Bring on the heat please!  Liked the people and comfortable to sit there on my own and eat some ribs.  Will return again but with my own sauce.
author: Doreen D.

description:
I was so disappointed with MM that I started a Yelp account to warn others.

I'd read so many good things about MM here on Yelp that I was excited to go. The atmosphere was cool, and the people very friendly. The quality of food, however, was really poor. 

It's been mentioned that the brisket was like beef jerkey, and I couldn't agree more. Slow cooked shouldn't be "dried out and shriveled." Coupled with the tiny side portions the presentantion reminded me of a prison movie.

I was quite honestly insulted that anyone with a conscious could have put this stuff in a container for someone to eat... and for what they charged, it was pretty much ridiculous.

Granted, this was during a week day and the food might be better at dinner or weekends but I am more than reluctant to give this restaurant another try.

It should go without saying that the quality should be the same (hopefully great) whenever that 'open' sign is on the door.
author: Chris T.

description:
As many have said, meat good! 

It's my 2nd time there, but first as a yelper.

The meat in the sandwiches is very good, but what really makes the experience is there mustard based sauce.  Delicious!  Also tried the slaw, which is a different approach from your traditional slaw.  Has almost a vinaigrette dressing rather than mayonnaise based.  Tasty, but I think I'll stick to the normal slaw from now on.

One quirk that gave us a good laugh.  They have a sign up inside advertising a sunday brunch (bbq + brunch... hmmm?) and I guess they've stopped doing it, but instead of taking down the sign they just taped a big red cross over it.  Guess someone must have been very attached to that sign.
author: Keith S.

description: Best BBQ place I've eaten at in the city! The pork (in all styles and dishes) is awesome- juicy, tender, and tasty. The sides are all amazing and the banana cream pie dessert is to-die-for. This place is a BBQ joint, so don't expect a fancy dining experience or frou-frou dishes on the menu. This is the place to go when you just want some damned good, homestyle BBQ cooking. A little on the pricey side, but totally worth it for the portions and taste.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I've had better. That's right. I said it.

The food is OKAY; when I went with a group of friends we all tried different types of BBQ and I think that the beef brisket is probably the best out of everything. I had the beef brisket sandwich and I thought there was too much bread to the amount of meat, and actually ended up just leaving a lot of the bread on my plate. The fries were okay, not incredible. The sides were... interesting, not memorable.
author: Jen E.

description: This place is solid. I love the BBQ here as well as the sides. I've only been a few times but have never left disappointed. Definitely a fan.
author: Lauren B.

description:
These are all the things I remember about Minnie's after having been here twice:

- the brisket is FANTASTIC. I didn't even know what brisket was before I ordered it, but omfg! Melt in your mouth, flavorful, yum!
- side dishes were so-so to me.
- do NOT sit down at a table until you have ordered. There's a sign that says so and I watched a bunch of people get yelled at by the staff.
- the sauces on the table are good, but I'd probably buy brisket by the pound to go next time.
author: Wendy T.

description:
The sweet tea is absolutely perfect. I should know. 

A few dishes are not *entirely* Southern, but probably altered just a bit to be less threatening to the West Coast palate. I forgive the nice people at Memphis Minnie's, as I understand their need to appeal to everyone.

The staff is very friendly, too - the way it should be in a BBQ joint.
author: Jill C.

description:
Today  I learned what southern hospitality is. I have to say I'm a fan.

It's not very often that I go to barbecue joints, but going to Memphis Minnie's is making me think I should a bit more often. Where ever I go, I take the atmosphere into account, and to put it simply Memphis Minnie's is very pleasant. They greeted me with a hello and a smile, and were even kind to me as I stumbled through my order (I have a bad habit of going to the cashier without knowing what I want.) 

My smoked Texan beef brisket was tasty though lacking that special something. I should have thought to use one of the barbecue sauces available at the table. 

Though the decor is like a watered down Bennigan's (flair, now in wall format) I found myself comfortably chewing away and soaking everything in. Definitely somewhere to return to and try more of their menu.
author: Keith M.

description:
This place really isn't worthy of all the hype (I certainly hope this isn't actually the best BBQ in the city..). 

Their ribs were fatty and nothing special (in fact I left most of them on my plate due to their flabbines). T
he macaroni and cheese was room temperature, greasy, and flavorless. The tart 'n tangy slaw was descent but I could definitely live without it. Their bbq sauces were alright but not my thing. 
Basically everything I had was leagues under what I was expecting and I will not be returning.

2.5 stars - I really hope I just went on a terribly off day..
author: Natalie G.

description:
Things I am an expert on: How to score 20 goals in one period with Pavel Bure in NHL '94 for Sega Genesis; Finding things I can wrap with bacon and bake in the oven (e.g. everything), Pretending to still be somewhat in the indie music loop by responding to questions about bands as such, "I've never heard them, but I've heard OF them."

Things I am not an expert on: BBQ. Everything else.

That being said, Minnie's makes a damn tasty brisket sandwich, which is made even more awesome with that freaking mustard sauce on the table. God damn that was delicious.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Reading some of the reviews, I really wasn't sure what to expect when I came here.  Some love it and some hate it.  It could be that Memphis is inconsistent???  

Well, for my group, we all pretty much were highly disappointed.  Of course 4 out of the 6 in the party went to Kinder's in Reno about a month before our visit here so we had pretty high standards.  Kinder's was infinitely better than Memphis...  The texture of the meat, the sauce...  Just about anything you could think of would be better.  

But even if we did not go to Kinder's, we certainly would have had the same opinion that Memphis, on our visit, was extremely substandard.  It may be good on some days but I don't think I could ever go back to take a chance that they are having a good day.  I will just have to visit another place to go "take a chance"...  Sooner the better...  Had a craving for BBQ on the day we went and had a STRONGER Craving afterwards because it was so bad...
author: Mark W.

description:
Wickedly good BBQ, super friendly service and piggily wiggilies everywhere. What more do you need?

We had the brisket, smoked pork and rib tips. All were excellent. There were three tasty sauces on the table along with a roll of taper rolls. I highly recommend the pit smoked beans. 

You order up front and likewise pick up your BBQ there when they call out for you. The guy helping us was hilarious. 

The music playing was.. "suitable", they serve sake (huh?) and you can order meats by the pound.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Beef brisket is gooood. Everything else is ok. I can't believe so many people gave this place a 5 star. This is not a 5 star place and I am not talking about only fancy places deserve 5 stars; 5 stars is about overall experience. Mac and Cheese side dish was better than average yet too soft. Ribs were not that great; Houston's has much better ribs even Outback. Chicken was ok.
The place has a cool vibe to it with all the cheesy pig memorabilia, but as a whole the place didn't quite cut it for me.
author: Lo F.

description:
I had really high hopes for this southern BBQ joint.  A bits in the seedy area of the Haight but nonetheless, the food isn't worth traveling for, or even walking a few blocks for.

We ordered a lot of food to share - the pork ribs, beef ribs, and brisket. Each entree comes with 2 sides each so we tried all the sides: chard, sweet potatoes, corn bread, mac and cheese, potato salad, and coleslaw. We also got a huge plate of BBQ seasoned fries and fried corn fritters. The pork ribs were good and at least tender. The beef ribs were charred and totally overcooked. I felt like I had to chew on a piece about 50 times before it was manageable to swallow. The brisket was dry. All the sides were really unimpressive. We all agreed the best thing on the menu was the fried corn fritters and the ranch sauce that came with it. Anchor and Sierra on tap so that was a plus. Due to the meal being so mediocre, we didn't want to waste anything on dessert.
author: Josephine H.

description:
Over---rated.

I used to pretend that I loved this place. My ex-bf loved it. I still don't get why. Maybe that's why he's my ex.
author: Hana N.

description:
I hadn't been in this place since it was the Spaghetti Western back when the Lower Haight was still relatively cool. I can tell you, I won't return here unless I'm forced.

I ordered a combo sandwich (half pork/half brisket). I'd recommend that you stick to the brisket only. The pulled pork was so over done that it looked and tasted like pre-chewed food for senior citizens with no teeth. The brisket was pretty good, but everything was cold--both meats.

The greens (a side dish) was cloying--what ever it was they add to it, I hope was just a mistake--tasted like someone dropped a Mr Pibb in to the collards.

The service was brusque but ok. I asked for an extra plate, the guy grabbed one, dropped it at the other side of the counter and told me it's over there as he walked past me. For some reason he couldn't hand it directly to me.
author: Hank S.

description:
Eh. Not bad, but not great either. The pulled pork didn't taste smoky - it tasted more like it had been cooked with propane. Ew. The sides were also kinda yucky (the mac and cheese especially!), with the exception of the baked beans which are really great. 

I've had both Memphis and Carolina-style BBQ and this just didn't do it for me.
author: Beth T.

description:
This spot is very bad, and has been bad for years.

The ribs are tough and served cold.  
The sides are simply not tasty.
The prices are expensive.

Even Roadside BBQ, another subpar BBQ on geary st. is better.
author: Sheila S.

description: This yelp is in response to STACY S and GLORIA who gave Memphis Minnies bad reviews. First off you must be from a different planet because if you have traveled this great country and tasted barbeque you would know that BARBEQUE IS NOT GOING TO BE SERVED TO YOU RIGHT OUT OF THE SMOKER. Most sauces should be thin as to not over power that hard work they have put in ie (THE MEAT) There meats smoke anywhere from 4-18 hours. The sides are not the focus at this joint. The MEAT IS. THATS WHY THEY HAVE PIGS EVERYWHERE. If there focus was to sell macaroni and cheese by the pound it would probably be called MACARONI MINNIES. BUT ITS NOT. This place serves up the best barbeque on the west coast. Hands down. If  you dont beleive me you can come to my house and I will slap you in the face with a shirt that still smells like Barbeque. I sometimes go to my closet just to get a wif of what I am missing. So to  all you yelpers out in Internet land do not be detured by two blind, obviously very sick, twisted, individuals with NO TASTE BUDS. MEAT BABY. MEAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jacob G.

description: I dunno what it is but every time I come in here I try my hardest to eat something delicious and it just doesn't happen. It's like a sick joke or something. Everyone around me is shoving food into their mouths and I, sit sadly in my seat wishing the food on my plate was better. I've been here several times and i WISH that I felt the happiness that the people i come with feel. I have tried several times to like their sauce selection and it just seems...not like the flavors i want to put onto my meat. I want a hardy BBQ sauce or a spicy tang to kick it up a notch. Doesn't happen. I dont know why. I like the place a lot, and I could see how people may be turned off by the owners, but come on its a BBQ joint, they need some kinda attitude. I really like their fried onion strings though, they can be quite delicious.
author: Amy M.

description: MMm Brisket I LOVE Brisket ! Memphis Minnies is a great place to eat. Slow smoked meat very tasty and u get different sauces u can try at ur table. I think ive tried about everything there now LOL Usually not too long of a wait but they are closed on mondays or tuesdays I think. So I definately recommend ...Great SF BBQ
author: Alyssa S.

description:
yes, yes, amazing delectable meats that melt in your mouth and not on your recently purchased t-shirt.
but the key to BBQ joint heaven is the great & friendly service these folks provide. 
seriously, these days in San Francisco service with a smile and questions answered usually comes with a price (aaah~! maybe that's the newly mysterious SF food&drink tax..) to match. no, not here. 


"easy, greasy, beautiful, covergirl"  4 stars for the Minnie's
author: Tomas V.

description:
Definitely a fun place to go for bbq.  The food is pretty good too.  they have a bunch of different sauces on the tables that you can choose from to put on your food... I've actually only been here once, but would say it is really a fun place to go.  I really enjoyed their side of beans, and the pulled pork- yum!

The decor is so eclectic, and cluttered- but in a funny way.  The people that work there look really "down home" (whatever that means)... parking on the weekends is really bad, and the inside of the restaurant isn't really that big, so either go when its not super busy, or i suggest you be prepared to eat outside standing on the street or go home with your food!

Overall, i think it is a fun place to go with friends to get a sorta cheesy southern bbq experience.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
In college I met some friends from Texas while on tour; they were in a band together and when they came through Cali they stayed at my house.  I had promised them we would BBQ the next day and they all seemed very excited.  

Fast forward to the next afternoon and the look of disappointment on their faces when I pulled out the Weber grill and the hamburger patties.  

"I thought we were gonna BBQ?!?!?!"
"That's what I'm doing."
"That's not BBQ!"
"WTF are you talking about??  What do you call this?"
"Dude, you're just grilling."

I then learned that what I had always known as a BBQ was just grilling and that real BBQ involved slow-cooking meat for several hours with all kinds of fancy sauces.  This is the kind of BBQ you will find at Memphis Minnie's.  Warm tender cuts of meat and delicious sides; and you HAVE to try the sauces, they are truly amazing.

My only gripe is you don't always get that much food for your money, I dare say it is just slightly overpriced.  But if you want to get a deal order the rib-tip plate which is the price of a sandwich but eats like a meal.
author: Alex K.

description:
Ummm.  That 18 hour Texas Beef Brisket.  HELLA HELLA DRY.

The greens were good.

That's it.
author: sHoo o.

description:
Why do I still convince myself every so often that "maybe, just maybe this time it will be good" when it's always just dry, bland, and smeared with room-temperature BBQ sauce hours after the meat finished cooking.  

Oh, and I even tried the brunch once.  Ordered red beans and rice and got a pile of beans next to a pile of rice.  WTF?? I'm supposed to mix it myself?  Sad.

Extra star for having a seeming monopoly on the BBQ market in San Francisco.
author: matt c.

description:
3 1/2 stars, rounded up

Ordered take-out for lunch: Memphis smoked pulled pork sandwich, sweet cornbread muffin side, a slice of pecan pie and some sweet tea.

Yummy sammich. I can imagine it would have tasted better piping hot. Really good smoky flavor and not dry like I feared. I love love love that mustard BBQ sauce. Really good acidity. I need to buy a bottle of it some time. I should have added some of the Beelzebub's hot sauce before leaving. The meat could have used just a pinch of a spicy kick. The bun itself was cored out to hold more meats but was therefore also more prone to spillage. I wish the bread was a little more substantial.
 
I wasn't wild about the cornbread muffin, but it was decent. I hope it tastes different when it's fresh out of the oven, because mine was dry.
 
Minnie's pecan pie, though, was soooooo delicious. I wish I bought a whole pie.

The sweet tea was very sweet, maybe too sweet for most folks. It reminded me of sago at gulaman (palm sugar water drink with tapioca pearls).

For my purposes (Lower Haight destination for the rare workday lunch expedition) I think I'd rather make the long lunch trek to Rosamunde's for a Tuesday burger, but I'd be willing to go back and try it again to give a more well-rounded appraisal.
author: Grace L.

description:
A pig is not safe here.  

Memphis Minnie's is one of the premier barbeque joints in the Bay Area.  It's always a treat.  The pulled pork melts in your mouth and they make their own pastrami (only available on Wednesdays).  Every meat is fantastic there.  I feel lucky to have this down the street.
The restaurant is bright and adorned with barbeque and blues posters.
author: Sam L.

description: A thimble-full of macaroni is an unacceptably small portion for the price. I'll go back, though, for the pulled pork sandwich. It is (usually) awesome.
author: Jason M.

description:
On Height between Filmore and Steiner, I remember there was another BBQ restaurant that went out of business not long ago. They were one of the branches of excellent Korean style grill "Hibachi" (Note: Hibachi is a Japanese word, but the business is run by Koreans. They serve awesome food that isn't available in elsewhere.) 

When I noticed that "Hibach" was gone, I said to myself "Competition level of eateries in this area must be too high". So when I walked in Memphis Minnie's, my expectation for their BBQ was more than descent. I had a reason to believe there must have been a note-worthy quality and special preparation behind each item they served. Otherwise, how could they knock "Hibachi" out of the block for good? Well, I was in it for a rude awakening. 

For the first time, I dumped my BBQ into a trash bag without going for a second bite. As repeatedly mentioned here by many viewers, ribs was dry, tasteless, cold, and the smell of disgusting fat, instead of savory smell of properly smoked meat, reminded me of a bad cooking procedures. I will not go back to Memphis Minnie's again until they invite a real pit master from a Southern State to reintroduce to them the way to cook BBQ. 

Food was very bad and unacceptable, so I did not look into other criteria. 
I still do not understand what made good place go bankrupt and sub-standard neighbor live on. Perhaps, the hypocritical tendency of Height hippies has been going against natural selectivity throughout generations.
author: yota L.

description:
The BBQ here is the best in the City and some of the best I've had anywhere. The brisket was so tender you almost need a spoon to eat it. The sweet pork was amazing as well along with the sides, particularily the collared greens if you want to try something a little different. The owner is a character and he takes a lot of pride in the quality of the food and the art of good BBQ. They smoke the brisket for 18 hours and have a poor guy who spends the night with an alarm clock to stoke the coals (seriously).
Great staff, fun atmosphere, incredible food and cold Shiner Bock!! A+
author: Eric G.

description:
I love good BBQ, but Memphis Minnie's disappointed.  

Summary: two stars because the meal wasn't that great, the prices for the quality didn't match, but the dessert and sides were good. 

The meat on the two dishes I shared with a friend was dry.  

They don't have enough sauces on the tables.  Two - really?   Only two sauces? 

The greens weren't half bad - well flavored. 

The pecan pie - one of the best I've ever had.  

The corn muffins - pretty ok.  

The prices were a bit steep for the quality of food.  

I feel bad saying this, but Famous Dave's (a BBQ chain primarily existent on the east coast) is better than Memphis Minnie's.  Then again, Famous Dave's is one of the best managed chain's in the country.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I was expecting a lot for a place that is known as having "the best BBQ in San Francisco..."  The guy at the counter wasn't extremely friendly, I asked him what the best side was and he gave me aaa nothing to work with.  My friend who was fiending for BBQ and who insisted we go to Memphis Minnie's asked him if the sandwich was large and if there were sizes (she wanted a lot) he assured us that the sandwiches would be substantially large....WHICH they were not!
I ordered a spicy chicken sandwich with seasoned fries.  Fries were great, chicken was ok/good, bread was alright.  I asked for a water and the water kept coming out as Hi-C (ew).
I went to BBQ-fest in Memphis this year...and Memphis Minnie's does not resemble real Memphis BBQ much at all.  This place does not live up to the hype...so 2 stars for you Memphis Minnies!
author: m g.

description:
My new favorite food. Been craving the the Southern Star (beef brisket/sweet pork combo) sandwich I had last week.  Yum.

UPDATE: Just went for the Sunday brunch and it rocks too.
author: Val U.

description:
Memphis Minnie's has the best pulled pork I've had outside of Tennessee. 

That's all I need to say. Oh, and the slaw...THE SLAW. Not creamy and sweet (ick) but vinegary and savory. mmmmmmm.

The only reason they don't get 5 stars is because the don't deliver. Sometimes I wanna have my pork delivered, you know?
author: Teri M.

description: Not the best I've ever had but man that sweet potato pie is superb. I had two slices back to back in one sitting. Does not dissapoint. I've had better ribs. The sauces are pretty good though. If you're wondering where I've had better ribs, try the Nugget's Hotel Reno Rib Cookoff during labor day weekend and you'll know what I mean.
author: Jon H.

description:
Sooooo, generally speaking, I love bbq.  They were good for dry bbq, but I'm a wet rib kinda gal.  Their brisket was delicious.  I don't like any of their sauces, personally and none of my friends did either.

Oh, and one of my friends got extremely sick and is almost positive it was from this place.
author: Josie A.

description: Memphis Minnies is one great BBQ place. I recommend hitting it up on Wednesday's and ordering the pastrami reuben. They cook / smoke / steam the meat for ten days before cutting it up. I added the mac and cheese as a side which was awesome. Dallas "Chef" makes some oft the best BBQ on the west coast.
author: Tim F.

description: OMG- We went here right after the Haight street fair. We just happened to come across and we thought why not. It looked good and truth be told at the moment BBQ did sound good. So we came in and food there to be a line, we knew we found something good if that many people were waiting. Little did we know. The guy who was taking the orders was very rude. I felt like i was on his time and not like a new customer. We ordered and my friends chicken meal was raw. Seriously the chicken bone on both pieces of meat (leg & thigh) had blood still on it. The chicken wasn't cooked all the way. The corn muffin was dry. Overall it was bad. I will never come and eat at this place again.
author: Omar J.

description:
I love this place.  The Southern Star, the Brisket, the Pastrami (only on Wednesdays), the Burger (yes that's right, I know it's almost a crime to order a burger at a BBQ joint, but trust me - it's delicious!), the greens, the fries, the slaw, the potata salad... I could go on.  In 3 years of frequenting this spot, I've never had a bad meal.  

The thing that gets me is that the meat has that authentically smoky taste that BBQ should have.  BBQ isn't about the sauce.  (Although their sauces are super yummy and difficult to pass up.)  The staff is always extremely friendly and personable.  Let me say it again, I love this place.
author: Clementine D.

description:
When we first arrived, I thought it looked and smelled just like a good, no frills BBQ place I would find in Texas.  When I asked the guy taking my order if the brisket sandwich came sliced or chopped, he asked me if I was from the Lone Star State.  It turns out he was from Texas as well.  To my dismay, the sandwich only came sliced, but I ordered it anyway.  We had a large group and it was crowded, so we had to huddle near the bathroom until a table was available.  It wasn't a problem since we had a pitcher of beer to help pass the time.  I give them an A+ for southern hospitality.  One guy even iced a few pint glasses for us so we wouldn't have to drink our beer from warm glasses straight from the dishwasher.  Nice job.

I have to say I was a little disappointed with the sandwich.  First of all, it came on a French baguette.  Also, the sandwich came sans sauce, you had to add the sauce yourself at the table.  I'm of the persuasion that BBQ sandwiches should come smothered in sauce - you should get dirty eating them.  But the brisket itself was very good.  And the fries were great.  I would probably go back again, I'll be trying the homemade cornbread muffins next.
author: Sarah S.

description:
With all due respect to Kansas City and (maybe) Texas, when I think BBQ, I think North Carolina pulled pork BBQ with a side order of hush puppies and cole slaw... in NC, you get a heaping portion of each and it runs you about $3.99.  The meat is tender and the sauce is delicous... this is why it would be my choice for my last meal on earth.

And eating at Memphis Minnie's is just like being back in North Carolina!  Is what I wish I could say, except that the reality is that this place is crap.  The only reason I didn't give it 1 star is because at least they attempted to serve BBQ, which you don't find a lot of out here.  The meat was dry, the sauce was off, and it was way overpriced (and yes, I have lived in SF for long enough not to expect a $4 meal, but for what you get here, it's overpriced, even for SF).

I would recommend not going to this place, but if you do, please don't tell your friends that you've eaten real BBQ.
author: Ben G.

description:
What a place to pork-out, literally.......

This place is like walking into a smoking hot BBQ joint in the south.    All the meat, I believe is smoked, and YOU select the sauce you want to use, at your table.      And the sides are great.     Everything is home-made and you just couldn't find better.

Bob - as always - your meat rocks......

BTW - I recommend this place to everyone I know that loves BBQ and they love it too.     I've had one friend cater a wedding anniversary party from Mempis Minnié's and another friend cater her Law School grad partry from here.      FABULOUS.
author: Duke H.

description:
I'm giving the full 5 stars. Go for the brisket.
I've had world-class barbecue from all over the place, and this is some of the finest brisket that can be found. Outstanding.
author: Lisa T.

description: Do yourself a favor and get the tri-tip plate. The meat is tender, the crust is crunchy, and the sides are excellent. They had Japanese Sake too, which struck me as off pudding. I guess Sake and BBQ go good together? Skip the Sake and get more corn muffins.
author: Andy H.

description:
This is my new favorite bay area BBQ joint period. I was told about this place from a coworker and when I was working in the city for a couple week i thought id go check it out. 

We were working up the street on Fillmore and took a walk down the hill past the crazy old guy with turrets who likes to yell look over here and then smile and look away or my favorite OATMEAL!! then he giggles. Oh man love the crazies in the city. 

Anywhoo back to Memphis. 
So I ended up liking this place so much I went here for like a week and a half straight. Ive tried damn near everything on the menu. 

My favorite is the tri-tip sangwich with mac n cheese side.If it wasn't so piggly I would have drank the rest of the mac sauce out of the cup. The beans are magical sweet smokey with a dash of cinnamon. the BBQ sauces are great my fav is the mustard based sauce which you can buy for like 6 bucks there. 

Smoke chickens are out of control my work partner and i decided to hog out get a couple sandwiches and share a whole chicken. Oh man that was a long walk back up the hill, I need a ski rope tied around me to be pulled back up the hill. 

ribs are falling off the bone nummalicious. 

chicken wings should be illegal.maybe if we shot the chef to restore order and balance amongst those who BBQ.. 

there shoe string onion rings are like crack. 

maybe they sneak meth or something into there food because it really is addicting. 

lemme tell you about pastrami Wednesday... this is the only day they have pastrami and a pastrami Reuben. I went deep on the Reuben.. it was so big and glutinous i had to remove most of the cheese and sauerkraut in order to pick it up and eat it.Im mean dont get me wrong i like tasty food but there is a line when you look at it and your just like yeah no i cant eat all that. 

they also have a sanwich that is in trial right now that isn't on the menu... 


THANKSGIVING SANGWICH!!!! I like thanksgiving.... 

Sourdough roll, Smoked Turkey, Stuffing, gravy and cranberry with sweet potato goodness on the side.....you pig!! yes i am. 

You must try this place i cant believe its only been open under 2 years,its gotta a cool old school southern vibe and they place kick ass old school blues music. 

I gained 12lbs i think while eating here everyday for a week and a half, but its all good i ate well for the next month and took care of that.
author: G P.

description:
I'm a regular at Minnie's. I normally would have given it four stars but my meal yesterday was very disappointing.

I asked for a lean cut of brisket -- the cashier repeated this back to me in order to indicate understanding, at least you'd think, right?

So finally our order is called and I can't wait to dig in. I put that first mouthful in to find out that the meat is extremely (1) fatty, and (2) room temperature. I truly hate to send things back, but after a few bits I really couldn't stand it. I told the guy behind the counter (VERY politely) that the meat was really cold and also I had asked for a leaner slice. Then the other woman behind the counter goes "yeah... we were calling your number like 5 times, of course it's cold." She acted like we purposely let it get cold so we could have the privilege of complaining? It was just so obnoxious, really made my meal a lot less enjoyable. They replaced it with another cut of brisket that was much leaner and warmer but still not that warm! How hard is it to keep the meat warm!?

Anyone else had any lousy experiences like this?
author: Jill M.

description:
Now listen here. I'm a big fan of barbecue. I can smell barbecue anywhere for up to two blocks. For that reason, I'm a wreck whenever I'm in Lower Haight.

I gotta say, Memphis Minnies has some good slow-cooked, fall-apart pork. But jeez, bbq'ers, for something as down home and gritty as a good barbecue, why pack in that San Francisco pretense? I guess Memphis Minnies doesn't believe in good old American St. Louis style wet barbecue (is that why Memphis is in the name?). Who cares if I like barbecue sauce on my barbecued food? I like barbecue sauce on my cereal!

To their credit, they do offer a few delicious, and unique, condiments for your otherwise dry bbq sandwich. Otherwise, well, they don't call it dry rub barbecue for nothin'.

I wish there were more options for barbecue in San Francisco. There's nothing like a good sweet and salty tri-tip sandwich on a hot Saturday. Memphis Minnie's pulls through in a pinch. I'd go so far as to say they are the best barbecue available out of the shallow BBQ pit that is San Francisco.
author: Scott L.

description:
Where can you go in the city for some really good BBQ? Memphis Minnies on Haight. 

I always order the St. Louis Style Smoked Pork Ribs plate with my two sides (mac n cheese and pit smoked beans) and a side of cornbread. When ordering, be careful not to get distracted by the tantalizing pecan pie or fried peach pie. You will roll out of this place stuffed by just eating the dinner alone.

I highly recommend drenching your ribs in the Texas Red sauce that is so generously placed in a bottle on each table.

And if you are vegetarian, no worries. The mac n cheese is good enough on its own.

This place is fun to eat in at. Honky Tonk music plays in the background and the staff is funny and super friendly. They know and love their BBQ! Not convinced? There are plenty of awards on the wall that prove that this place is the best BBQ in the city.

The only reason why Memphis Minnies doesn't get a full five stars from me is because parking sucks in the Haight. Plan accordingly. Don't wait until you are starved and craving BBQ. Allow yourself a little extra time to cash in on that parking karma.

Yee Haw!
author: Kathleen N.

description:
Memphis Minnie's just may be the best BBQ on the north side of Haight Street between Steiner and Fillmore, but that's about it.

All the trappings of a meat friendly dining experience. It's got big rolls of paper towels for slopping up your spills.  It's smoky, that's good, right? 
-- I liked the food. I had the brisket; yummy - but hungry for a good sauce. The sides, Mac & Cheese, greens, sweet potatoes - were all good. The flaky crust on the pecan pie alone will bring me back. 
I think Ms. Minnie may need to make a bigger commitment to her BBQ if she wants a special footprint in the BEST SF BBQ sweepstakes. 
They can have the fourth star on this review as soon as they take the burgers off the menu, really. (Rule #1 about BBQ: It should be all they do! If you can get a cheeseburger it's not a real BBQ place.)
author: Richard S.

description:
A big problem with BBQ in the west is that everyone wants it slathered in sweet ketchup (more or less). This is because they have never experienced the joy of slow-roasted meat. That is, a pork shoulder roasted for 16 hours or a piece of brisket-slow cooked and smoked for  20. Meat cooked this way doesn't need sauce because it is cooked so that it retains natural juices and fat. Overzealous texans ruined BBQ for everyone with their attitude that more fire == better. This is a culinary fallacy and must be considered when shopping for BBQ.

At Minnie's, the staff is saucy but the food is not. The meat comes out without sauce, and it doesn't need any - it is slow cooked, succulent, moist, BBQ heaven. You won't need a knife either - the meat is tender, and pulls apart easily with a fork. I had the brisket and the pork, with a side of collards. All three were amazing. I was born (and raised) in NC, and grew up eating slow-cooked, southern BBQ, and you will be hard-pressed to find better 'cue on this side of the world.

Seating is tight, but the staff does a good job of making sure everyone finds their way to a table. My only complaint would be about the indecisive fools ahead of me in line, but there isn't much the restaurant can do about that? Pick a meat and take a seat!
author: Jason M.

description:
Mmmmmm pork.

Okay I know we have some barbecue snobs on the list but jeebus effing christ people this is the lower haight.

Eat it, stuff your pork hole and enjoy it.
author: George K.

description: Went there for the first time with my girlfriend last week. I had the pulled pork and brisket and it was awesome! They even had North Carolina style vinegar barbeque sauce, which I LOVE, being from NC. Both cuts of meat were moist, tender and delicious! I had the cole slaw and mac and cheese, both of which were very good. We also had the brisket covered cheese fries which was good but a little too salty for my taste. The bacon pecan brittle was amazing! Definitely recommend them, definitely going back!
author: Vincent P.

description:
If you're one of the, "I'm from the deep south and this isn't real BBQ" people; honestly, what did you expect?  Do you know what city you're in or did a tornado carry you here while you were sleeping?  

I was raised mostly on Texas style BBQ, and this is different to be sure, but still very good and not exorbitantly priced in my opinion.

This is San Francisco by the way, so just give thanks that you found some familiar cuisine, (on Haight of all places) and try to enjoy your ribs or what have you.  I don't eat pork, but everything I do eat here (beef ribs, brisket, chicken etc.) is really pretty excellent.  

It's also nice that you can get a pitcher of beer as well as a flight of sake with your meal.  They have some very tasty varieties and the sake BBQ thing is actually quite delicious.  Just another unique, very un-southern characteristic of this distinctly Californicated BBQ joint.   

Yes, the sauces are a bit weird.  So are some of the sides, but the cornbread and sweet potatoes are great.  I don't care much for fries, but theirs are interesting.  The banana pudding, which I generally don't care for at all, is incredible there.

Oh, and they'll sell you one rib too.  They won't pour some soda into your hands or break a hundred, but they will sell you just one rib.

I have enjoyed several regional variations of "authentic" BBQ, and while this place is definitely non-traditional, I think it still qualifies since the meat is smoked and slow cooked.  It isn't like they bake their ribs or anything.  

Think about it this way; what would I do if I found a falafel cart in the middle of  Dixieland?  Complain because the hummus is too dry and my pita has sesame seeds on it?  

It's a fucking falafel in Dixieland.

Tell you what, if you're nice, I'll fry you up a catfish sandwich at my apartment just up the block.  I'll use an "authentic" southern catfish.

It's a Jewish catfish sandwich though, so it comes with swiss on marbled rye with a kosher dill and a pickled tomato.  

Plus you get your choice of egg, potato or macaroni salad as a side.
author: Hebrew K.

description:
I was so pleasantly surprised at the superb quality of the food I had! I had pulled pork, pit beans and coleslaw. The pulled pork was exactly the way it should be, the pit beans were exactly what you might expect as well. The coleslaw and sauces really set this place apart from the masses. The coleslaw, though sweet, contained some chewy marinated green peppers and was really very good with the BBQ. They had three kinds of sauce on each table. I opted for the traditional Carolina Mustard Sauce, because it is traditional with pork. OUTSTANDING! :-) It was a huge portion and you know? I ate every bit of it.
Oooh! I almost forgot. Stella Artoise on tap. Yummy with the BBQ!
author: Kimberley M.

description:
I heart this place.  I'm serious.  Memphis Minnie's is the s#*t.  I've eaten there many, many times and thus far they can do no wrong.

Tonight a couple friends got some take-out from MM and brought it over to my apartment.  From what I remember, we had the brisket, sweet smoked pork, ribs (not sure which ones) and sausage.  For sides, we had the mac & cheese, slaw & smoked pit beans.  A great assortment and EVERYTHING was good.  Especially the, well, all the meats, and the mac & cheese.  But the other sides were good, too.  They have 3 different BBQ sauces; a mustard based one, a vinegary sweet one and something called North Carolina that is a little thinner and full of spices.  All the sauces are great and I tend to have all 3 containers in front of me which I alternate between.  This place makes me feel like (and sound like) a gluttonous pig, but its really that good.

MM claims that sake is the best accompaniment for BBQ and I'm eager to go in and try that out sometime.  We had a great bottle of Argentinian white that did the trick.
author: Ariel D.

description:
Good: 
Texas BBQ sauce is soooo GOOD
friendly employees
decent prices

Bad: 
sometimes the meat can be a bit dry, so its best to drown everything in sauce.
Corn bread is usually dry also....
author: Vespa Fox C.

description:
I guess it's good but you got be aware of what you're ordering. I'm not well versed in meat lingo so I'm more a fan of the side dishes but eating a big bowl of beans isn't really substantial for dinner.

It's nice that they have sauces on the tables to allow customers to pick and choose what they want. But I don't like having to constantly soak my sandwich in sauce to give it some flavor and texture. Otherwise, the sandwich is very dry. 

I don't know, I'm not really a big meat eater so this place probably isn't for me. But I am a BIG fan of their banana pudding. Real bananas, whipped cream and nila wafers! So it's not a complete waste to go there.
author: Viv C.

description:
Memphis Minnie's was a bit of a paradox to me. How is it possible for such a dry rib to have meat that falls right off the bone being the biggest one?

I'd almost have to dub this the Reggie Jackson of BBQ places. It swings big, and that means when it connects the ball goes a long way. And when it misses, it falls flat on its face. Unfortunately, what it missed most on when my girlfriend and I went was the meat. The ribs were tender, but very dry, and the flavor was okay but not the best. The brisket was a little dry as well. The cornbread was so overcooked that it was nearly inedible, and the Mac and Cheese didn't have any cheese taste to it, and quite frankly the baked beans were just baked beans.

There were redeeming factors though--the fries, the banana pudding and the sauces. I made the mistake of ordering a large fries. I say mistake because my girlfriend and I were sad that we couldn't even finish half of them. The seasoning on top was great. And I don't think it would've been possible for me to eat the banana pudding faster. The sauces were the real key, as they almost singlehandedly saved the meat. If they could've covered up the texture and the dryness a little more, this rating may have been higher.

All in all, I probably will go back if I'm in the City. In spite of the two stars, there are things I'd like to mange upon again.. My guess is the place is inconsistent, and I'd like to catch them on a good night..
author: Joey J.

description:
While I enjoyed the food, I fell in love with "Memphis Minnie's" because of the experience.

Memphis Minnie's is, according to WordPress' terms of service, the official restaurant of Automattic.  http://en.wordpress.com/tos/  Based on their glowing endorsement and tempting photo, I stopped by for lunch on my way to the Golden Gate Bridge, assuming any calories I consumed would be burned off by the walk.

With its bright red exterior, it's fairly hard to miss Memphis Minnie's.  Inside, the tables are festooned with amusing caricatures of pigs eating pork.

I ordered the "Southern Star" sandwich sampler (which gave me a half texas brisket and a half sweet pork sandwich) along with mac 'n cheese and a piece of cornbread.  The sandwich was good but not great, made better by the various barbecue sauces lining the table.  The macaroni and cheese, on the other hand, was amazing.  The sauce was thick, and every bite was a juicy, aorta-clogging dream.
author: Michael A.

description:
Holy cow. Um...I mean pig. Pigs everywhere! 

Good stuff here. Super, super tender. Have the beef brisket, I'm telling ya. 

Wednesday is pastrami Wednesday. If you like Pastrami, I'm sure it's probably the best you can find in the city.
author: N B.

description:
I have only been there once for lunch, but so far I'm in Love!
The bbq' chx sandwich was heavenly, as was the pork n' beans I had on the side.  

Brunch sounds amazing, I've yet to venture over there for Sunday brunch, but red beans, rice, andouille sausage and eggs sound delicious!
author: Joanne D.

description:
Yea, this place is good. Very good. Once you walk in, nice atmosphere and first thing I noticed was the bottles of sauce for your food. I am a sauce guy, I love to slather sauce on anything. BBQ, Ketchup, Salsa Verde and pretty much anything liquid. I order my pork/ beef for a reasonable price, around $10 and proceded to douse my meat with sauce. Boy was that good.

Finished up my platter and saw "Corn Bread," I'm not a big fan of it, but I decided to try it. It blew my mind, I went back and bought 2 more. Love the bits of corn and the freshness of the bread. 

I wish they would open till midnight on weekends, so I can go there for late night munchies. Please open till 12!!! I beg you!
author: David L.

description:
Hole in the wall. Brisket good. Beer good. Beans good. Greens bad. Yummy.

Addendum: Pork eggrolls, OFF THE CHAINS. Beer, good. Yummy.

Addendum 2: Wednesday night. Pastrami sandwich. Now THAT's what I call a pastrami sandwich!!!! Yummy.

Addendum 3: Oh, get the red sauce instead of the weird mayo stuff with the pork eggrolls. And Reuben sandwiches? Never been top of my list but Mr. Smith told me try it and I have to say I scarfled it down like  a hoover on high voltage. Boip.
author: Mi M.

description:
I'm underwhelmed by MM. While I'm not a BBQ aficionado, I have sampled a good amount of the stuff in California, the Carolinas and beyond. The first thing I noticed about MM was the relatively large/diverse menu. I'm accustomed to smaller, more focused selections at BBQ joints, and I'm weary of large menus because they indicate a lack of focus. 
I decided to split the spicy pulled chicken sandwich with a side of sweet potatoes.  At over $8 with tax, this is a modestly sized meal. I agree with others that the side dishes are small, considering ala carte purchases are over $3.  I was disappointed that the sandwich was cold, that the chicken wasn't marinated in BBQ sauce and that there was a mayonnaise like spread on the inside. I couldn't detect any heat in my spicy chicken. It tasted alot like a bland chicken salad sandwich. 

One star for 3 BBQ sauces on the table... they're the saving grace of an otherwise mediocre meal. One star for the atmosphere- very comfortable, if small. Head to Everett & Jones!!!
author: Jenni D.

description:
I have v. fond memories of brunch at Memphis Minnie's, but it seems
that's all they will ever be.  Brunch is no longer offered and it is a
sad, sad testament to the times.  If anyone reading this has any kind
of power there, please, I beg of you, bring breakfast back.
author: Patricia A.

description:
Okay checked this place out after watching a review of the place on KQED's Check Please! Bay Area. I must say this place was good!!!

I didn't want anything to deter me away from what I went there for, THE MEAT!! Oh my GOODNESS it was amazing!!! We had the brisket, baby back ribs and beef ribs. 

Brisket was moist and tender. With a great smoke ring around it. 

Baby Back ribs fell of the bone, but still had a slight bite to the outer layer. YUM

Beef Ribs were ok, mainly bone and not much meat. I wouldn't order this again. 

I took out .5 of a star for the amount of tables. Only about 6 tables in the joint, but I guess that's SF for ya. And i took off another .5 of a star of the BBQ sauce. I know that this place wants to keep it as "Southern" as possible, but I'm a cali rib lover, so I like me thick, rich BBQ sauces. If you're like me and enjoy a wide sauce selection you'll have to check out Famous Dave's down in Gilroy. Otherwise Memphis Minnie's is the place to be!!!!
author: Rana A.

description:
I liked the greens, but couldn't eat a lot of them because they were really sour. The beans were excellent. Cole slaw was good. The cornbread was edible. I didn't like any of the sauces. The meat was good, but kind of dry. I tried the brisket and the pork ribs. 

I went because of a review in Details magazine.... but Details lied.
author: J-Meoww W.

description:
I believe the hype...

and the brisket chili cheese fries are the best chili fries I've ever had.....and I've had 'em all over the place, gotdammit...
tasty chunks of beef brisket in the chili mixed w/ cheese on top of the fries....

the bbq chicken was ok, maybe a little on the dry side but there's a few diff sauces you can throw on that sucka to keep the party going...
vinegar, bbq, mustard...they have it covered...
mac n cheese is delish...
the tangy coleslaw is tasty as well...
(apparently we were the first folks to pronounce tangy right all day....the guy at the counter said folks were comin' in saying tan-jee)

still have to try other things on the menu...
the tri tip sammich is at the top of the list...

the 5 stars are pretty much earned by the chili fries alone...

thats it...I'm done...
author: Jared D.

description: I'm glad there is a place in SF that can get me some honest-to-God sweet tea.  The sandwich I had was average.  The house sauces are generally ok but I only got really into one of them.  The true gems here are the sides.  The Mac and Cheese is super.  I wish they came with larger portions for the sides!  Overall average to good food and a fun callback to my old stomping grounds in Nashville.  Glad to eat here and will probably return.
author: Eric W.

description:
this place is way over rated. all these yelpers who praise this place must have not had good bbq before. To start off the food here is not even that good. One thing i would say that is good is the bbq sauce. As for the meat its just average and for sure not amazing. 
The service here i would say sucks hands down. Did i forget to mention that it is crazy overpriced. Man the sandwiches here are tiny. It was my first time trying this place and i was sadly disappointed. The food comes out basically room temperature and its not even hot. I ordered and waited for a my food quite a while and the thing that pissed me off was they forgot my sides. I called back 5 mins after leaving the store and told them and asked them to bring it to me because i did not want to walk back. Then the girl who told me over the phone sorry we dont have anyone who can deliver it to you. Wtf?? im two blocks away and you guys messed up my order the least you can do it fix it by bringing it to me. If you cant deliver take it off your menu because thats just false advertising. The food here is not worth the wait. This is the last time i would ever eat at this place there are plenty of other bbq joints around the city that have much better food and friendlier service. THIS PLACE SUCKS
author: Art N.

description:
BBQ!!!  Most of what I've tried here is excellent!  The chicken has been a little on the dry side both times I tried it, but the ribs, sausages, and brisket were delicious!  Sides are good but they could be a little bigger.  I love the 3 different sauces - vinegar, mustard, and red, and I think now they have a hot sauce too . . .  I came here for my bachelor party and the brisket was so damn good it inspired me to get my own smoker (wife got it for me for xmas!) but I'm not sure I can match the majesty and splendor of that hunk of meat they served us!

why the 4 then?  chicken could be improved (it was still good, just not as good as their other meats) and the sides are kinda small.  If I could I'd give it a 4.5.
author: Ted S.

description:
Let's just get this out of the way, if you know anything about this part of the city, you might as well take the bus. I only say so because parking is scarce. But once you get in, you are automatically hungry (maybe the parking difficulty is intentional). 

I was able to try a bunch of things. Of note, I really enjoyed the Pork Egg Rolls as a starter. This may be worth the visit itself. The breaded grit sticks are good so long as you use that ranch side often. The real treat is the Brisket and the great sauce choices available at your table. Good lord, I almost walked out with the Texas Red Sauce and The Carolina Mustard Sauce (the hot sauce is also good). The sides were ordinary, so pick any. But out of nowhere, they have the BEST sweet tea ever. I'll be back...
author: Brian A.

description:
memphis minnies was the first bbq joint i hit up when i moved out to the city years ago. i remember having the brisket sandwich... i remember it being super delicious and i was a little mad at myself for not ordering more! this time i knew i was going to do it right. it was a good thing that i had my girlfriend with me this time to help me out. 

we got the 2 meat combo (brisket and pork ribs) with 2 sides (mac and cheese and collard greens) and brisket chili cheese fries. The meat was tender and tasty, mac and cheese was solid but i think the collard greens were a little too "tangy" for my taste, and the brisket chili cheese fries were mind blowing. I mean, those fries could feed a small village or in our case... can send two people into a 30 min "i ate too much" nap.

Memphis Minnie's... it's been a long time but i'm glad we got we got to reunite.
author: Brian L.

description:
I loved it. I had the brisket plate. It's so tender it just falls apart. I really liked the vinegar sauce they have at the tables.

My friend ordered the spicy chicken sandwich and repeatedly declared, "This is so good!".

It was a bit expensive and the portions aren't huge like I was expecting. That was fine with me, I'm used to getting more than I can eat at BBQ restaurants.

I'm glad it wasn't crowded when I went, I've heard it gets busy and it didn't look like it would be very comfortable when crowded.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Blech, never again!  Apparently the kind of place Yelpers faun over.  Browse through the reviews and you can see that this place is a roll of the dice.  Unfortunately, when my girlfriend and I went, we crapped out.

$14 for FIVE pork ribs, two TINY sides and a small piece of cornbread/corn muffin... a good deal this place is not!  Thank Satan there wasn't a wait, because I'd have been even more upset we paid this much for crappy bbq.

Pork Ribs
Mine were mushy and tasteless.  My girlfriend's were so badly burned they were black and tough.

Sides
SMALL, as in they put them in tiny dipping cups.  Mac and cheese was overcooked and tasteless.  Potato salad was OK (mashed potatoes with a hint of sweetness).  Greens tasted like vinegar and not much else.  Sweet potatoes were overcooked but sweet and tasty.

Corn bread/muffin
Overcooked and crumbly.

Sauce
The red was thin and not at all savory (watch out, because it can just fly out of the top because it's basically the consistency of water).  The mustard sauce tasted like it didn't belong on bbq.  Didn't try the vinegar out of fear.

If this is the best bbq SF has to offer, I'm going to cry.
author: Max F.

description:
The first unadulterated BBQ I've found out here (originally from Arkansas).  I really don't have any qualifications to my full 5 star endorsement.  

The meat is smokey yet tender and moist and you get your choice of sauce.  The prices are solid, sides really good.  Had the fried grit sticks and mac and cheese.   Everything super tasty, hearty and got tons of love in it.  

Since so many people have already given praises, I just wanted to chime in and give my full on support.
author: Krista G.

description:
Their brisket is like buttah.  Fawls apart on yaw fawk.  Supa yumalicious.

The pork is good too.  Their beans have a funky taste to them that I can't quite put my finger (or tongue) on, but the bf loves them.

Winning MegaMillions is easier than trying to get a parking spot anywhere near here.
author: Jeff P.

description:
After a difficult day of drinking, my friends and I decided to eschew the usual Saturday night debauchery for some fatty food and trashy television.

For the fatty food portion, we hit up Memphis Minnie's and bought the following items (for 3 people):
* 1 pound of brisket
* 1 pound of sweet pork
* 1/2 pound of andouille sausage
* 3 cornbread muffins
* 1 pint of potlikker greens
* 1 pint of mac & cheese
* 1 large order of BBQ seasoned fries

So, we may have gone out of control in the portions department since we could have fed the Duggar family with our order.  But, everything - especially the greens and the mac & cheese - was delicious and just what we needed to get through the night.
author: Marcus C.

description:
To me, Memphis Minnie's is about one thing.  Brisket.  Good brisket.  Smoked brisket.  Slowly.  Carefully.  Charred around the edges.  Tender meat, with a lovely smokey taste that can stand alone or together with various sauces that are served on the side.  The sides are nothing to brag about, but when the meat is this good, who cares?

The place is in the Lower Haight.  Unassuming.  A seemingly shabby place packed with carnivores intent on one thing, protein, fatty protein, meat.  If you're a vegetarian and enter this place, someone may bite you.  

A fun, down home place with good old time eats.  The way food used to be in the ice age, in a cave some where.
author: David D.

description: This place sadly suffers the same fate of most Bay Area bbq places. The meat is dry and relatively flavorless. However, staff is friendly and service is prompt. It'll do the job in a pinch but don't get too excited. Sides are mediocre.
author: Steven H.

description: This place is good for restaurant BBQ. I think people have this fantasy that restaurant BBQ spots are going to be as good as it would be if you do it at the house. I can honestly cook up the best ribs if you've ever had, but that takes a shit load of time. So I go here on a Wednesday night. I get the Minnie sampler. It comes with 3 meats of your choice and 2 sides. I get the brisket, ribs, and sausage. Those 3 have been good every time except the ribs are a little tough at times. I also get the potato salad and mac and cheese. Its all descent for a Wednesday night BBQ spot.
author: Ethan S.

description:
I don't know much about Bar-B-Que but I do know good food -- and I didn't find it at Memphis Minnie's.

Came here with a herd of boys with everyone ordering a wide variety, like the fried chicken, tri-tip, chicken wings, ribs, rib tips and brisket. With all that meat and testosterone, you'd expect some grunting, lip-smacking and a whole lot of empty plates. Instead, I saw a lot of shrugs and a lot of leftovers.  Some of it was OK  -- especially if you slathered it with the mustard sauce -- but most of it wasn't.  Had a taste of the mac and cheese that was greasy and bland, greens had a weird flavor, yams were sweet and good but the only side worth having more than a bite of are the fries. 

Oh -- and if you're going to post a sign up that says, "BE NICE OR LEAVE" -- LIVE BY IT! because you should've booted your cashier a long time ago.
author: Chelle Y.

description:
I've eaten at Memphis Minnies four or five times now and believe that it's in the Bay Area's top five BBQ places (Bo's in Lafayette is another).  They utilize a refigerator sized smoker to barbecue their meats and as a result  the stars of the show are very good, flavorful and tender large meat cuts (i.e. beef brisket, pork shoulder).  The non-large meats cuts (ribs, chicken, links) are pretty good but not quite as distinctive.

Being Memphis style they emphasize the rub rather than the sauce so the meat is served alone and you can add different sauce types (Texas, N Carolina, S Carolina) at your table.  If you are attached to the "wet" KC style then it may not be the place for you.

They also serve pretty goods sides (don't miss the greens) and desserts as well.  They also have a couple of nice beer taps (Stella, Anchor Steam) to help bring it all down.  Very nice and highly recommended.
author: John P.

description:
They call this Memphis BBQ?!?! I never been to Memphis, but if this is what it tastes like, I sure don't wanna go!!! If you're into traditionally smoked bbq, then this is not the place for you.

First of all, I tried the pork sandwich and thought I'd eat well with some sides cause I sure was hungry! I ordered a side of "tangy coleslaw" and bbq beans.

The pork sandwich did not come with ANY bbq sauce on it whatsoever. When I asked for some thick bbq to throw on top my sandwich, they referred me to the watery, cold bbq "sauce" (more like liquid) on my table. The sauce was rather bland and watery. The pork was lacking in flavor. But the bread was decent....

Next I tried the beans. They were hot but unfortunately had ZERO flavor and were watery as well.

The coleslaw was the worst. It tasted pickled and had bell peppers in them ??? I guess they're trying to be "different."

They also had sake to go with it. WTF? 

But the worst part is this shady bbq meal cost me $12.50!

I'm going to Big Nates, thank you.
author: Yvette C.

description:
Wow! So many southern bbq experts in SF ... who knew? Seriously, folks, get over yourselves (food snobs). 

Even the driest meat in the joint smacks of delicious, albeit sometimes subtle, smoky goodness. The sauce choices are excellent and the sides are sides and treated as such. Though I have to say the vinegar soaked greens are worth going back for (yup, some of us get that vinegar is a GOOD thing).

Seriously, I've tried bbq from other Bay Area spots and none have been tastier than Memphis Minnie's. And for what it's worth, we thought the service was helpful as we attempted to navigate the fairly large menu.

Will I go back? As soon as possible and I encourage others to give it a try.
author: Steve J.

description: I would say this place is hit and miss.  I've been here and had bad brisket, yet good ribs.  Had it for catering a few times and it's been pretty good.  Last night though I stumbled on to the fried chicken.  So good.  We each had our entree's and got a plate of fried chicken for the table and it was perfect.  I miss it already.
author: Paul M.

description: Memphis Minnie's has delicious barbecue. Chicken, beef brisket, pulled pork - it's all good. If you are trying to watch what you eat, steer well clear of the sweet smoked pulled pork as it is about 30% fat.  Their sides are pretty solid too--I recommend the greens, delicious! 3 sauces at every table - red sauce, vinegar sauce, mustard sauce. If you want real spicy sauce grab it from the counter before you sit down. They have a small beer selection and a surprisingly large sake selection - try it, sake goes real well with BBQ! Sandwiches at around $8, platters at around $12.
author: Teo W.

description: I consider my self a BBQ connoisseur, so I was eager to try an new place; not so good this place.  Food is mediocre and the sides on the cold side.  It is an order at the counter/seat yourself joint so it forces those waiting for a table to hover!
author: Sturgis Q.

description: To start off I have been eating BBQ and soul food for years. My family is from all over the south so I know good BBQ. My friend and I shared the combo dinner with ribs, steak, sausage, mac and cheese and cole slaw. We we're both shocked and disappointed. First off, what is with the price for the portion that you get at this spot?! I was very sad to see that after paying about $20 for a plate of BBQ to find when  my friend and I sat down to grub we only got a cup of each one of the sides and a small portion of each type of meat we ordered. The food was decent, kind of a generic version of BBQ,  nothing to write home about.  Not sure I will eat here again, other better, tasty places in SF to get my fix.
author: Shanell W.

description:
Finally!  Great barbecue food that doesn't involve taking an airplane or even BART.

I love love love barbecue so much that I learned to cook it when I moved here from England and I had been serially disappointed with each of the BBQ joints I'd tried here in the city. 

You can smell Memphis Minnie's as you walk own Haight with the familar odour of mesquite wood and charcoal mixed with meat fumes and every time I've been there there has been a line and a wait for tables.

If I were to judge this place on the ambience then I might knock a star off as the place is pretty tired looking but when you sink your teeth into that sweet sweet barbecue any reservations over the decor will disappear.

I think I've tried every one of the meats on the menu now and can say that the smoked sausage and the brisket are the stars of the show but there really isn't a bad thing on the menu.  The corn bread however isn't that great, I make better in my own kitchen, but then of course I'd say that.

Barbecue food is so regionally divisive and the best thing about being a fish out of water is that they are able to provide barbecue sauces from all over the south without invoking the ire of the locals.  Personally the mustardy Carolina sauce is my favourite but you have sweet Texas and one other to choose from.

Their Collard Greens almost made me weep with joy as I am a sucker for a good plate of greens and I did chuckle at the customer who, when told that they were out of ribs asked the chef to stick some on for him.   The chef said he'd oblige but he might have to wait a while for them to cook, the customer undeterred said this was fine and asked how long.  The reply?  8 hours.  Brilliant.
author: Tony S.

description: I really liked their pork ribs.  The sides were dissapointing to the other people with me, specifically the cornbread, but I'm more concerned with the meat.  I did like their fries. Also, their have cool stuff on the wall.
author: Marc S.

description: Our friends took us there and they have serious soul foods. I'm so impressed with their barbecue sauce. I tried chicken and few side dishes, the food was great. Definitely not the type of food I have very often, but probably good for twice a year.
author: Yoko S.

description: I can only comment on the banana pudding...which was delicious!  Can't wait to go back for some BBQ....
author: Wendy L.

description: Inexpensive, down home, great BBQ with all the sides to match. My favorite is the pork and the sweet potatoes. You'll feel like you're not even in California and at an authentic roadside bbq joint.
author: Eve K.

description: I have to agree that the pork ribs are excellent, however the side dishes are pretty mediocre.  After grabbing drinks across the street at Noc Noc my friend and got a light dinner- shared the pork ribs that comes with 2 small side dishes and corn bread muffin.  We tried the coleslaw and sweet potatoes,.. nothing special and even though i LOVE corn bread.. it was too dry for me to have more than a few nibbles.  Stick with the pork ribs and don't have high expectations for the side dishes. Fun atmosphere though :)
author: Melody T.

description: Come in and do not sit down yet. Not even to get dibs on a table was what we were told by the big guy at the cash register. Other than that odd intro the food was amazing. I ordered the sweet pork sandwich with a side of sweet potatoes. They've got these huge bottles of bbq sauces- a tangy mustard, Texas red sauce and one called STUPID HOT (very Bay area!) It'll make you truly stupid so drink lots o water. I personally like the red sauce more. Sweet potatoes was good but too sweet. Decent prices, just scout tables like a hawk.
author: Thomas L.

description: I took my boyfriend here for one of our date nights because we love us some good southern BBQ! I thought it was pretty good! What I enjoyed most was the fries and the various sauces that you can try. It is really heavy food so plan on making it a major meal and make sure you have some tums or something with you when you go because the heartburn will kill you. I will go again if am wanting some BBQ and others are up for it but I am not sure if it would be my 1st choice.
author: Thea M.

description:
I was hankering some Southern comfort food, and was recommended this Haight Street eatery as a place to get it.  I went to school in the South and drove to every state south of the Mason-Dixon line (and ate something in every single one), so I am a bit particular about my ribs.  Ribs, like most meats, come in three varieties.  Bad, Very Good, and Freakin' Incredible.  There is really no 'mediocre' ribs.

Memphis Minnie's had the right interior decor for a good rib place, namely a bunch of artifacts from other ribs places, but the lack of a proper open flame over or cooker was the first sign that this was not proper BBQ.  I ordered the smoked pork ribs and waited for my meal to come out.

When it came out, I was a little disappointed from the get go.  The ribs were dry and sauceless, which is fine for slow cooked and spice rubbed Southern (Carolina) style ribs, but the meat fell off the bone like saucy and more quickly cooked Northern (Carolina) style ribs.  The three sauces on offer, a tiny red BBQ sauce of sorts, an uninspiring mustard sauce, and a simple vinegar sauce did their best to add some zing to the affair, but over all I was left unimpressed.

If anything, great ribs should leave you looking like a mess, no matter how careful you are.  Northern style ribs soak you in sauce, Southern style ribs coat you with the spice rub.  These ribs just left a hint of grease on my fingers.

So while the meat was not great, the sides were alright.  The mac and cheese was good enough, as was the potato salad.  The sweet potatoes really didn't do much for me though because there really wasn't much that went into their preparation, served neither candied nor with brown sugar.

Over all, two stars.  One for trying, the other for the decor.  None for the food.
author: Eric M.

description:
I guess don't go there later at night. I was sorely disappointed by my food. I can only hope the reason was that it was late at night and they were close to closing? (but seriously if you're open that late at night, the food should be good all day long no?)

Anyway, I had the rib tips. They were hella dry. I can kind of see where the flavor was coming from but they were just so dry. It was not enjoyable to eat. For a place that specializes in cooking meats, perfection should be moist, juicy ribs. I'm pretty happy as long as the ribs are you know, some what juicy. Totally dry at Memphis Minnie's. The corn bread was also gritty which was strange.

Anyway, that's why I had to pull it down to 2 stars. I thought about giving it 3 stars, but really those ribs do not deserve 3 stars. I'm willing to try it again, maybe earlier in the day.

On the plus side, a friend's fried chicken sandwich was pretty good. And the people are nice. But c'moooon, you gotta kill it on the ribs. No deal for me.
author: Karen J.

description:
I have been wanting to go here for quite some time and finally made it in on Sunday for lunch. I have dined at many a good barbecue spots across the country, including the infamous Arthur Bryant's in KC. I was pleasantly surprised by the pork ribs. They were deliciously smoked and the choices of sauce are delicious. This also happens to be the only restaurant I have ever seen to serve pudding with vanilla wafers (ingenious and delicious).

I like that it has the hole in the wall vibe and though some find the wall decor tacky, I like knowing I am eating somewhere with a bit of history. Extra stars for the picnic style seating and the unlimited roll of paper towels at each table.
author: Alicia J.

description:
My friends and I were underwhelmed with the food after seeing the collage of awards and even the Yelp sticker on the windows. My roommate is from Texas so we were hoping to find some real BBQ finally, but alas the search continues. In all the BBQ meats tasted all right, but it just wasn't as good as the hype was.

The three of us each got the two-way combo for $14.95 or $16.22 after tax (choice of two meats, two sides, and a corn bread muffin.)

They had three sauces: a red bbq, a mustard sauce, and a vinegar base. Roll of paper towels supplied for your convenience - nice!

+ Meat
