I love their ribs, briskit, mac and cheese, corn bread, etc. I wish they had a location in the south bay.
author: Markisha G.

description: Like many other Yelpers I tried to love it but didn't. The brisket was a bit dry, the pulled pork was bland, and the ribs were just average. As for the sides, the mac was gritty, the cornbread was dry, and the baked beans were just ok. Portions are good and the staff was cheery thus the third star. Still searching for good Q in the city.
author: Kris N.

description: I write specifically to praise the barbecue pork egg rolls. They are amazing--and the sauce is unrivaled. I recommend them with a side of mac & cheese.
author: B G.

description: I'm originally from Tennessee, so I've sampled a good amount of bbq in my years. So far, I've been here 3 or 4 times in the past year. To me, it's just ok. I've had the brisket, pork, ribs, chicken, sides, etc, pretty much anything you would order. It doesn't compare to bbq back home. The meats were nothing special and the sides were actually kinda bad (mac n chz, cole slaw). The prices are alright and you get a lot of food. I'm crossing this place off my list and moving on to find another BBQ place.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Ok, so I'm from Texas, grew up in South Carolina and my dad has actually designed and had made his own BBQ pit so I believe it's safe to say I know good BBQ.  But this place is a sorry excuse for BBQ.  I ordered sausage which was way too fatty, the chicken was cooked way too long so it was super dry, the potato salad had huge pieces celery which is all you tasted and Mac and Cheese tasted like it was two days old. Not to mention the corn bread was dry and crumbly. I literally left an entire plate of food; it wasn't worth eating.  Come on people, this is not good BBQ.  And to make things worse, my dinner was around $20 which is ridiculous.  In TX you can get a huge plate for around $8-$10.  I mean, I know that SF knows good food but they need to go back to square one in the BBQ division.
author: Kelly B.

description:
i'm just waiting for someone from east of the mississippi (and south of the mason dixon) to open up a bbq joint in san francisco.

this cute little spot has decent bbq but nothing to write home about.  the bf and i both got the 2 meat combo (pork ribs and chicken) with collard greens, beans, fries, and mac-n-cheese.  the ribs were dry and over cooked, the chicken was juicier but as with the ribs you can tell that they had been sitting around for hours.  i thought the sides were better.  

the greens, are chopped finely and cooked in a tangy mustard sauce and the beans have tiny bits of pork in it.  the bf liked the mac-n-cheese but i thought it was mediocre, the fries were yummy, and the corn muffin was dense and flavorless.  one plus is that they have all-u-can-drink sweet tea and sodas.
author: maggie m.

description: I love some down home cooking.  My idea of a dream world is to eat breakfast at Lois the Pie Queen and then start eating BBQ, and not stop until my life ends.  So searching for tasty BBQ is a lifelong avocation, one with massive ups and crushing lows, kind of like being drunk at a dubstep house party.  Looney's in Oakland was my favorite when I lived in the East Bay.  I've moved to San Francsico and I rarely see anything down home or Southern or anything so I figured my craving for BBQ treats might have to go on hold.  I tried Memphis Minnies, not expecting much.  Wow!  It was the best.  The employees were way pumped, and how could you not be?  It's nice to walk into a place and have tons of meat everywhere, and people be nice to you.  It's like the opposite vibe of being in the pit at a hardcore show.  The guy at the counter had a real homestyle personality.  I ordered a brisket sandwich and mac and cheese.  Both were great.  I tried the sauces and while they weren't the best thing ever (not as good as Looney's), I didn't care, because I'd just spent less money for more food than I had earlier at Zazie and was way more full when I left.  Epic win.
author: Whitney D.

description: Son says it's his new favorite restaurant. The pulled pork,curly fries & coleslaw were what I was craving & the 4 sauces were all delicious.
author: Karen O.

description:
Ever ytime my husband & I go to SF....we have to go to this great BBQ place.  He usually orders the 2 combo (ribs and pulled pork).  He said it was to "die" for! (I'll take his word 0 I don't eat pork). I like to order the spicy chicken sandwich and it too was to yummy!!!  You also get side orders.
The place is not that big and seats are first come first basis.......so you have to get there fast! Place fills up quick!
author: Shasha P.

description: The best Brisket sammy I've ever had....don't forget to smother it with the lip scorching "Stupid HOt" sauce!
author: John B.

description: I used to get bucket loads of Memphis Minnie's when we had family style day at my last job.  I LOVE LOVE the Brisket.  It is fall off the bone tender and I can never stop eating it.  The sauces are pretty saucy as well.  I like the mustard looking one and also the more vinegar influenced sauce.  The place is small, but there are lots of interesting items to check out when you eat in.  This is the only BBQ place I've tried so far in SF and I'd go back if again!
author: Crystal R.

description:
Finally I've found something that's almost like Texas bbq!  If you're hankering for some authentic Texas bbq, Memphis Minnie's is as close as you'll get to the real deal.  The brisket is DEE-LICIOUS as are the pork ribs, but stay away from the pulled pork.  It was below-average and much too dry for my taste.  The collared greens are good as well although it's up to individual tastes as to the other side dishes.

Try out the restaurant's sauces.  The Texas and Carolina sauces go great with any of the meat although the quality of the bbq is good just on its own.

This is a comfortable restaurant to chow down at.  I will definitely be back when I get a craving for meat!  Yee-haw to that!
author: Jenny K.

description:
When I go for BBQ, I am looking for finger licking, sticky faced, happy belly satisfaction.  

We found Memphis Minnie's on the list for Dining Out For Life (Different restaurants donate a portion of the meal/drink $ for AIDS research ).  I thought cool, I could go for some BBQ and good reason to eat out.  
Over all the food was good. The waiting in line and then hoping you get a seat-- not so good.  And, usually I like a little more zip to my BBQ but it wasn't bad.  Their fried grit (yes, I said grits) sticks were very tasty; but seriously, what isn't good fried?  

I was only able to give three stars because:
1) I felt clean after my meal-- they don't even offer "wipes" (they know its a clean meal)
2) We had still had room, so we drove over to Mitchell's and get ice cream.  Only then did I have happy belly...
author: Ana d.

description:
I dig this place but they can be very hit-and-miss. Sometimes you go there and the meat is dry... dry bbq? wtf! 2/3 of the time it is pretty friggin' good though.

All I know is walking into Memphis Minnie's in a Cardinals cap should garner me more love than it does. Perhaps the only thing Memphis about Minnie's is Minnie herself, and I've not seen hair nor hide of her yet...
author: Wil E.

description:
We ordered the rib plate and the pork plate.  The ribs were dry and overcooked, when I got home I found that they gave us 3 ribs that looked like they had been hanging around the bottom of the oven for a few days.  

The "sweet slow cooked pork" was not sweet nor did they cook it long  or slow enough.  Normally to properly slow cook pork it is cooked in a low oven 12-24 hours (the really good stuff is cooked 24 hours).  This cooks off the fat (which pork shoulder is full of) and flavors the meat.  The pork shoulder they serve here is cooked maybe 3 hours.  It is full of fat, is tough, and has no flavor, (no wait, it tastes like undercooked pork shoulder which tastes like crap unless you drown it in their sauce in which case it will taste like -- surprise -- their sauce).  Also these plates cost wayyy too much!  $13.95 for a meager plate of dry ribs, $11.95 for a pork plate.  The coleslaw was too sweet, vinegar based; the potato salad was ok and the corn bread was ok.

I avoided this place for years because it looked like what it is: an overpriced, yuppified, fast-food version of BBQ.  I guess if I "didn't know what BBQ is supposed to taste like" I would think it was just fine.  But come on people!  Get out and be a little adventurous.  BBQ may be a hard find on the west coast but it is out here... but if you are looking for a nice, sanitized restaurant with a Mickey Mouse mascot I guess this is your place!
author: Fredricko B.

description: Seriously, just good eats!  My favorite is the Frito Pie, omg, all your weeks calories in one DELICIOUS BOWL!  It's on lower Haight, so expect the ambiance, last time we got the food and headed over  to Mad Dog in The Fog for some Northern Soul (the music, not the food...). My only suggestion, make sure you're near a place with good, clean, not crowded toilets...
author: Christina M.

description: Best. Fried. Chicken. EVER. Everything I put in my mouth melted!!!!
author: jessi a.

description:
not mad memphis. not bad. 

came here for a protein heavy easter sunday feast, dressed in my church bests. after shielding myself with the table paper towels from head to foot, i was ready to begin. the food came out quick. like too quick. i ordered and before i literally had the chance to walk the 10 feet to sit down, my food was ready. clearly pre-made. i'm okay with that, as long as its served hot. it was kind of warm, but not hot. sad times.

got the st louis ribs, beef brisket, and pulled pork. i thought the beef brisket was definitely the best. the ribs were decent, but were kind of weird. they werent dry rub, and they werent wet either. something in between that were decent in its own right. the pulled pork was a little dry in my opinion.

it's funny that memphis minnies doesnt have memphis style ribs. you'd think they would, no?

sweet tea was great, cole-slaw was made with some sort of pickled mild jalapenos and without mayo (for better or worse), macaroni and cheese was okay.

25 for 2 people make this pretty reasonable. the food was tasty enough, but i don't think a bbq critic would have been impressed. worth a visit, but i won't be running back.
author: James W.

description: Food is excellent, staff is knowledgeable and friendly and the prices are good. What's not to love about Minnie's?
author: Maggie M.

description: Great bbq. Learned its about the cooking process, not the sauce. Its right near toronado and will def make a second visit next time I am in the haight.
author: Christopher V.

description: The only thing that I didn't mind eating was the cornbread biscuit. It's somewhat gritty but the pure corn taste is pleasurable. The rest of the meal was rubbish. The beef tasted like cardboard. People always refer to cardboard when something tastes bad, but this is really like cardboard: dry, dull, and tasteless. The collard greens and beans is just as unforgivable. Avoid.
author: Michael H.

description: As someone who recently gave up meat, I feel that I must pay homage and say proper goodbyes to one of the things that used to make me happy in my heart: bbq chicken, especially from MMs. I used to wake up dreaming of this place, especially after a long night of drinking, and no matter where I lived in the city, would make a trip for a fix. Fortunately, I can (and do, and will often) still put bbq sauce on non-animal food items. Five stars in my heart, but only four because there is now nothing for me to order there!
author: Erin A.

description:
I do not understand the mixed reviews on this incredible place. It is as good as it gets. My son and I came over from O town on a Sunday afternoon, craving some good Q. We even sat in traffic in the heat for half an hour. It was all worth the trip. We quickly found a parking space on the corner and scooted inside. Our order was immediately taken and we grabbed our seats. We had barely sat down when  whoosh! Our names were called and I was greeted by 2 chock-full  combo plates of brisket, ribs, sausage, corn muffin and 2 sets of sides. Yummy! This is what I was born for! The meat was moist, succulent, and smoke flavored. The way meat is meant to be. 
Unlike some bogus barbecue joynts, the meat it is not hidden under some too sweet sauce. This is the real deal. Each side was something to shout about. I loved the cole slaw, sweet potatoes. As a treat I picked up some deep fried grit sticks, which came with their own special dipping sauce. That could have been a meal itself. They were crisp on the outside and tender on the inside. Wow!  I was amazed a how great the service was, something a place this size doesn't always emphasize,  Some other rib place make you wait a half hour just to order, add another half to wait for food, then a further wait for your check. Not so at Minnies.  Just thinking about this place makes me want to return right now. Drool, drool! Make sure to save room for desert !!
author: Vera P.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet. This kind of BBQ just isnt my cup of tea. It was too dry for my liking and the sides were just "OK." I actually liked the decor of Memphis Minnie's more than their food.
author: Amanda H.

description:
Lived in Lower Haight for too many months before hitting up MM.  I'm no expert in BBQ like every other reviewer.  I do definetly enjoy dank pulled pork and fat ribs on occassion.  First time I got the Tri-Tip sandwick, and I'm satisfied everytime afterwards.  I think the fries are simply awesome, even though I'm not sure they could shake more salt and seasoning on them.
Brisket and Pulled Pork are B+
Mac and Cheese is pretty tasty, even though serving sizes are pretty laughable, in general.  

Chose wisely in this establishment.  Some stuff is overpriced and not that thrilling(Rib Dinner).  Others are big meals for under $10.  I think I'll stick with sandwhiches at this joint.

Sauces are pretty solid in my book.  Hogs Breath is a fiery BBQ sauce, and when combined w/ Red Suace and Mustard its pretty much a taste convention, southern style.
author: Kevin Q.

description:
Let me start by saying I'm from the Southern Midwest and I **know** bar-b-q. 

Minnies is very close to getting it right. The ribs are disturbingly good by themselves and I tend to like them with only a little bit of sauce. The mac-n-cheese is great, the greens are too salty, the cornbread is never warm (blasphemy), the sweet tea is great but a bit too sweet, the desserts are really wonderful. 

All in all it's a great experince and the food is mostly good. I do hope they start warming their cornbread up though.
author: Manuel H.

description:
This spot was reviewed on check please bay area and everyone on the show loved this places. I have eaten here 3 times and i tend to disagree

The amazing
The banana pudding..........banana pudding isn't something i would generally order but this stuff is sweet sweet legal crack

The good
fun decor, pigs everywhere a total affront to vegetarians.....a true meat temple 

the so so
the sandwiches and mac n cheese 

I will probably return, cuz i dream of the banana pudding
author: Jimmy M.

description:
ok, so yesterday, i needed to leave work a bit early so i went to the office to fill out paperwork. My co-workers had lunch in the office w/all the bosses. They offered me some of the bbq they had picked up from Memphis Minnies. At first, i was kinda shy, but i gave in. They all looked kinda full so i helped eat some of the ribs. 

So i went to grab some ribs put them in a cup since there was no plates. I grabbed the sauce that was labeled "HOT". I didn't think nothing of it. So i proceeded to eat the ribs with the hot sauce over it. Damn the "HOT" sauce was no joke.  After i had finished the ribs, i was sweating from the hot sauce. My mouth was on FIRE!!! It was funny everybody in the office was laughing at me....BOO HOO !!!

*Tip* My boss suggested (after embarrasing myself) that if your mouth is on fire like it was in my situation, take something sweet and put it in your mouth. In my case, since sugar was available next to the coffee maker, i put enough in a cup and slowly licked the sugar out of the cup and let it melt in my mouth. It sure did the trick !!

Memphis Minnie's overall has some damn good ribs despite the hot sauce they use. 5 stars next time i go there.
author: Garry K.

description:
I can't speak for all the people who claim their meat was "dry." My experience with Memphis Minnie's was full of meat that was crispy and moist in the right spots. The brisket was devine and the pork ribs fell off the bone. The sides are basic and done right. One complaint: the cornbread was a little dry. 

I've lived all over the South and this competes with any backwoods shack in which I've ever dined. 

So what, they have sake. No one is forcing you to drink it. 

Shut up and eat your BBQ.  

This place is 100 percent legit.
author: Wes P.

description:
SOOOOOO GOOD! 
this is probably one of my favorite places to eat. whenever your craving a mouth full of meat there is no better place than this. And the sauces are amazing, My brother claims it is his dream to bathe in in these sauces... nasty  thought but proves how good they are.
The people who work here  are way to nice. you walk in and feel like you left the city and landed in the south. 
The Banana pudding can cure the craving of the sweetest sweet tooth, and if it doesn't, well just order a glass of sweet tea. 
But trust me there is always a line here for a reason. try it.
I would eat here every day if I had the metabolism of a humming bird.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I'm glad this joint is in my neighborhood.  Bonus that they now deliver for those days I just refuse to exit my jammies.  Brisket & pulled pork are tops.   Have I had better bbq?  Yup, but I'd probably have to hop over to Oakland to find it.

My tummy tends to gurgle & churn a bit after eating there... every time... but it's kinda worth it.
author: Kelly W.

description: Been here a few times. Disclaimer: I grew up in Kansas City and am a bit of a BBQ snob. This place actually smokes the meat-not crazy about any of their sauces, but I wouldn't want to spoil the meat anyway. I've the the tri tip, pork and beef and all were very good. Cool place to grab a sandwich or a huge meal and hang out with some friends. Community seating usually provides some interesting conversation. Love the deserts but the sides were not overly impressive. Parking is a bitch, but the 22 is close by.
author: Robert M.

description: Like the fabled elephant graveyard , where all elephants go to die . I have found where all pigs have gone to die. A hog heaven as we say. After watching one too many episodes of Diners , Drive-ins and dives , I had a mad craving for BBQ. Luckily I had a cohort who felt the same. We skipped down the haight , following our noses to the smell of sweet BBQ. I really like the sweet potatoes and the assortment of BBQ sauces on our table. The pulled pork sandwich was awwwright. I loved the cheesy ambiance with the crazy assortment of pigs everywhere you turn.
author: Sophia C.

description: I'm British, so what do I know about BBQ? Not much i don'e suppose. But I do know a thing or two about foor, despite being British. This place is OK. Some of the dishes are hit or miss, but if you're hungry and you want BBQ this lace has it. Strangely the owner is a Sake fan, so there's Sake abound, but there's beer too if you prefer.
author: Stephen C.

description:
The restaurant itself was just plain old "OK." I wouldn't quite rate it 3 stars.... but perhaps in the range of 2.50 to 2.75. It's just your regular bbq shack with different "stupid" hot sauces on the table. It's a little on the pricey side for that kind of food. The cashier was pretty friendly and nice and I also liked the fact that they served sweet tea there (even though I can just brew some up myself at home). The sweet tea has this nostalgic taste that brings me back home to Mississippi so I like to drink it every once in a while. Also, there's lots of cool piggie decor to look at while you're smacking away and licking your fingers.  So feel free to add your personal touch of piggie artwork to the restaurant's collection. Oh and I thought it was weird that this "soul food" joint served Sake too.

Now, on to the food -- I got the fried catfish, tartar sauce, corn muffin and bbq seasoned fries. It also comes with coleslaw, which didn't quite appeal to me so I didn't end up touching it. I thought the corn muffin was a little on the dry side with a butter after taste that I'm not used to. I prefer my cornbread to have the right slight crunch on the outside, moist inside and a little sweet and I add the butter myself. The bbq seasoned fries were tasty, but I kept burping up that taste so that wasn't too good. Haha. The catfish was just okay.. I wouldn't get it again like I normally would at other Southern restaurants. The breading tasted like there were some sort of sand crystals in there. I don't know how else to describe it. Like there's speckles of something super hard in the batter and I can hear noises from my teeth grinding into it. Does anybody know what the heck I am talking about?! 

My other two buddies got some pork ribs, beef brisket & mac cheese. I think if I ever came back to this spot, I would give them ribs a try. They looked pretty moist and you can add those tangy/spicy sauces on it.

That's all folks!
author: Stephanie M.

description: Ribs are good but the sides are gross. Did not like the mac n cheese, sweet potato or corn bread. The bbq sauce they provide is really weird too. It's really watery and taste like beans.  I don't know why this place is so crowded. It's just ok. I'd much rather go to Armadillo Willy's for my ribs.
author: Terry D.

description: I think its the best BBQ in San Fran, that doesnt mean its great because theres only about 4 other resturaunts.  But they have there strengths.  The brisket is wonderful, so are the pork sandwhiches and the rib tips.  Nice little sauces too.  Unfortunately I have had real BBQ in the south and most of the stuff on this menu doesnt cut it.  But i will return because your the best in SF and i LOve the brisket
author: Jonathan S.

description:
I love the pulled chicken sandwiches.

The only downside is the service.  They made a sarcastic remark to me after I asked a simple question about a substitution.
author: Ben S.

description: Ordered a Texas Brisket sandwich.  The bun was small with a very small portion of meat with no extras like onions, pickels or peppers.  For $10 you should get more than a thin layer of meat.  A friend of mine with us indicated his previous experience was a healthier portion of meat.  Was my 1st visit and I was unimpressed and I am from Texas too.
author: Jim H.

description:
Going to Memphis Minnie's reminds me of how much I miss Cliff's BBQ on Bayshore.  

Despite all the accolades and press, Memphis Minnie's isn't very good, especially lately after receiving tons of publicity (Check Please on TV and Food and Wine magazine).  Their sides are actually odd rather than good.  Greens are far too vinegary and the mac and cheese is just plain weird.  The BBQ food itself is middling at best and recent visits were suprisingly too dry if you do not use the sauce, which is a killer for those of us who like dry rub ribs.  Either they're having heat/moisture issues with their smokers or the food is not very fresh.  Either way, anyone with time and grill can do better at home.

I've been going here quite awhile and it just seems like the focus has drifted over the last several years.  I first went there in 01 or 02 and it was fantastic.  I hope they can find their stride again as SF is devoid of any decent BBQ joints.
author: Nathan R.

description: Pulled pork sandwich was freaking great. Great service, really friendly staff, easy going vibe. I'll be back and trying everything on the menu!
author: Josh G.

description: I don't think I can add anything to the mediocrity of the food that hasn't been summed up by a multitude of reviewers before myself. What I can say is that Sake does not go with BBQ. I should know. I tried 9 different kinds just to be sure. Oh, and the restroom door is very difficult to operate after trying very hard to understand the aforementioned combo, and you should not have pigs staring at you when you are trying to pee. Stupid pigs, they're everywhere.
author: Drue C.

description: I haight Memphis Minnie's BBQ! And by haight I mean make love not war.
author: Kevo M.

description: I ain't from Memphis, but I been dere for work.  Tried Corky's and the Rendez-Vous.  And I have just one question.  Where's the dry rub, Minnie?  'Cause if you ain't got dry rub, you ain't got shit.
author: d s.

description: ...really the corn bread isnt bad, all the flavors were pretty solid thru the meat combo deal I had....Good friggin eats, ok prices....get to chimpin on this one, go get a belly full of baby pigs.
author: Gomerio G.

description: Yes i would eat here again, but no.... I wouldn't dare eat the 'greens' which I thought wouldn't taste like pickles or some kind of old nasty socks. I can't say the sandwich was huge, because well.. it wasn't. I remember the sauce..and holly shit was it good,..but if i want the sauce i could get it for free...or maybe even buy it at a store. Either way, i would suggest visiting this place...make up your own mind.
author: David C.

description:
Once upon a time, I lived in Texas and consider myself a Texas (beef) barbeque fanatic.  Well, I can't believe this place has evaded me all these years.  Its some fine ass rib-nibblin' authentic barbeque, right down to the tattooed, snaggle-toothed employees behind the counter.  Better than Brother in Law's, and you don't even need to strap on your glock or wear a bullet-proof.  What's also different about this place is that its really a fusion of Southern and Texas barbeques - two totally distinct styles.  For example, where else could I have ordered a "two-way combo platter" with smoked beef brisket and cowboy beans perched next to pulled pork and collard greens?!  I pushed the sides aside and headed straight for the smoked meats which eventually melded all together becoming a plate of tender, succulent diced critter swirling in tangy red sauce.  YEEEEEHAW!  (credit cards accepted with ID.)

Update: I just tried the beef ribs.  These are the ONLY real Texas beef ribs I have EVER had outside the State of Texas.  Bravo!!! And the banana pudding is awesome too.

Update: I hope I'm just in a bad dream.  Last night I went to dinner here and got my usual ribs and brisket.  This is the second time in a row that the ribs seemed of a slightly lower quality meat than when I first came here a few months ago.  I hope they haven't switched distributors and I just got the rare bad rib.

update: hmmmmm. not sure what's going on here. I suspect that they have changed to a different distributor for their ribs.  The quality seems to have dropped off a bit. The ribs are coming out tough.  However, the beef brisket is still top notch, so I will continue to go there.  Also, try the sweet potatoes in an apple sauce broth.
author: Rick H.

description: This place was "eh" as far as BBQ went.  I got a brisket sando and they served it on ciabatta bread which is not exactly my favorite bread.  None of the seasonings really reach out and grabbed me.  The sides were also just okay.  Still searching for some good BBQ in the city.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I only went once, wasn't impressed.  the ribs were dry, brisket is norm.  sauces were bleh,  I would give it another try, but its not a must, cuz i love bbq. maybe i just went on a bad day.  but service was fast and friendly.
author: Quailty P.

description: I really hate to take stars off on a business because I know it's hard to make a living running a restaurant, but I just can't really give them a great review.  I grew up in North Carolina and can tell you that ribs are not supposed to be this dry.  Nor is cornbread.  I could barely choke them down with a drink.  I found the mac & cheese unpalatable, and the fries and beans were unmemorable.  I tried to like this place because everyone is so ga-ga over it and it's in my hood, but after countless tries, it just makes me miss North Carolina.  And I never thought that would be possible.  I always order it to-go, so maybe I will try eating it in-house next.  For some reason, I want to like it ...
author: Jenny C.

description: Let me say first that I generally despise BBQ with its otherwise bland meats covered with sickly sweet sauce.  Luckily, a foodie friend educated me in the ways of BBQ and sent me over to Memphis Minnie's.  Their flavorful dry rub means that I can go without the sauces and still be satisfied.  Granted I'm no expert on Memphis style BBQ (I've been to Memphis only once), but what I can say is that Memphis Minnie's serves up some excellent comfort food.
author: Michelle P.

description: At this point I've had almost every meat o the menu and I've never been disappointed. The meat has great smoky flavor and is juicy and tender. The sauce is also top notch. My only issue with the place is that I keep wanting to eat more of it! Something that neither my jeans or my girlfriend will allow. Be sure to try the beef ribs and the sauces on your table.
author: Allistair J.

description: Ya it's good and even clean.  100 point inspection card...though I've never seen anyone cleaning.  Amazing.
author: Wakako U.

description: Too expensive, and greens are NOT supposed to be sweet people! They are a vegetable?? I don't know about u but I don't like sugar sweet sauces on my sauteed green veggies. I like them to taste smokey and savory like they should to contrast with the corn muffin. Southerners know what I mean. This place made me feel bad for Peninsula peeps if you think this was good bbq.....you have been deprived. The ONLY saving grace to their pork ribs was that they were tender....but really 18 bucks for 4 small pork ribs? Naaahhhhh Um good. Thanks but no thanks.
author: Carla L.

description: This is my favorite bbq place in the city, party because they offer you a choice of what sauce to use at the table. Their pork is so tender I could cuddle up with it.
author: Nish N.

description: Time to get carniverous! This place is so awesome and I can honestly say it is the best BBQ in the Bay Area. (Hey, my daddy used to drive all the way to Flint's in Oakland from Livermore for ribs TO GO--Kristen was raised on good BBQ). They really do slow cook their stuff because we've walked by it at 2 am and could smell the stuff they were making for the next day. (And it smells even better when you're tanked--the teases!) Their sides are also about as awesome as the meat products. I don't know about the sake with BBQ though. I got a flight and it just didn't jive with me. Now I cannot wait until my cross country road trip through the south so that I can sit in a car and get fat on Southern BBQ--I'm a workout-a-holic; imagine how hard it is for me to want something like that. Sorry vegetarians; you're getting left at home on Minnie's night.
author: Zulu Q.

description:
i don't know what took me so long, but i'd never tried memphis minnie's until last night, and now i'm planning to work my way... slowly.... through the menu. 

i had the rib tips, which were tasty enough, with a bit of gristle. the three sauces on the table were good. well, at least the red texas sauce was great, and the most expected for bbq. i loved the vinegar north carolina sauce, too... and mixing those together was just about perfect. i didn't try the mustard sauce, i'm going to save that for my next visit, when i'll try the sausage.

for sides, i had the potato salad, which was just like my mom's southern potato salad, and the potlikker greens, which were awesome!! slightly sweet and vinegary. yum. i told my tennesse dad about them and he was jealous. the cornbread was fine. 

and for dessert, banana pudding. like my grandma used to make, only they use little nilla wafers instead of the big ones. yum yum and yum again. 

it's not cheap, but it's good, no-nonsense, neighborhood food. i'll be back for sure, for sure.
author: leslie a.

description: Maybe it was a off night...BBQ was ok, not much moisture, a bit dry.  Maybe this is Memphis style, I don't know.  But, the pecan pie was great!
author: Koa K.

description:
My stars are for service, corn bread, and the sweet tea. There were several people that spoke to us and asked how everything was. The guy at the register called me by my first name when I gave him my debit card and when we left!

I'm a southern girl and love BBQ. Personally, I like the "wet rubbed" style. They offer "dry rubbed" at Memphis Minnie's. But it was still pretty good. There were 4 different sauces on the table to choose from. They give you a cornbread muffin with your meal. It is the sweet kind, just the way I like it.

My favorite part was the sweet tea! It was prepared perfectly and they offered me one to-go. Yay!
author: Mel C.

description: As a New York native, I don't know nuthin' 'bout Southern barbecue, but I know what tastes good, and this tastes terrific. I usually start with an order of fried cheese grit sticks, then dig into a platter of one of my two favorites, beef brisket or sweet smoked pork (with the big beef ribs running a close second), with tart and tangy cole slaw and a creamy macaroni and cheese on the side. The corn bread fluctuates between moist and crumbly dry, maybe depending upon how soon I get it after it leaves the oven. Only once was I disappointed with a meal, when I deviated from the norm and ordered fried catfish, which was dry, with curly fries that were underspiced and overcooked. Definitely take-out food, because my mother taught me never to lick my fingers in public, and at home I can lick not only them but the plate as well.
author: Gourmet G.

description: for everything else this place serves, I'd say 3 or 2 1/2 stars is more then enough, but holy moley, that Saturday special: SOUTHERN SMOKED FRIED CHICKEN, it deserves to be in all caps, it is literally the BEST DANG FRIED CHICKEN I have ever had in my life, I seriously consider moving to SF, because that chicken blew colonel right out of the water, and Popeye's can suck it, it is the BEST FRIED CHICKEN I will ever put in my mouth, I guarantee it.
author: Allen L.

description: The cook told me "I could break your shins," because he didn't like the sports team on the T-shirt I was wearing.
author: Jeremy L.

description: PMS + meat + greens + mustard sauce. You all get to live another day.
author: Megan W.

description: It's ok of you don't know real BBQ...
author: Bryan E.

description: My mouth waters just thinking about thier pulled spicy chicken sandwich!  The guys who work here are really nice & friendly.  Again, another one of those unpretentious places in san francisco with GREAT food.  The service is always great, the food is always awesome.  Every once in a while there's a line and the tables are all taken - which is a bummer - but I'd rather have them too busy and not get a place to sit than have them go out of business.  They think of all the conveniences, too.  A roll of paper towels at every table, along with three types of sauces - the vinegar-ie one I avoid, but the other two are fantastic!  The pulled pork plate and the pulled spicy chicken sandwich are the best - as for sides, you gotta go with the fries and/or the sweet potatoes.  YUM!  Seriously a great spot to get a hearty, mouth-watering meal!
author: denise L.

description: I was introduced to MM by my ex-bf who swore by the food. We only went a couple times and the food was just okay. The only thing I loved about this place was the mac and cheese and the banana pudding. Don't go there if you want stellar BBQ. I might go back if I have a craving of some sort, but that just depends.
author: Ruchita P.

description: The brisket at this place is to die for. All of the meat I have had here is fantastic (I've never tried the chicken). The fries are great. I am not crazy about the rest of the sides and I am not crazy about the sauces. But the meat is smoked with real wood, it is smoked for the right amount of time and the smoke flavor is present in every bite. It's definitely the best bbq in the bay area, followed by Big Nate's.
author: David S.

description: Not a terribly huge fan, and i LOVES BBQ. Though i do think they have a good thing going being one of the only BBQ joints i can think of, i also think they fall a little short. Im not down with the Carolina/Tennessee BBQ style, which is runny, liquidy, vinigary sauce. I like it like Scandanavian Dancing Girls, thicker than thin and full of fury.  Sides are aplenty. but a little disappointing. The greens and beans needed enrollment in Herbs and Spices 101. The cornbread is one of their shining stars, as is their sweet potato pie. The actual meat seemed ok, but swamped in all that sauce, it was still dry. This is not a replacement for backyard BBQ, but it seems palatable if youre on your way home from Toronado and you need to get your Q on.
author: Mick F.

description:
With it being the 4th of July and all I was really in the mood for some smokey barbecue. I cruised over to Minnie's and waited about 20 minutes in the line that was out the door. Since the place was so crowded I opted to just take my food to go and enjoy it at home.

Since the kitchen is up front I spent my entire time in line drooling over the food that was being made. HUGE racks of ribs were getting smoked up and chopped  and by the time I got to the register I was dying. I ordered the Southern Star which is a beef brisket AND pulled pork sandwich with a side of mac and cheese and an order of their BBQ seasoned fries. The food only took about 10 minutes to be prepared and was reasonably priced. At first bite I was slightly disappointed by the bread used - more of a baguette texture than anything but too chewy, not crisp enough. The meat however was unbelievably tender and flavorful and the two homemade sauces on the side - texas red bbq and mustard sauce were delish. Mac and cheese was also very good, kind of creamy. The fries are hand cut and are very good but they were unbelievably over seasoned to the point where I couldn't even eat them after a few bites.

Overall Minnie's is a cool spot to grab some tasty bbq. I'm not sure I'd recommend running over here if you're visiting SF but it's definitely a great local spot.

Update: Just wanted to let you guys know I got a harassing message from a newly created Yelp account about this review. He berated me for complaining about over seasoned fries and crispy bread and to be completely honest seems like it's someone that works or runs Minnie's. Not cool at all, I've never had a negative experience with a fellow Yelper. Very lame.
author: Ben K.

description:
the bf loved the food there.. he had ummm.. pulled pork, ribs, and something else, or maybe not..

meat fell off the bone...  he liked the baked beans..   i ate some of his mac' and cheese.. that shit was gooooooood!  i ordered the grits and cheese thing.. to the extent of a mozzarella sticks.. those were good too.

they have a million sauces.. not all good.. taste em' then find your niche.

dude... good luck on parking.. took us 45 min. on a sat. night.  boo!
author: Sheri N.

description: If I were to describe this place in one word it would be 'Yum'. Leave your diet at the door as you gorge yourself with yummy BBQ and indulgent side dishes. Mac N Cheese...need I say more?! The atmosphere is modest and by modest I mean something tacky that you might find on Beale Street in Memphis...without the Elvis stuff.
author: lindsey l.

description: wow I am having a hard time finding a bad place to review. I give Memphis Minnie four stars- All four for the bbq- I love bbq from memphis actually more than my own birthplace recipe. And Memphis Minnies nails the technique and the sauce. I just wish they had hush puppies and would dust.
author: Lindsey S.

description: I have been going to Memphis Minnies for years and the cole slaw has vastly improved!  Love it now, but it will not make up for a somewhat recent change in containers used for sauce when ordering take-out.  The plastic sauce containers are about half the content of what was once provided.  I no longer live in the Haight (or San Francisco for that matter) so that meant there was no chance of driving back a few days ago.  This reflects cheap business practices (in my opinion) as I had to carefully delegate and dabble sauce on my meal and go without the desired amount since the current little tiny sauce cups just don't make it.  Now I must be preoccupied with asking for two sauces when I go in.....come on now!  Once four stars now three........
author: Charlene M.

description: I've been waiting to find good bbq since I moved here.  I'm picky about my pork so it's hard to impress me this far out west as it seems people prefer beef ribs and brisket over pork shoulder and pork ribs.  This place has a good selection of meats, specials, and good selection of sides. The pork was good and the sauce selection also was ok. I got pork and sausage, the BF got brisket.. we enjoyed our meal and the staff was very friendly.  The atmosphere was good although I wouldn't want to be there if they were super busy as seating is limited. I'm looking forward to visiting again.
author: Rodney P.

description: This place was alright for me.  Coming from KC, I'm a BBQ snob.  The quality of the meat was good, but the sides and sauces left something to be desired.  And I totally don't understand why the wait.  But if I'm craving BBQ, I'll definitely come back for the meat.
author: Christena T.

description: This is the best  BBQ place in San Francisco...But that's not really saying too much...It would probably not even hit the top 50 in The Deep South...But...The beef brisket is the best thing there with the smoked pork and smoked turkey breast close behind...The other meats,which include pork ribs,beef ribs,smoked chicken and andouille sausage are nothing that special,but a lot better than Big Nate's...The side dishes are really good with a preference for the potlikker greens and the chili cheese fries...and for desert...there's some decent choices...but....Try The Banana Pudding! After you eat it,you will feel like Al Bundy after any meal...Leaning back in your chair,the top button of your jeans undone,and patting your stomach lightly with a dazed smile on your face...Go there and enjoy yourself
author: David W.

description:
I think this is the best bbq in the city....now, if you're talking the bay area, Minnie's will have some serious competition with Everett/Jones...but if you're just talking SF, this is the place to go for authentic bbq.
The food here has been consistent and bonus points for the "special" hot bbq sauces and for having Shiner Bock. It isn't the best beer in the world but it goes very well with southern style bbq.
The meats are all tasty(tried them all except for the sausage and chicken)..same for the sides. I haven't tried any of their desserts although I hear they're good as well. I hear the burgers are worth trying too.
One thing I believe everyone overlooks @ Memphis Minnie's is the Smokey Mountain Wings. Son-of-a-gun are they good! They're infused with smokey flavor and are some of the tenderest wings I've ever eaten. Almost fall of the bone...not sure how they accomplish this...I know they spend quite some time in the smoker. Just pure sticky smokey goodness. If you're craving buffalo style wings, these might not cut it for you but as far as flavor goes, these are rockin'.
Last time I was in Minnie's all we ordered was 3 batches of Smokey Mountain Wings and some beers....and left extremely happy.
Haight Street and BBQ! What a combo!
author: Terry M.

description: As much as I eat out, I'm surprised I haven't fallen to food poisoning more often.  Unfortunately, Memphis Minnie's broke that streak, and left me in bed for a number of days, wondering if this was the end.  I don't know if it was the smoked meat or the greens, but hours after eating at Minnie's I was cramped up, bent over, hands clenched and drenched with sweat praying for a quick death.  I'll spare you Yelpers the gory details, but the pain and suffering I experienced still goes unmatched in my 32 years of existence.  Even when I walk by Memphis Minnie's these days and catch a whiff of their BBQ, I find myself having to keep from up-chucking in the gutter.  While I know plenty of other people that swear by this place, I've been burned too badly and refuse to put my hand back on the stove.
author: DamnGringo X.

description: I don't know anything about barbecue, except I really like barbecued potato chips. I also really like the food here.
author: Maria D.

description:
as a vegetarian there isn't much for me to comment on as far as the meat at memphis minnies goes.  i wouldn't have ever thought about going here in the first place if it hadn't been for my friend sean luring me there with the tale of good, real, sweet tea.  so, i went.  i had some sides.  they were good but nothing too memorable.  i was excited about the fried cheese grits sticks but they weren't that great.  also, no hush puppies.  how can you serve bbq with no hushpuppies?  but maybe they only do bbq that way in eastern north carolina (i'm from wilmington).

also, just as a side note. memphis minnies does not serve true eastern nc style bbq. for all those who don't know eastern nc bbq does not use a red bbq sauce. instead just a spicy vinegar is used to dress the slow cooked pork.  western nc style pork bbq does use a red vinegar based sauce.

i almost forgot! the sweet tea was actually really good and on point which shocked me.  if i was ever in the lower haight on a hot sf day i just might consider going in and getting a sweet tea to go.
author: Kristie P.

description: Jesus, San Franciscans really don't know what BBQ is. I lived 15 years in Kansas City  and 6 years in Texas so maybe I have lofty expectations. The ribs were dry liked they were cooked in the oven. My friends brisket looked like it was marinated in ketchup. The place was dirty and the service lousy. This place should be embarressed to call itself a BBQ joint. San Fran - stick to what you know: California cuisine and dungeness crab.
author: Call Me Z.

description: My boyfriend and I have been craving BBQ all week and were sorely disappointed with this place.  They were out of chicken and tri-tip??  Maybe it's more of a rib joint so I may be willing to try it for that but it was kinda gross.  The greens were overly sweet and tart, not my type.  SO BUMMED.  The girl taking our order was really nice....that's about it.  I had the spicy pulled chicken (since that was the only kind of chicken they had) and it wasn't even "pulled" chicken and had some strange creamy sauce--not what I was expecting at all but not terrible.  Mac n Cheese was not good either.  My bf had the sausage and was disappointed in the watery BBQ sauces.  Not sure how this place has earned a name but probably wont return.  We paid way too much to be this disappointed.
author: jessica f.

description:
this place wasn't bad, but it didn't leave much of an impression either. the pulled spicy chicken sandwich was pretty good, but a little too spicy for my taste. my friends had the taster, and they said the meat was just "ok." 

i probably wouldn't come back here again and if i had a craving for some southern food, i'll go to hard knox cuz that place is DAMN GOOD!
author: Emy s.

description: One of my favorite places for bbq.  Must eat the mac n cheese
author: Ann C.

description: I hate BBQ, but I really like this place. Maybe I am a convert, because I love their chicken and tri-tip along with fries and mac and cheese. They have this great tangy South Carolina sauce too that goes perfectly. End with their own Pecan Pie. Yum.
author: Stacy R.

description:
lunch for two:  $34

this is more of a carolina style bbq....hence, everything here is based with vinegar...the beans tasted like vinegar, the greens tasted like vinegar...every sauce was vinegar-based...everything just fell short of our tastebuds-o-meter

the greatest disappointment were the ribs...they don't use the high-quality baby backs...they use short/spare ribs...i've NEVER seen this done at a bbq joint before...i don't usually use sauce because the meat should be flavorful and smoky alone....these ribs were very bland and a touch dry...almost zero taste of the smoky flavor you crave from a bbq joint

sorry, but we won't be back...boo!
author: Guinnivere B.

description: In many ways, Memphis Minnies is my "home base" of San Francisco restaurants--the place I go when I just want some delicious comfort food in a relaxed, unpretentious setting.  The red beans and rice with andouille is one of my absolute staples.
author: Buzz A.

description:
Pros: Authentic feeling cute Kitsch 
Geeky and friendly staff 
Casual 
Decent BBQ. 
Delta Blues background music 
Owner has personality 

Cons: 
Unclean (Does SF. Environ Hlth Dept ever visit?) 
Not maintained physical structure 

..................................................................Kinda Fun!
author: s c.

description: I am a deep southern born bbq snob, I looked for great Q for years in this area tried every place anyone mentioned and frankly they were all what I would call 'California bbq'.  This is as good as it gets in this part of the country, it could hold its own in most parts of the country as an above average Q joint.  I have been here so many times I have literally had everything on the menu and have not found anything I would not order agan, although admittedly I am not a fries person.  I have brought several others who think they had found the best Q in this area and have converted them all.  Any bbq place can do ribs but if you want to test a place try their pulled pork and brisket.  Memphis Minnies shines with everything on the menu being extremely strong.  The only thing is that it could be a little less sticky on the tables, but again coming from the south if the table ain't sticky the Q probably sucked, unfortunately most folks I have brought here don't see it that way.
author: Bob F.

description: I have past this place a thousand times and finally went in the other day.  Wow.  You better have a strong stomach.  I got some pulled chicken sando with a side of mac n cheese that was just excellent.
author: Tito C.

description:
Ever since i moved to the Bay Area from Texas about a year ago i have been on a steady search for a decent BBQ place for when im feeling homesick. The first place i tried, Uncle Frank's in Mountain View, remains my favorite, but this place is definitely seconds (haven't tried Bo's yet).

My GF and i were planning on going to Bo's last friday night but she got home late and there was no way we were going to make the hour long drive and get there before they closed. With my heart set on having BBQ i remembered reading about Memphis Minnie's and looked them up. They're open till 10, so we hopped in the car and headed up to the City. 

The place was much smaller than i was expecting. Its also pretty kitschy. It doesn't feel like the best texas BBQ joints which are usually out in the middle of nowhere and involve a large woman who calls everyone 'baby', large slabs of meat served on butcher paper (no plates), and a roll of paper towels at ever table. This place feels like it would fit in pretty well in Austin though. And the t-shirts and other memorabilia from some of my favorite BBQ joints back home indicate that they know their history.

So how was the food?

We started with the rib appetizer. The ribs were okay, but certainly not the best i've had. They were a little dry (i like wet ribs) and weren't quite fall-off-the-bone tender. Luckily they have 3 sauces to help the dry ribs problem.

Ah yes, the three sauces. They do a vinegar based Carolina sauce that was good, but i can't really compare it because i haven't had authentic Carolina vinegar sauce. Next up is the mustard based Carolina sauce that was definitely the star of this trio. Not quite authentic but delicious in its own way. Last up with the tomato based Texas sauce. It was good but a little bit off. Texas sauce is traditionally sweetened with brown sugar (or sometimes honey), not white sugar. While there was brown sugar in the ingredients listed on the bottle, it was definitely sweetened with mostly white sugar. Also, Texas sauce traditionally has much more heat than this. Throw in some crushed red pepper and you might be on to something. See Uncle Franks for a great tomato based sauce with some heat.

Next up we got the pork sandwich with BBQ seasoned fries. The pork was okay but also dry. I loaded it up with the mustard based sauce and it turned out okay, but i feel like i make better BBQ pork sandwiches at home. The fries were pretty incredible though. 

Last up was the brisket. With mac and cheese (the GF has a thing for mac and cheese), collard greens, and a corn muffin. Holy crap, the brisket was incredible and after everything else being pretty mediocre caught me completely by surprise. Next time i come here im only getting brisket. It really needs no sauce but a touch of the Texas sauce sets things off just right. I'm pretty unusual in that i am a Texan who loves pork BBQ (thats a Tennessee, Georgia, Kansas, Carolina thing), but i agree with most that brisket is really the way to test a bbq place. It starts out as a tough, fatty, truly disgusting cut of meat, and anyone that can turn it into something delicious knows what they're doing. This was good brisket. The mac and cheese was good but not great. The collard greens were fantastic though. I didn't know anyone was cooking collard greens in the Bay Area. Wes was right though that the sides are ridiculously small. The cornbread muffin was also a bit dry and not sweet enough for my taste.

Speaking of bread, i know that if there is one place in this glorious country where wheat bread is giving white bread a thrashing, its right here in the Bay Area. You guys (and myself included) love that super dense 9 grain stuff that could kill someone if dropped on their head. I continue to be amazed and you guys' inability to eat white bread with BBQ. Look, i don't think i've had a sandwich on wonder bread since i was in 3rd grade. I love my wheat bread. When it comes to sandwiches for lunch, or toast for breakfast i turn end to a grouch if i get stuck with white bread. But somehow with BBQ it just works. Nothing soaks up that sauce and washing things down like a slice of wonder bread. Why is that so hard? Im not asking you to eat wonderbread all the time, just with BBQ. You can't get cancer from eating like 3 or 4 times a year. Plus you're eating BBQ, are you really going to try and monitor what you're putting into your body? Wheat bread or french baguettes just don't have the right texture. Its got to be white bread.

I'm not really sure whats up with the sake and would advise people to stay away. I see how maybe the flavor contrast would work but it just feels wrong. Instead go for the sweet tea, a southern staple. Its not the best sweet tea, but its not bad for being served out here. 

They make good sauces at Minnie's, but they should get over their fear of putting them on the meat. I'll be coming back, but at the moment Uncle Franks is still the king of Bay Area BBQ
author: Travis D.

description: Had the brisket sandwich it was good- but nothing to drool over/ crave...it was fun trying the 3 types of sauces though! :)
author: Valerie A.

description: I got the "southern star" combo so i could try the brisket and the pulled pork. The brisket was my fave but the sauces they have can make any sandwich taste good. The funky decor made for a fun atmosphere but the pigs in every size, shape, and material caused a little guilt. The coleslaw was not up to par, but the french fries were good. Next time I am craving bbq, I will be going there again.
author: Caitlin D.

description: This place is fucking amazing. Its probably not the most traditional BBQ joint (like Brothers in Law) but it is so addictive I can't give it enough stars. The brisket is what is most popular here and rightly so. My recommendation for an introduction to this place is to have their brunch, served on the weekends from 10-2. If you have their brisket hash with poached eggs and do not immediately have an orgasm then you must be impotent.
author: Steve B.

description:
The T.G.I. Friday's of BBQ.

There are t-shirts from real, legitimate BBQ cook-offs hanging all over the walls and they have brightly colored displays explaining things like "Grilling VS BBQ", "Kansas City Style VS Texas Style", etc. A seeming accumulation of cute little introductions from all the stupid BBQ-101 books that you scoffed at last time you had to be inside a Barnes & Noble or the like.

If Minnie's turned out phenomenal, competition-quality 'cue, the whole decor would still be a bit Red Robin. But given the mediocre meat served there, the decor is reminiscent of a white college kid with nasty dreadlocks who wont stop explaining (in harvard ebonics) the differences between rap and hip hop.

You're standing there thinking, "rap and hip hop are great and all, but I'm sure that whatever kind of music is in this douchebag's ipod is crap custard".

Same story at this BBQ joint, I'm sorry to report. For all their authentic posturing and detailed explanations of the art, they don't deliver the goods.

The pulled-pork sandwich is served on a hard french roll. Without coleslaw.

The ribs are BOILED before smoking.

Boo.
author: Jupiter H.

description: What can I say, this is as good as it gets here in San Francisco.  The meat was decent but what is the deal with the sauces?  The vinegar and mustard sauce should be removed quietly out the back door leaving only a mediocre BBQ sauce that leaves a lot to be said for.  The staff is helpful and the crowed is pretty much your urban trendy skinny jeans and t-shirts with vests.  Then again this is the lower Height.  If you're looking for decent BBQ, I'd suggest heading over to Oakland.  It's not bad, but I'm sure you've all had better...I know I have.
author: Ron O.

description: In the age of Yelp, I was so suprised to find that Memphis Minnies couldn't accomodate my order for 20 people take-out on Saturday--it's Tuesday.  I have ordered from Memphis Minnies before and the food is good--love the ribs and mac and cheese, but I guess now I will need to find another BBQ joint.  Maybe they should hire more people or make some more mac and cheese so as not to lose an order for 20 and future business
author: Honey N.

description: Love the cornbread, love the coleslaw, love the nana puddin. Oh ya... the meat has been pretty tasty too! Slow cooked, smokey flavor. I love that their sandwiches are large portions of meat between two slabs of bread - no frills. Prices are pretty high but you get a lot of food. The interior is colorful & pretty grimey. I've never had a problem with the service although it has never been great.
author: Kevan M.

description: I've been to Memphis Minnie's twice and I've had stomach problems for three days both times.  The Texas sauce is not texas-style and should not be labeled as such; it has some weird spices in it.  Still looking for good BBQ in the Bay Area...
author: H G.

description: Slow-Smoked Texas Beef Brisket & side of fries -yum!
author: Sha A.

description:
i like it.

- slunky, smoke filled bbq house.  
- casual eatery
- hot as hell, kick yo a$$ spicy bbq sauce - on special request

- came here to get nasty bbq filled teeth for my birthday.  we were all happy with full tummies
author: Mimi X.

description: Me and my buddy was craving some bbq and we came upon this on yelp and omg this is the best bbq i've had in SF so far. i had the smoked ribs and brisket w/ baked beans and mac n cheese and all i can say was DELICIOUS!!!! the ribs was moist and tender, the brisket had a nice flavor and melts in your mouth, the mac n cheese was just to die for, and the baked beans was soo tasty.
author: Tim T.

description:
one of the worst disappointments ever.

the menu gets me all hot and bothered, but when i finally tried it, i was crestfallen. everything was either too sweet or too something. 

definitely not as good in practice as in theory.
author: jennifer y.

description: Best Brisket I have ever had anywhere! Friendly service, sort of a rough neighborhood.
author: Aaron B.

description: I was born in Northern Alabama, I know good pork BBQ and this guy does it right.  Gus, the guy that runs it is awesome too.  Get him to sit down and talk sake with you, he's quite knowledgable.   Sake with brisket that is smoked for 18 hours is to die for.  Bet you'd never guess it's a great combo.  Pork ribs are great too. Wanna know why the sauces are so good?  He puts clarified butter in each of them.  That'll do it! Favorite sides:  The greens, the coleslaw, and of course you can't go wrong with fries since you can dip them in more bbq sauce!
author: matthew w.

description: This place has made it possible for me to stay in the bay area as long as I have.  I ran across this place right as I was considering moving away because of the lack of good bbq.  Bob is a really great guy, and a real scholar on all things BBQ.  He's really fun to talk to.  He even put the Hoover's t-shirt I brought him back from Austin up on the wall.  Too bad they don't do brunch anymore.  It was the best.  I wake up some Sunday mornings jonesing for the pulled-pork hash.
author: Benjamin P.

description: the meat is pretty good, but the sauce is sugary sweet. It IS a southern style bbq joint though, and a trademark of southern style is sweet sauce.
author: John M.

description:
Minnie's is still the barbecue king of San Francisco, though its place at the top is slipping (see my last paragraph).  I just reviewed B's and wrote plenty about the good and bad points about Minnie's, so I'll make this a little quicker.

I saw Bob Kantor's name on the guest signbook at Snow's in Lexington, TX the very same day I went--it's too bad I didn't get the chance to shake his hand.  

The brisket at Minnie's is the best in San Francisco.  The meat and the dry rub are excellent.  It's as good as a commercial smoker can produce.  Sometimes the brisket can be a hair dry, but it's usually fantastic: flavorful and moist.

The sausage at Minnie's is also the best in San Francisco.  I can't stand links, and the andouille is actually reasonably similar to the sausage cooked in Texas.  No complaints: it's the best around.

The ribs are also good, though I prefer B's.  B's have the perfect rub and the meat just tastes better.  Minnie's ribs can be a little dry.  Baby Blues also has good ribs, but B's wins in this category.  

The sides at Minnie's are excellent--the mac & cheese, fries, and cornbread are all very good.  Big win for Minnie's.  The sauce is also very good, especially the yellow mustard stuff.  Very distinctive and goes well with the meats and sides.

Now to the major downside at Minnie's: the intangibles.  More specifically, it's very difficult to get a meal there.  They have no takeout register--which means that if you call in in advance, you still might stand in an absurdly long line to get your food, which is just unacceptable.  It's even more unacceptable considering there's no parking at all in the Lower Haight, which inevitably means you have to park illegally to pick up your food (and then risk geting towed for a half hour while you wait in line).  There's no delivery option either, so these problems can be especially troublesome.  The cashiers can also be annoyingly dismissive, the space is pretty cramped and the service just stinks.  A word to the wise at Minnie's: the difference between you and the #2 in the city (the just-opened B's) is now very small.  This is when service becomes a higher priority.  Yesterday I had a decision to make between Minnie's and B's and I chose B's because the food is excellent, it's easier to park/pick up and the owner cares about his customers.
author: Damien W.

description: Awesome food....wholesome...comforting....and tasty.  Mellow low key environment.  Good to eat there...easy to get takeout too.   Make sure you order dessert!
author: Mr P.

description: I like me some BBQ!  If you love BBQ, then try this place.  I'll admit, it's not the BEST BBQ spot I've been to, but it's darn near close.  The ribs were tender and the BBQ sauces were yummy.  If you aren't aware, the parking situation is horrible at the Haight area, so you better have some Wheat Thins in the car to munch on while you drive around for about 1 hour to look for parking.  Check this place out everyone, it's a treat!
author: Manton R.

description: Perhaps as good as it gets in SF for BBQ, but I don't rate on a curve. Avoid the beef ribs--overcooked and dry when I tried them. Stick to St. Louis and don't set your expectations too high.
author: Eric M.

description:
i loved this place and i would like to think that i have very good taste in bbq considering i'm a so-cal lass and my husband is from texas (who is super picky about bbq and also a fan of MM).  the two-item plate is the best and the brisket was just exploding with tastiness while the pulled pork was so soft and flavorful.  the banana pudding was smooth, light and just darling.

the joint is on the small side, the staff was nice and the food came along quickly considering the place was jumping the night we went (we had a LARGE group of people dining and they all loved the food as well).  i didn't venture into the sauces as i felt it would be blasphemy to cover up the perfection that was the meat.  as far as the negative reviews below, maybe y'all just had a bad chef because my experience was outta sight.
author: Selene S.

description: I didn't earn the nickname BBQ Ben for nothing so you know I love me some BBQ.  After a pretty long hiatus from BBQing because of school and a lack of space for a grill at my apartment, I got a really really bad craving for some 'que.  After some research I decided to try out this place and I really wanted to like the food here because the ambiance is cool, but I honestly think the food was lacking.  I had the pork ribs which were not really falling off the bone and on the dry side with the beef brisket which was really full of fat but pretty tender.  For the sides I had the mac n cheese which was barely even lukewarm and seasoned fries which was a bit too sweet but was the best part of the meal.  The cornbread I had was not even warm, come to think of it nothing in my meal was served warm which disappointed me.  Like I said I wanted to like this place but I just couldn't.
author: Ben M.

description: My standard order includes the brisket sandwich with a side of collard greens, rib tips, and a slice of pecan pie.  The brisket has a crunchy bark with just the right amount of spice while the meat has a medium smoky flavor that does not need any sauce.  The collard greens are salty good, and the pecan pie has enough sugar to induce a diabetic coma. All of which I expect from a good barbecue joint.  Occasionally, I'll get the pulled pork which I find tasty as well.
author: Charlie S.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  My friend was raving about the BBQ here and I liked the atmosphere... it really made you feel like you were going to a southern homemade hole-in-the-wall restaurant that gave it a sense of authenticity.  Maybe it was just a bad day, but I wasn't really feeling it that night I had it.  The place is pretty poppin as soon as you step foot in the door, I was introduced to someone's back as there was a long line to the cashier.  And the place wasn't very large, so the amount of people that can be seated was pretty minimal.  One thing I did like about the place was how the guy behind the counter will basically yell out to get your queue to a table, and the customers there were pretty nice about following the rules.

I ordered the Texas Beef Brisket with side order of mac n cheese and potato salad.  The sides were very average... I think I've made better mac n cheese and their potato salad, while better than the mac n cheese, was very typical.  The brisket was pretty good, though very dry eating it straight up.  They had these bottles of various BBQ sauces that you can add to the meat, and I think that's the only way to eat the meat here.  I drenched that sucker with the Texas Red Sauce and it made it infinitely better.  It wasn't very spicy, but it did good.  I was able to finish off most of everything on the plate, but I don't know why this place didn't leave a better taste in my mouth.  Perhaps I had really high expectations here due to what I had heard, but I had a hard time deciding whether it deserved at least 3 stars.  After contemplation, I couldn't give it more, but I am willing to try the place again if I ever get a chance to, so I can open my eyes and tastebuds to what people are talking about.
author: David Y.

description: I was extremely disappointed of my visit to this place. My gf told me she remembered going there and it was good and her brother in law loved it. Since I love Rosamunde and Toronado so much I thought why not try this place out. So we split a 3 entree (St. Louis Ribs, Pork and Brisket). All the meats were extremely dry. I was expecting at least the Pork to be moist but I do have to understand that we are in San Francisco and not Texas so maybe that why that was the case. THe BBQ sauces they had on the tables I wasn't too impressed with. THe Mac. And cheese looked like something that was packaged along with the Potatoes. I tried to finish the meal as fast as possible so I can get a drink at Toronado and forget about this place. This definitely goes on my Ban list.
author: Nir B.

description: Minnie's is a great place if you are craving slow-smoked, southern BBQ with vinegar-based sauces. Their brisket is the tastiest in town; be sure to get the platter so you can pick 3 of their great side dishes. I recommend the beans, corn bread, and mac n' cheese. For dessert, their pecan pie and banana pudding are as good as any place in town.
author: Peter C.

description: We go here before Niners games to stock up but only if Brother in Laws isn't open. The selection of sauces, three of them in total, is really cool. Everytime I have the brisket I think about my Hindu friends and how much they really all missing out. Everytime I bite into the pork ribs I wonder how silly Islam really is. Where I think this place falls short is in spicyness (I like it HOT!) and the sides. I'm not down for cornbread...I need a buscuit or some bunny bread. Check this place out, it might match better with your palate than it did mine. In the meantime...if Brothers is open, that's where I go.
author: Steve H.

description: I had heard a lof about this place, but it was a little do overated for me.  Food was good, but its expensive. I had the Beef Brisket.
author: Scotty B.

description:
I am from Alabama and spent all of my summers as a child in North Carolina; I know southern bbq and this is NOT it. I haven't been this disappointed in a meal in a very, very long time. It is a sad day when the best thing you eat at a bbq joint is the onion rings! Also EXTREMELY overpriced. Being from the South this place is a slap in the face to southern cooking. 

I must also point that a native Californian was with me. She thought the place was as bad as I did. She actually said "Hell, Popeye's would have been better southern food. Neither one of us ate much our food.
author: Steven R.

description: Too many good things to list...but definitely get the brisket. Brunch is awesome as well.
author: Chris R.

description: My friends had their doubts when they saw the child like font out in the front.  Needless to say, once we left they never once doubted my restaurant picks.  This place made the Lowell newspaper!  What more can you ask?  Go!
author: Doogie H.

description: If you like brisket, then come here quickly to sample theirs because its frickin great, I don't know a place in the Bay thats as good and I've eaten at nearly every 'que place around. I wanted to not like this place when they took over my old fav breakfast spot Spagetti Western, but the decor aside, its all about the meat and this place does it right. Although I can't recommend ribs since I never get that. I usually get the southern star brisket sandwich combo because I like the pork too. The sauces are great, the owner is cool, nice to talk to about bar b que in general and its located across from Toronado, the best beer bar in the U.S., and you can't always eat the great dogs next door...
author: Brian Aaron J.

description: Never again. Canned greens. Canned yam. It was like eating straight vinegar on half the meat. Burnt cornbread. They ran out of ribs at 4pm pn friday? My father liked the fish so maybe one dish worked. If you are use to real BBQ ...forget it! And if you like ur stomach don't get the greens or Mac and Cheese.
author: B S.

description: This is a 3.5 star place! I will keep it short as first, there is really little if anything  to say in the negative column. As most who know me, I am a stickler for this being as objective  as possible. This is one of the few times that I can say that the majority of the good to terrific reviews are accurate and maybe underrated! Everything they have, and I think I have had half the menu at some point, as my other half eats here weekly, and its all superb. I rarely give three stars or  in this case three and half. I have taken people from out of town and every one of them have revved about the food. As far as my negative reports, ....umm, well still can't think of any.  i Think they are very  very good at what they do, and don't know why they have not grown as I would think other locales would gladly welcome a Memphis Minnies. The sides are good and my one tinny criticism if I have to have one is that the fries are ever-so slightly a tiny bit on heavy side of salty. The flavor of fries with garlic and crispiness are great. I don't like boring  McDonalds=type fries. So I will keep this small. This is one of THE BEST PLACES for barbecue. Price is very reasonable considering what quality of food is, and portions are on the larger side as well.
author: Jeff V.

description: Had an pretty decent meal there - the fried chicken (smoked first) was solid... The slaw was fantastic, but there just wasn't enough of it.  The greens had a great flavor, but were cut up too small.  The cornbread was cold and dry, with no options to add anything to it.
author: Stacey M.

description: Too much smoke flavor in the meat.  WTF was the flavoring in the greens?  How do you FU greens?  A $45 mistake.  They have a Goode Co. Barbecue t-shirt on the wall and my rx is they should go to Houston and take some lessons from a REAL barbecue master.  Will not return.
author: B Y.

description: Not sure why BBQ becomes so unexceptional once you are west of Texas, but there you have it. I had heard good things about this place, and while the service was very efficient, the food left something to be desired. The ribs were only okay after smothering it in sauce, the sides were downright bland, and it was pricy for the portions received.
author: Paul J.

description:
Very very tasty BBQ.

Great flavour. Really the food couldn't be better. Had the ribs, brisket - its all good.

Only complaint is that when you are there and its cold the wind from the street just rips through the place and its freezing cold. There doesn't seem to be any heaters in there and they keep the door open.
author: John S.

description: The pastrami sandwich on Wednesdays is mighty fine! I'm not from the south or anything but all the meat here tastes swell to me.
author: gabriela l.

description: Delicious!  Fun atmosphere and great food, including good sides.  The brisket is moist, and the sauce is sweet and spicy.  Great when you need a barbecue fix, don't waste your time on other places, this place has what you need.
author: Bridget L.

description:
I'm a regular here, which in light of my following review, either makes me very patient or just a glutton for punishment.  (I'll explain that part at the end.)  In sum: dining at Memphis Minnies is a very inconsistent, very uneven experience.  More often than not, it's just not very good.

At its best, this place deserves all the superlatives you'll see in the other reviews.  Seriously.  Its brisket, when the brisket has just been roasted, is succulent and wonderful.  The fatty exterior of the cut is charred just right, sealing in the juices.  Similarly, when the sweet-pulled pork is just ready, it's a moist mound of fine barbecue.  The ribs--I'm less a fan of the ribs here, and have fewer good things to say about these-- but that said, when they're done right, others seem to like them.

The problem is that they're rarely done just right.  You never do get the barbecue here at the peak of perfection.  That legendary brisket--purportedly slow roasted for 18 hours--is, at the time you're ordering, roasted for a whole lot longer than that.  And by the time you get it, it's usually quite dry.  I won't exaggerate and say that it has the consistency of beef jerkey, but it sure looks like beef jerkey--and that is *not* an exaggeration.  And dry brisket, by the way, is not very appetizing (and annoyingly flaky).  

And the same goes for their pork, and their ribs, and their tri-tip.  

And forget about trying to get a truthful heads-up from the college-aged help behind the counter.  Ask them how their barbecue is that day, and they've got an answer that'll make Ol' Memphis Minnie herself proud: "it's great."  The help is, well, no help at all.

Anyway, I'm a regular at this restaurant because I live around the corner from the place.  This is, for me, one of few neighborhood joints that I go to when I don't feel like cooking, which is often.  So, I've been to this place many, many times (easily more than 20x, probably less than 50x), and I have a strong basis for my opinion.  So take my word for whatever you think it's worth.

The Bay Area's got a decent amount of barbecue places (mostly in Oakland, but one or two in the city as well), many of which are quite good and very consistent.  If you're looking for good barbecue, go elsewhere.

(One thing: If you must go, and I know it's not cool to do this, but I really do recommend asking to see the cut of meat that you're ordering.  You can tell right away if something's been in the smoker too long.  Also, if the guys behind the counter pull out your ribs and they're wrapped in aluminum foil--which I've seen more often than I can count--just cancel your order and run to Rosamunde's across the street.)

Rosamunde's is good all the time.
author: Donovan X.

description: After having a disastrous BBQ experience in Milpitas I was hurting to  have some good BBQ. Luckily we were going to San Francisco. I had remembered watching "check please" and seeing this place. It looked so good on the show that I have been wanting to try it for months now. I was not disappointed. The place is nice enough inside. Not seedy at all. I had to get it to go since I had just eaten a few hours earlier. We tried the beef and pork ribs as well as the brisket. All were solid.
