I personally liked the regular BBQ versus the mustard but it was nice to have a couple choices. I really want to go back and try some of the other side dishes like the mac and cheese and fried grits. The banana pudding looked good too! Next time for sure. Good job Memphis Minnies for restoring my faith in BBQ. now if I could just quit burping up liquid smoke.
author: Johnny J.

description: This is really good *Tennesee* BBQ which is not necessarily *Southern* BBQ. If you eat traditional BBQ in Memphis, New Orleans and Austin you will get three very different things. And I love them all.
author: patrick g.

description: I haven't been to many BBQ-specific places but this place rocks.  It totally has the BBQ restaurant feel to it.  I ordered the brisket with mashed potatoes and mac n cheese with a beer and it was under $10.  If you love BBQ like most people should you definitely need to come here.  It's pretty busy and there's a reason for that.  The only thing I wish for is a spicier BBQ sauce to choose from.  While the sauces they have are excellent none had any kick to it.
author: David C.

description: Just average food. Ribs weren't very meaty. Recommend getting the meat combination plates.
author: Derek N.

description: This place is SO good.  I had been to Brother in Law's and Big Nate's multiple times and no one had ever told me about this place.  They brought it in for work a few weeks ago and it blew those places away.  Try the mac & cheese (I had four servings).  Also, I had great pulled pork.  Try it out!
author: Steven M.

description:
i'm from the south.  the south, south.  georgia.  florida.  i grew up in a swamp.  i rode alligators to school.  ok, not really.   but i do know good bbq.  and while minnie's smells amazing, it isn't quite right.  the chicken was juicy, but not as flavorful as it should have been.  the pork ribs were tasty, but not quite the falling off the bone tender that i love.  the sauces were tangy but not quite right- too sharp and watery (i like spicy or sweet or both-- i don't know about this tangy stuff).  the greens were... i don't know.  they were something- sweet, but not a natural sweet, like a frankenstein-sweet.  the yams were ok.  the baked beans were just god-awful.  the potato salad, though, was amazing.  mustardy and chunky and creamy and almost as god as momma's.  almost.

all in all, minnie's is the best bbq i've had so far in SF (it is also the only BBQ i've had so far in SF).  it is good and i'll be back, but i can't say it is authentic or amazing.  it is just good.  a nice solid 3 star good.  a worthy good.  you should go.
author: Samantha W.

description: I lived right by Memphis Minnie's and had the chance to try a few of their options.  I ordered the Texas brisket meal one time (supposedly smoked for 18 hours).  They offer 3 different sauces (a Texas one, a NC mustard one, and a NC vinegar one).  Corn muffin tends to be dry (a la has been sitting out for a while).  The brisket was quite nice but overpriced.  The sides (beans and mac & cheese) were very small in portion and not memorable.  I never got around to trying their ribs because they're on the pricier side.  My best advice: try a sandwich, half the price of a meal, and you still get a nice portion.
author: David L.

description: My friends and I were eager to try Memphis Minnies after seeing it on the "Check Please Bay Area."  I wasn't expecting everything on the menu to be loaded with fat, but it was.  I figured I would eat something super healthy for dinner, so "Let's do it"  My friends love BBQ, they routinely go to Phil's in San Diego,  We were all sadly disappointed.  The meat was tender and juicy, and that is where I would leave it.  Everything else was really dissappointing.  Too me they even messed up the hand cut fries which were sooooo salty.  The greens were vinegar sugar mush.  I had a pulled pork sandwich which had too much cartilage in it.  I would not go back.
author: Scot B.

description: For 4 people, we ordered 1 lb of the BBQ pork ribs, 1 lb of the beef briskets, 1 order of the fried smoked chicken, and 1/2 lb of sausage.  Total about $68.  Very good food.  Loved the ribs, very tender..even my 18 month old baby could chew on it!
author: jane l.

description: I'm very disappointed. This place has a lot of hype, and I just wasn't impressed. I guess I was expecting something like TJ Robinson's Gingerbread House-quality eating experience and it just was a major fail. I split a Memphis Sweet-Smoked Pork, which was adequate, but dry. Sauce helped, but none of the sauces stood out. The Red sauce had a Thai-Vietnamese-Teriyaki taste that was more strange than delicious, the yellow mustard sauce was also underwhelming. Those two were the most tolerable of the four sauces offered, and every time I tried one, I was convinced that the other sauce might redeem itself. And it didn't. So the meat was dry and the sauces were weird/untasty (and thin/runny). We ordered beans and potato salad for the sides, and our plate came with corn bread. The corn bread was good, if not spectacular. The pieces of meat in the beans were a lovely surprise, and the beans were actually pretty good. I'm not a beans person, and I don't generally appreciate beans, but I have to admit they were very flavorful. The potato salad was fine. I had a sweet tea with my meal-- which tasted strangely fermented in a weird way. Nothing I ate here was amazing, and everything was quite pricey. The portion size of the sides are small. I plan on giving this place another try in the future. Maybe their fried chicken sandwich or beef brisket will blow my mind. I hope so. I lied to my bf about how I felt about the place because I didn't want to hurt his feelings. He seemed to enjoy the food very much. The cooks were very friendly, and the waitresses are very young, loud, and flirtatious. Maybe I should come back to this place when I'm not PMS-ing.
author: Christine S.

description: Great food and sandwiches for the price. You have to try their sweet tea and Macaroni and Cheese!
author: Bryan K.

description: I think just about everything has been said already in the prior 308 reviews so I'll keep it short.   I've eaten BBQ throughout the south and southwest and MM's is legit!  The smoked pork is consistently fabulous!.  The sides are okay, but the meat is usually top-notch.  While I tend to like the molasses, brown sugar, ketchup based sauces,  I love the 3 different sauces at MM's.
author: Raj M.

description: You absolutely cannot find better BBQ in the city! That's it - you just can't. WHY did it take me so long to go here? Oh yeah - all the pigs were a little intimidating for a semi-kosher Jew like me! Yeah - I don't do the pork thing. But they have SO MUCH MORE than just pig products! Chicken, Beef, Brisket, Grits, MAC & CHEESE, Sanwiches, Beef Ribs - I LOVE IT! Great prices too! But what's with the Sake menu? Huh? Am I missing something? When did BBQ pair with Sake? Seriously - their Sake list rivals Skipjacks. Who cares. I SMOTHERED my brisket sandwich and fries with their house made BBQ sauce and mustard. EVERYTHING is made in house from scratch. As it should be! I swear, I damn near drank the stuff. Just go. It's great. Don't let the pigs scare you away ;-)
author: Eli S.

description:
its ok

i suppose my friends talked this place up but its mostly pork based and i'm not a fan of that. I had the tri tip sandwich it was tastey but i don't think i'd go back ever.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Here's the deal...
I used to be a big fan when I ate meat...but now I don't even really know why I was a big fan - I'm not just a sorta fan. I went there and ordered some sides - the food was pretty okay...but the wait was wicked long and the guy was really rude. We asked for cornbread and he got really irritated...told us that it would take 30 minutes for any more cornbread to come out....our order took almost nearly as long to prepare & there was only 2 of us...he could have offered to put them in the oven for us anyway and told us we'd be waiting for a while anyway.
The people who got their order right after us DID get cornbread. 
I know it seems silly to take away stars...but his attitude wasn't really that nice. 
Also. they have a sign asking for us to nominate them for the Diners and Dives show on the Food Network - but why would i nominated the restaurant when the service wasn't friendly and I felt like I was putting the dude out or something.

However...if you like Banana Puddin'...they make the delicious Nilla Waffer kind like you'd make at home. Yum.
author: Katy A.

description: All the other reviews stress the incredible bbq and they are all correct...however the real treat here is the saturday/sunday brunch.  I shouldn't even be telling you all this because pretty soon I won't be able to get in the front door on a weekend morning.
author: Quinn C.

description: I love this place. Most of the dishes are of the "dry" bbq sort... If you are into beans, their smoked baked beans side dish is great. I've never been there when it was crowded--usually after the lunch crowd on weekdays.
author: Dan P.

description: This place has amazing BBQ!  I get the pulled pork sandwich and my boyfriend gets the beef ribs and chili everytime.  Great service and tons of food!
author: Cynthia B.

description: Go on Wed. -Pastrami Reuben, at a BBQ joint will blow your f-ing mind.  Oh the rest is good, but the Pastrami Reuben is just about the best damn sandwich you can find in SF.  The rest of the grub is good, TX BBQ Sauce has a cinnamon flavor, good, but different.  Like I said go on Wednesday, cuz the Reuben is only available on Wed.
author: Mickey D.

description: Moved to San Francisco from Texas, and my quest for good BBQ in the city lead me first to Memphis Minnies. I was overall disappointed. Bad meat and very disappointing sides. I was going to give them three stars just because I have yet to find any BBQ in the city that is any better and yes, as a Texan I have high standards, but the lack of good BBQ is SF is one of the things calling me home to Texas.
author: Blake R.

description:
Too bad this place is on the other side of town....else I would be eatin it every day.   I LOVE BBQ DAMMIT!  And Memphis Minnie's is wonderful!  Yummy!

Get the ribs....they are to die for.
author: James B.

description: I could make this reeelly funnneee but then the review would be seen as pure comedy. So on with the serious review. This place did not suit my taste. I had the pulled pork and beef brisket combo. they both had the standard smoked flavor that you could find at nates,everett jones or carmens. Nothing special really. It was dry too. I was expecting something exciting and special that i could proudly gush with oohs and ahhhs but alas it was nothing to even write about with exception of this review....oh, i almost forgot...the coleslaw was good!!!
author: tiny w.

description: This place is O.K. I am totally from S.F. and so I'm just not into all that vinaegar in my sauces. Sides are pretty good but I never crave them. The meat is great sometimes and sometimes too dry. For the price I prefer more consistancy. Staff was nice but who cares if the food isn't what I want. I can see someone else digging on this place but I just don't think it is for me. That's all.
author: Boxxxman J.

description:
Memphis Minnie's was featured on "Check Please" on KQED.  Three everyday, off the street type of people who apply to be on the program are invited to share their view about their favorite restaurant.  Each of the other two also patronize the restaurant and give their critiques.  The program is quite informative as the restaurants range from greasy spoons to some pretty upscale places.  Another feature of the show I like is they tell you what to expect to spend per person without drinks.  

Memphis Minnie's received rave reviews so I was disappointed when the food didn't blow me away.  I ordered the St. Louis rib plate which included a sweet corn bread muffin and two sides.  I chose the potlicker greens and the southern sweet potatoes.  The greens were good and the sweet potatoes were ok.  The skimpiness of the portions bothered me somewhat.  The sides amounted to about two tablespoons worth and there were about 4 or 5 ribs on the plate without the tips.  The tips are offered as a separate cut.  The ribs were fairly tasty but a little too dry for my taste.  The meat would just about fall off the bone before you could get it into your mouth.  Minnie's does make excellent sauces which are abundantly available on each table.  My wife had the tri-tip sandwhich.  Interestingly enough, the only thing on her plate was a tri-tip sandwhich, no fries, no cole slaw, nothing.  You would think at $8.95 they would at least put some fries and an ice cream scoop of slaw on the plate.

Ever since this place was featured on "Check Please" the place has been jammed.  One of the people in our group said he's never seen it like that.  There is only seating for about 20 people total so if you have a group as large as 6, it is a challenge to get seated together.

I honestly don't think I would go again considering the fact that Armadillo Willy's does a better job on it's meats and is a much better value.
author: geoff k.

description: Good consistent BBQ. But the real story here is their sides. AMAZING mac&cheese and cornbread. Oh man how I love their sides. The good BBQ is an added bonus. Also usually very friendly staff.
author: Drew C.

description:
You can't help but to notice the little red building with its windows ablaze and the cartoon like sign featuring a jolly chef toque adorned porker. We actually came across it as if by mistake. After being smacked in the nose by the aroma of wood smoked meat we frantically looked around wondering where the intoxicating BBQ smells were coming from.

When you enter you find yourself transported instantly to the Deep South. The smell of barbecue is heavy in the air and there is row of tables occupied by a wide variety of patrons clearly enjoying their meals. There is a small pie case that displays some of the regional desserts, the sauces that they make, and some piggy influenced chachkis, which can be found all around the restaurant.

At first I found the menu board to be a bit complicated. I don't mean to say I didn't understand what the items on it were; I wasn't sure why some of the items were on it. I guess when I really think about it one item kept distracting me; Premium Sake. As it turns out I am not the first to point out that Sake and barbecue are an odd combination. Their official position on the sake is that there are similarities in the long standing traditions and artisanal approach to both, and besides, the Sake tastes great and so does the barbecue so together they are doubly good. Ok, I'll buy that. Some people drink red wine with fish and white wine with beef, and some people will drink Sake with barbecue.

Since we just happened to end up at Memphis Minnie's and this was not a planned review I was a bit unprepared to order the variety of foods that I would for a typical menu sampling. Since I was with a couple of other people I just let them know that I would be eating off their plates for the sake of the review. They hesitantly agreed.

I ordered the Minnie's Taster; three meats with a choice of two sides. On my plate will be the Texas Big Bones, the 18hour Smoked Texas Brisket, and the Memphis Sweet Smoked Pork. Accompanying those meats will be the Potlikker Greens and the Tart 'n Tangy Slaw. In addition to those I will also be sampling the St. Louis Smoked Pork Ribs. I really had my mind set on the Andouille sausage, alas there was none. In all fairness it does say "Not All Items Are Available All The Time" right on the menu board.

I prefer to start with the sides, let's get the supporting cast out of the way so that we can get to the main event. The slaw is crispy and tangy. There are slivers of red onion and bell pepper which compliment the shredded salad. This is not your typical California creamy mayo slaw. The dressing is on this is vinegar based and has a distinct twang to it. There is a sweetness that follows as your taste buds snap back, but it is well balanced and not sugary.

The Potlikker Greens are prepared in a classic down south manner, with onion and vinegar and slow cooked tender greens. I found these to be quite delicious but a little sweeter than I like. I did put about half of them down before the sweetness got to me.

Center stage was a battle for the best and quite honestly I find it almost impossible to pick the best of these incredible smoked delicacies. The beef ribs are rich and dark with a zesty bark. The meat comes away from the bones cleanly and they are the most tender beef ribs I have ever experienced. Next, the pork shoulder, buttery soft and smoky with just the right amount of spices. The outside pieces are sweet and sticky from the slow cooking process. No knives are needed here. The beef brisket was juicy and tender. The flavors were mesmerizing and the texture was perfect. There was a quarter inch smoke ring on the tender beef slices. The St. Louis Ribs also came away from the bone cleanly. The outside was crusted with spices and slightly charred meat while inside; the tender pork, pink from smoke was juicy and sweet. I struggled with the idea of putting sauce on this perfectly cooked meat but the variety of sauces on the table was intriguing.

On the table were three sauces Red, Vinegar, and Mustard sauce. First the Texas Red; Bold, tangy, and sweet, the flavor of ginger and clove stood out. The North Carolina Vinegar Sauce is tangy but not sour. I think the word vinegar in the name of this sauce is a bit misleading. It is fresh and herbal and really wakes up the meat you sprinkle it on. South Carolina mustard sauce is a just little sweet and has a delicate nature. It is a perfect accompaniment for the any of the pork dishes. All of the sauces were balanced and enhanced the meats. They were delicate enough to let the meats natural flavors come through, yet bold enough to stand up to the rich smoky meats that they adorn.

In Northern California where you find barbecue restaurants with no pits, and heavily sauced meats cooked in ovens, Memphis Minnie's is a whole new world; like walking through a portal to a land where barbecue matters. The meats are perfectly prepared and the sauce is optional if needed at all.
author: Ron L.

description: After moving to SF from the South, I thought I had sadly kissed my BBQ-eating days good bye. I was gladly mistaken! Living so close to Memphis Minnie's has made my life make sense again. Sweat Tea will make any real human's life worth living, and this does a pretty good job at living up to my syrupy standards. But by no means is it 'Soul Tay' (2 parts sugar 1 part tea), so no diabetes for you. They have the sauces sitting directly at your fingertips at every table. These people know how it's done. No one wants to leave their slice of glory unattended to refill their sauce chalices! Brisket = amazing. Pulled pork = amazing. All sides = '!!!' (anything to do with) Grits = amazing. Haters be stopped! Please do your psyche a favor and eat some soul food (Monday's excluded).
author: Sarah Ann B.

description:
I saw the review of this restaurant on Check Please Bay Area and tried it due to the favorable review of all three panelists.  Like any good restaurant reviewers, we tried an assortment of entrees and side dishes and were disappointed with everything.  The only dish that was marginally acceptable was the brisket.  The portions were small, the ribs were overcooked and the flavor was bland unless you added more sauce to the meat.  All the side dishes were bad especially the the corn bread which was very rough and contained hard pieces of corn. 

I would go to Big Nate's or Everett and Jones for good bbq.
author: Larry Y.

description: The meat is done well, but the sauces all really leave something to be desired. You can do better at most divey bbq joints in the city. Save your money.
author: Adam F.

description:
Either there are two Memphis Minnie's or the place has some some serious consistency problems.

The meat is traditionally barbecued: cooked over wood or charcoal "long and slow," but that's about it.  I've tried the place a few times and have always found their meat overcooked to the point of mushiness.  I agree that it's probably perfect for a two-year old, but I prefer more consistency to my meat than Gerber's.

Additionally, I have not had a good side dish there yet.  The macaroni and cheese is mediocre, the "southern" sweet potatoes laughably bad, and the cole slaw only acceptable.

Oh, yes, Memphis Minnie's does offer a small variety of barbecue sauces.  I believe a trio: Memphis, Texas, and Mustard.  None of them are great.  For really good barbecue, I suggest barbecue fans travel farther south in the state to Central Texan Barbecue in Castroville or Pecos Bill's in Glendale.  Those two bring true meaning to the word barbecue.
author: Richard C.

description: Beef ribs were dry and over loaded with dry rub seasoning making the ribs unpleasant to eat. disappointing at best.  Mac n cheese was nasty In General I feel like the food was way over priced for what I got (quality and quantity).  I do give this 2 stars as the pie was solid.  I have been to better BBQ here in San Fran; go else where.
author: brian w.

description:
Went here with my folks and GF.

We had pork ribs, pulled pork, mac and cheese, and brisket.

Pork ribs:
Tender
Good smoke ring
Smoky flavor
Juicy

Brisket:
Dry
Overcooked
Smoky

Mac and cheese:
Dry
Flavor lacked punch

Pulled pork:
Great smoky flavor
Tender
Juicy
Good stuff

Mustard sauce was perhaps the best. Took some home and added it to a beef stroganoff dish I made later in the week. Yum!
author: David L.

description: Meh.  People rave and I had high expectations.  The mac and cheese is fantastic, the brisket is really good.  But it's a BBQ joint, so the coleslaw shouldn't be swimming in vinegar, the sauces should be thicker, tangier and spicier, and the ribs should have some flava.  And I wish there were more than 2 beers on tap.  Stella + Anchor don't cut it when you've come from Tornado.
author: Kelli R.

description: My favorite brisket BBQ in San Francisco.  I also adore the brisket chili fries, and for only $7 they are a steal (big enough to easily split between 3 people).  My greatest surprise was to see my fiancee, Anelya S., only give this place 3 stars, specifically because she didn't like the chili fries I absolutely love!!  I guess not everyone likes the same food.
author: Allan G.

description: Pretty inconsistent if you ask me.  The mac n cheese is a winner.  Their cole slaw is interesting:  spicy, sweet and my favorite menu item which is not good for a bbq place.  All of the meats I've sampled (brisket, tri tip and various ribs) came out dry, overcooked and just generally uninspired.  Much better bbq to be found at dives and rib shacks in the souf.
author: beltrand a.

description:
Barbecue heaven
Sauce not a necessity
Brisket melts in mouth
author: HaikuReview X.

description:
Being from Texas I consider myself to be very picky in the BBQ arena.  Memphis Minnie's is fantastic.  I had the brisket and it is to die for; no need for sauce, it melts in your mouth!   

I can't wait to go back!
author: Katherine P.

description: I thought this place was good. I also did not care for the dry cornbread. I did like the pulled pork and I thought the place was pretty cool. The prices and portions where fair. I was not too crazy for the sides. I would go here again, just would not make a special trip.
author: Lisa A.

description: This is good barbeque in the Lower Haight. It's a great place for brunch. The sausage is good and the fries and beans are worth having. Pork is tasty too. For some reason, you can get sake here. I guess it goes well with BBQ. Who knew? I like the atmosphere, but I can't give 5 stars to a place that makes dry cornbread.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I saw Memphis Minnie's on Check Please Bay Area (KQED) and thought I'd give it a try. After reading some good and some not so good reviews, we headed down to the Haight. Sorry to say that this is a not so good one. I went there with my wife and ordered a smoked pork rib plate and a Texas rib plate. The sides were mac n' cheese, greens, baked beans and sweet potatoes. Both plates come with cornbread. The sides were at best mediocre. What you would say "nothing special". The cornbreads were hard and coarse. Now for the really bad news, both the pork ribs and the beef ribs were DRY and TOUGH. Maybe it was because it was 7pm, but they close at 10pm! I don't know, but that was ranked near the bottom of my BBQ list! I just can back from a business trip to Athens, Georgia and I had some ribs to die for there! Tender, juicy and succulent! 

Sorry, but I won't be back to Memphis Minnie's.
author: Andrew L.

description: I may or may not be giving Memphis Minnie's a four star review merely for their absolutely delicious sweet tea.  Their Pastrami Wednesday pastrami sandwiches may also be contributing to their four stars.  The mac and cheese is probably also related.  The brisket is probably not part of it - I found it a little dry.  The ribs are definitely a piece of the puzzle.  And the really remarkably nice people that work there are certainly helping to round it out.
author: Oliver N.

description: My first taste of SF barbecue, and the immediate inspiration I had was to open up an Arkansas outpost in the city. The coleslaw wasn't even a good vinaigrette, not nearly enough to make up for omitting mayonnaise. Potato salad was similarly disappointing. I've had the brisket and the pork, which were both fine, but not exactly stones from the foundation of genuine bbq -- which leads me to the sauces, all of which failed the simple test of being spicy, flavorful, and tangy. Three stars because I was full afterward.
author: Henry M.

description: They get 4 Stars on the yellow BBQ sauce alone, not to mention the banana pudding. I've recently noticed that the meat is a tad inconsistent- one day the brisket is dry and lean, the next day it's fatty and juicy and same with the pork. I love the ribs, and the bread that they use for their sando's is really good, hollowed out to make room for the meat. The owner is really nice and I believe that this place has the best BBQ in SF.....
author: Matt H.

description:
This place stays true to the spirit of "real" bbq.

Real BBQ--it's cooked ("smoked") for a long ass time over a fire usually with oak, mesquite or some other substance that adds its own rich flavor to the meat. What most of us (on the West Coast at least) consider BBQ at home is in fact called grilling which is a different concept (unless you are getting into Santa Maria style than that's a whole other deal).

So yeah I take my BBQ seriously....

I hadn't been to this place in forever but after feeling a certain grumbling in my gut followed by a sign (ok I was thumbing through Details and I saw huge pornographic pics of meat--the dead coming from animal kind, not the other kind of meat that Details would be prone to show) I realized I had to go out my quest. After a nice stroll I found myself here with partner in crime John H. I remembered the brisket being quite good and that it was! Rich smoky flavor in every soft yummy bite and I was fortunate enough to have gotten it at just the right level of dryness sans sauce. The Memphis style pork that John H got was equally good in terms of richness but not as lean as my brisket (but pork fat tastes so fricken good! Hey I'm a Yelper, it's kind of assumed if you eat meat and you Yelp, you eat bacon. Think about it.) The mac and cheese was surprisingly just as hefty on my belly as my sandwich. If I had had ANY room in my pooch left I would have filled it with their banana pudding concoction.   

Key notes though: This is tough to eat after a night of hard drinking. 

After all the food is consumed, for the rest of the day, when you burp you will be tasting your meal here. Rich meaty smoky burps=not cool.

They only have two beers on draft here: Anchor Steam and Sierra Nevada. And that's just fine by me
author: Veronica G.

description:
*drool* this is the best bbq in town, and possibly the universe. the meats are smoked so well that you don't need to slather them in sauces to make them tasty - in fact, i rarely dip my pork ribs or beef brisket (my personal faves) in any of the sauces at all. i highly recommend this place, delicious!!!!! plus, the owner is a highly personable guy who's around a lot, which, as Alexis said in her post, is always a good sign.  

expect to pay a little more than you expect to for bbq, but i think it's worth it.
author: Jacqui M.

description:
Bitch Bitch moan complain.

1) No, this isn't North Carolina. Thank God.
2) yes, the guy who owns it is Jewish...so what, are you an anti-semite? You think Jews Can't Que?

All I know is that you can get, sometimes for as low as $8, an ungodly amount of delicious rib tips long smoked until they nearly melt. You can help yourself to as much sauce you like from three different handcrafted versions (I like the Texas best myself, what with the hint of star anise flavor), but purists say you should just eat the meat.

Then you also get two generous sides of large calorie items...the mac and cheese is great, if not exactly healthy.....the greens are a bit sweet, but also sour and delish.

I'm not such a fan of the beans, but they are different than other places. The cornbread is pretty good and you get a piece of that too...so for $8-10 you can feed one extremely person or two smaller appetited folks....so what the heck are you all complaining about?
author: Darien W.

description: You don't find too many ribs joints in SF, let alone quality rib joints.  So, to my surprise, here stands a restaurant that not only satisfies my desire to pork out on fried foods (mmm...sweet potato fries...drool), but also offers up an eclectic pairing of sake and briskets.  I've been there a few times, and each time, the food tasted great.  My only beef (pardon the pun) is how was tough it is to find a table during peak dinner hours, when 40 diners fight over 4 tables (actually..more like benches).  Oh, the bonus for me is, Memphis Minnie's is one of a select few restaurants in SF that is part of the AAdvantage Elite Dining service...meaning I get triple (or was it quadruple) points on every dollar spent.  No, I'm not a American Airlines marketing rep...I'm just someone who likes to collect miles and fly for free.
author: Sy K.

description: Although I live in California, I am a student of Texas BBQ, Memphis dry ribs, and Carolina BBQ pork.  Although CA is a culinary adventure, real-deal BBQ is hard to find.  I had heard great things about MM and finally went.  I had the 3 meat combo plate and had 3 huge beef ribs, 4 St Louis pork ribs, and slices of brisket plus 2 sides (pot liker greens and smoked pit beans) along with a good IPA.  Easily the best BBQ I have found in CA.  Everything had deep smoke flavor without being over-bearing.  They use CA Oak wood.  IMHO oak is best for Texas-style BBQ.  The beef ribs were both crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.  Had to chew around the membrane, but no big deal.  The brisket was really excellent, deep smoke ring but tender and moist.  Not as good as the best joints in Texas (Louie Mueller is my benchmark) but still pretty damn good.  The pork ribs were tender and tasty.  The sides were wonderful.  Never tried greens before, but they were wonderful with both sweet and tangy vinegar notes.  Pit beans were equally good and much less sweet than most versions and had some vinegar kick.  Corn bread was just OK.  I will be back soon to try there other meats:  Santa Maria tri tip, Carolina pork, and chicken.  This is great place to have BBQ.
author: Bob Z.

description:
Not to beat the proverbial (vegetable protein) dead horse, but I don't eat meat.  That said, Memphis Minnie's is not a natural go-to restaurant for me, but nonetheless, I've been a time or two.

I am able to speak to the tastiness of the corn bread muffins, the sweet potatoes, and the potato salad: Memphis Minnie's really knows how to whip up a damn fine starch.  Plus, they've got sake, and everyone knows that herbivores love sake.

My fondest memory of exemplary service at Minnie's is when one of the employees overheard my table debating the ingredients of mincemeat pie.  He sort of got himself in to the conversation, but couldn't offer any answers; ten minutes later, he walked back over with the Joy of Cooking and elucidated his findings.  (Turns out we were all both right and wrong.)
author: Hannah J.

description:
i am absolutely weird but I found the sides to be better than the meat. is anyone with me on that??

BUT

the meat was still super good,and if it were a man...i would not have thrown it out of bed.nosireee
author: Lauren V.

description: I thought it was decent.  I liked the hot bbq sauce and the pulled pork sandwich.  I did pour a lot of that sauce on my pork, which is something I normally don't do with bbq.  Oh, and they have sweet tea!
author: Pamela S.

description:
I know SF in general has nothing on the South when it comes to BBQ, but if you want a fix, and a fun atmosphere with very little 'tude to chow with your friends and drink a cold one before/after you hit the Lower Haight hood, then this place fits the bill!  

Pros:
* Nice, messy, large portions, that taste satisfyingly unhealthy
* Fun ambiance (pig curio collection, friendly staff when I was there)
* Really really cold beer in chilled pint glasses
* Wide selection of side dishes
* Awesome sauce selection including a hot hot sauce at the counter

Cons:
* Lighting is pretty harshly bright if you've just come from a dark bar
* A tad on the expensive side for a walk-up counter place (but you can split a plate if you wanna save a bit)
author: Josh J.

description: Perhaps the sandwiches are good, but everything we ordered wasn't. We shared three dishes: the BBQ pork, ribs and chicken. Everything was dry as a bone. The side dishes weren't impressive either: mac and cheese, potato salad, sweet potatoes, fries.
author: Bogee B.

description:
we've eaten here a few times and it's always good!  the ribs are delicious and love the sauces.  definitely get the mac n' cheese, so good with the crumbly stuff on them. 

we also went to a wedding not too long ago where they catered and it was a great spread!
author: jennifer l.

description: just a ok...service is slow...food just ok.  When we went there, it was not busy at all but it took the guy almost 15' minutes to realize that he needed to take the order.  We ordered the ribs and it was ok, the sauce was just ok.  I would rather get the bbq at Big Nates and eat it at home.
author: Pikachu P.

description: the bbq is sooo great. I believe they smoke their meats for days and when it's on your plate... they pretty much melt in your mouth.  the bbq sauce is good but the meat is where the action is at. wear some tre casual clothes and get ready to dig in to the food.  Potato salad is alright and the bread is good.
author: Grace K.

description: Authentic?  No.  Great barbeque?  Not really.  Pork can be dry, depending on the day, cornbread also can be dry.  Mac and cheese is a oozy mess of goodness,  Great place to go when you're hungry and want to overeat and feel sick but satisfied.  I'll go back.
author: Pug P.

description: What is it about blues and beef that just goes together so well?  I had the Santa Maria tri tip sandwich and it was damn tasty. Coupled with some decent (non mayonaisey) cole slaw, it was an enjoyable experience. For two of us it was almost $25 for lunch, which is a bit on the higher side, and     to be honest the place wasn't as clean as it could be. Which is kinda gross, when you're eating....beef...
author: Dana K.

description:
This place has decent barbecue. I have to say that I really like the fact that their meat is done well, and you have the option of choosing your own sauce.(self-service from bottles placed on each table) If you prefer a sauce with a "bite", they have one that has a balanced mix of vinegar, mustard, and brown sugar. This is the variety of sauce I am accustomed to, and prefer it over any other. The other two sauces seemed less sharp, and one bordered on downright sweet.  Barbecue is quite literally  a matter of taste, and in large part depends on whether you are a 1) meat person, or a 2) sauce person.  Memphis Minnies seems to deliver on either count. The meat was good, but the sauce made it (as we say in Texas) "gooder than gum" !!
The restaurant itself reminds me of a hole in the wall. The clientele was an eclectic mix of folks and the place can get crowded, as seating is limited . Give this place a whirl. I don't think you will be disappointed.
author: Michael D.

description: Pretty good BBQ.  Better than anything we have in San Diego.  Sorry Phil.
author: Mike S.

description: I had the beef brisket and it was good the only problem was at the price of $17.25 it should be a 2-way order or you should get more food. A half of scoop of Mac n cheese and the greens where kinda of nasty. They have the highest price bbq in the city. I give them 2 stars!
author: Tt I.

description: My friend and I stumbled upon Minnie's one night and we will definitely be back. Tasty BBQ (not the best I've had, but still the best I've tried in these parts), GREAT service, AND they have Stella on tap! The owner was wonderful - he even gave us more lean brisket when they saw that we hadn't eaten the fatty stuff! It felt like a true neighborhood joint, which will bring me back every time!
author: Mollie T.

description: I like this place a whole hell of a lot.  I really like their vinegar.  I, though, am a vinegar fan.  There are three varieties, and each one is a blast!
author: Jason W.

description: This place is 'just okay', like, if you need a bbq fix and want to get it in a convenient location. I agree...the meat is tender but without flavor unless you're generous with the sauce. For what it's worth, the guys who work there are sweethearts.
author: UrbanEmpress G.

description: Memphis Minnie's is DISGUSTING. Don't eat here. Ever. I went with my boyfriend last night and we both got the ribs, which were not tender and devoid of any flavor, and abundant with chewy (yet gelatinous) fat. We each got two sides, I had the greens and slaw. Both were completely DRENCHED in vinegar. I ate most of my greens, only to satisfy my hunger, as I wasn't eating anything else. Luckily I had a nice pint of beer to wash all that vinegary flavor down. My boyfriend got beans and potato salad as his sides. Much better choices, but absolutely nothing to write home about. As for the sauces, there are 3 choices. They might as well call these Vinegar #1, Vinegar #2, and Vinegar #3. Blech. Heed my warning. Eat somewhere else. ANYWHERE.
author: Liz R.

description: Ok, I am from Texas, Austin and Houston to be more specific.  I have eaten more BBQ than most people I know.  It's a staple back home.  This place has just about the same if not slightly better BBQ than every other BBQ place I've been to in California (north or south).  I will say that the environment is pretty cool.  You sit next to people elbow to elbow, and the tablecloth was red checkered.  The mac and cheese is good and the ribs are so so.  It's in the lower haight, and the vapor room is near by.  So if you have a medical card go get your buzz on and the food will be even better.  Oh and the big fella behind the counter is so funny, I miss normal people.
author: Amir B.

description: Haven't been here in awhile (thanks to my vegan gf who also doesn't like southern food). Trust me I dont hate vegan cooking but I am getting off on a tangent. This was awesome from what I remember of it. The mac and cheese was awesome but I ordered it again on the same trip and it must have been a new batch and it was horrible. My only complaint consistency people. Great BBQ
author: Chris L.

description: I don't know what happened to this place. BBQ used to be great, now it's just dry.
author: Three B.

description: First bbq I've ever tried in the city...I had the sweet pork, and tasted the brisket (kinda dry) with some beef bones. Personally I like the sides better than the actual bbq. Good comfort food, tasty seasoned fries, macncheese and tangy slaw. No waiters, but they asked us how the meal was at the end. They've got Sierra and Anchor on tap, and the prices are reasonable for the amount of food you get. 3 sauces-red bbq my fave, then the mustard, followed by the vinegar. I sat in the corner at a small table by the john, which was a little annoying at times. I'd go back to try the brunch.
author: Kim G.

description: Yes, the brisket melts in your mouth. But we have been going for the breakfasts -- the Chicken Hash is kick ass, plain and simple!
author: Eric P.

description: This is one of my very favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  I always get a sandwich and have loved every single one, especially with the sauces at every table (the Beelzebub is serious stuff).  My favorite all-time is the chicken-fried chicken and coleslaw sandwich sometimes on special.  The sides I've tried include baked beans, macaroni and cheese, fries, and sweet potatoes, and every single one of them was delicious.  I can't say enough about this place, and I hope every non-vegetarian in the city goes there.
author: Cassidy K.

description: Good for lunch, dinner, take-out and weekend brunch.  Sure hits - brisket (smoked 18+ hours) plate or sandwich, smoked pork plate or sandwich, smoked pork or brisket hash (weekends only), tart n' tangy slaw (vinegary crispy goodness, excellent when put on the sandwich).  The fries are decent, but often cold and limp.  Tasy and tangy collards if you go for that sort of thing.  (I do.) I seem to like the cornmuffins more than most.  I've only been a handful of times, but look forward to going back and trying different items.
author: darla s.

description: While the food was OK, it didn't transport me back to Dixie, porch swings, and kids eatin' watermelon on the riverbank with their feet dipped in the cool, cool water.  With a name like Memphis, you wouldn't expect Texas tastin' BBQ. If it is Memphis style, the last time someone offered me that was in Lee Atwater's restaurant in DC. It wasn't very inspiring either, and that place was south of the Mason-Dixon line.
author: Rene D.

description: 5-stars for San Francisco BBQ, can't think of a place I like better.  I usually get the brisket plate with beans, mac 'n cheese, and the corn muffin and wash it down with 3-4 glasses of sweet tea.
author: Ryan P.

description: I live by this place, so I come here pretty often.  The food here is awesome and your always full after eating here.  The coleslaw is different, but good, and the the mac and cheese is the bomb.  This food makes you pretty gasy thou.  haha.
author: christopher h.

description: Tasty Barbequed food. I had the pork spring rolls, which were very tasty (especially the sauce that goes on the top). In fact, I ate the second one the next day for breakfast (go figure). The prices were fairly low, and you get your food almost immediately. Can't really beat it.
author: Dana L.

description: "The side dishes are listed behind the flying pig".  That's what the guy at the counter told me..and anyone who has to say that for his job has got to be working at an interesting place.  Had the brisket and pulled pork, and even though I couldn't tell the difference between the two (probably because I covered them in sauce...I'm not from the south), they were both good.  Their sauce has got that zap that keeps you pouring for more.  Good place for BBQ, and the prices are fair.
author: Mark D.

description:
mmmmmmm, i was craving BBQ so badly when i walked in here. i ordered just the plain and simple half rack of ribs. it was delishhhh..
only complaint is that the tables were filthy and it took the busser a long ass time to clean them off. and also there bbq wings were a tad too dry for my taste. and they were coated in some weird candy hard bbq sauce.

but the FRIES and MAC n CHEESE there are off the chain good. mmmmm i could sit here all day clogging my arteries.

first time u go ORDER THE REAL RIBS, none of this sandwich sh*t...

;)
author: Diana C.

description: I like this place a lot. I'd give it 5 stars but their greens are disappointing-there is a sweet tang to them that should just not be present in greens. I like my greens bitter and smoky with bits o pork. Sweet roasted pork and the brisket are awesome! The candied yams are delish. and! there is also a hot boy that works there. Don't tell my boyfriend about that last part.
author: Fancypants J.

description: I like the brisket, spicy chicken, pulled pork, and tri tip.  I like the brisket just fine without any sauce.  The dining area is cramped; I don't like eating at someone else's picnic!  Also, I'm not a fan of the brunch menu.
author: Brett N.

description: I'm convinced this place is for out-of-towners. I've eaten waaaaay better BBQ than this place. Too much hype. It's oookkkkkk if you live in the area and are stoned or craving BBQ. Super pricey too. Brisket and chicken was dry. Ribs were alright...
author: Rouz E.

description: Wow did it get sold to a new owner or did i just go on a bad day.there food used to pretty good but the other day all the sides were really off ...dam do i have to start lokkin for a new place again?
author: gary n.

description:
Although I rated this place a 3, I really gave it a 3.45, but couldn't find the heart to round it up to a 4.  I tried the beef brisket and smoked sausage and the beef was for the most part tender, although the ends of the slices were very dried out.  The sausage was a bit spicy for me but had a good flavor.  The fries were pretty good...freshly cut and "barbecue" seasoned with a sugary tint.  The macaroni was an interesting combination of cheese and cornbread.  You get a choice of three barbecue sauces at your table (North Carolina vinegar, red hot sauce and mustard something) and i tried the red sauce.  I felt it was lacking a bit in flavor and it was a bit on the watery side and cold (a bit cooler than room temp), which didn't work well with my hot meat.  I was a little annoyed that the water dispenser that kept giving me pink water and I was also a little disturbed by the alternating honky tonk and zydeco music playing overhead.  Sorry the zydeco just didn't fit with the barbecue to me.  Where are they supposed to be hailing from?  Memphis, Texas, or Louisiana? The servers were nice enough and my food came up in 2 minutes literally.  The meat was good, but I've had a lot better, but this is San Francisco, so ok, I may have to lower my expectations a bit.  (I'm originally from Texas and went to college for 5 years in Memphis if you're wondering).  Like I said a strong 3 rating, but I'm open to changing my rating for better or worse when I go back and try the fried catfish and ribs and try some more sides.

11/5 Update:  Gonna have to knock this one down to a 2.  I've visited 7 times now since I live in the neighborhood and my experiences have been going downhill in quality ever since.  I still think the catfish is tasty, but I ordered a barbecue sandwich this past time and the bread was wrong for the sandwich, the meat was cold, and the barbecue sauces on the side were cold.  Why oh why would you ever serve someone cold meat and cold barbecue sauce, or hot meat and cold barbecue sauce?
author: LaSha G.

description: Fab BBQ, great prices . . . wood-cooked somehow . . . they say a little charcoal is good for the innards even if buried in sauce
author: Carma K.

description: This place makes the best brisket!!! The downsides are that this place is pricey... but damn.. it's worth every penny. Hands down, best BBQ joint in the city.
author: Sunny Y.

description: Oh the pulled pork!  I've been here about 20 times, and the pork is their drawing card.  Tender, sweet, flavorful meat with a smoky bark on it.  No other place in the bay area comes close to their pulled pork.  Their brisket is good, and he smokes it for 18 hours.  The ribs are great one day and ok the next.  The skinny fries are seasoned and are another highlight here. The pecan pie was sweet and crunchy.  They serve saki?  One of my favorites is the Southern Star,  a french roll with pork on one side and brisket on the other. They also have deep fried egg rolls. Sounds funny but they are tasty. The owner is a well known BBQ historian, and interesting to speak with.
author: Louis H.

description: Good BBQ awesome Mac n Cheese. The lower haight is quickly becoming my new favorite hood.
author: Rob H.

description: Love this place!! Smokey brisket that cannot be beat!  Good BBQ sauce to accompany it (although you really don't need that much of it to enjoy it).  Don't forget the fried peach pie.
author: H. Q.

description: Thank you oh soulfood gods for bestowing upon me your golden morsels of fried catfish love n tartar sauce.  I'm on a cloud in heaven...mmmmm..
author: Rosieposie Y.

description: Overall---will do when you're craving the BBQ.  The ribs are solid, pulled pork is done quite well, and the brisket is very tender.  But, the beans have a strange flavor and not sweet enough for my taste.  They never give enough BBQ sauce for my liking.  The sides are okay, nothing spectacular, nothing terrible.  Oh where oh where can I go to get knocked off my feet by BBQ??!?!?!?!?!
author: Jessica L.

description:
this review will probably sound a little skewed seeing as how ive been to minnies once and it was right before closing but...

so the bex and i walk in probably less then an hour before this joint closed (10pm on a friday!? why the f* does everywhere close early in this F*ing city?). she got some sort of bbq plate with two sides and i got a beef brisket sandwich. the meat in my sandwich was ok... pretty tender and good texture but pretty bland. i mean, if it werent for the mustard/hot/vinegar-y sauces, my tongue would have died of boredom.

bex's bbq wasnt any better and actually was pretty worse! it was cold, and dry and the flavors were negligible. i dont even think the sauces helped.

the worst part of the whole memphis minnies experience was that after we stared at the menu for a solid 10 minutes and had our hearts set on our respective sides, they told us they were out of the garlic fries and mac and cheese. what they did have, however, was the audacity to brag about how good their mac and cheese was even though they didnt have any. come to think of it, i dont think beef brisket sandwich was my first choice either, but they didnt have what i originally wanted.

maybe we came in at a bad time? maybe next time ill come in when there's some food left. then again, i dont see that next time anywhere in the near future.
author: N. B. K.

description: I must admit  Memphis Minnie's BBQ was really good.  When you walk into the restaurant the cook is very out going and friendly. The BBQ is so tender and juicy  the meat falls right off the bone,  I had the BBQ Chicken Plate that was good but I liked what Patrick O. had which I don't remember what he had but I would go back there in a heartbeat.  it may be a little over priced but it's worth it.  But I also would agree with Patrick O.
author: Emma R.

description: Best BBQ I've had in SF. Nice kitschy atmosphere and friendly, helpful staff. The meats are delicious, as is the chicken. They don't overdo it on the sauce so you can actually taste the meat, but a variety of sauces are provided to kick it up a notch if one desires. They take their time slow-cooking the meat here and it shows- the brisket is absolutely melt-in your mouth delicious. Haven't had a bad meal here and I will definitely keep going back.
author: Brian H.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for a long time. Reading all the great reviews I couldn't wait to eat here. I tried the half and half sandwich (half brisket half smoked pork) with the BBQ seasoned fries. Either I went on an off day or my taste buds are not working very well! The only reason this place got two stars is because the brisket was very tender but aside from that...forget about it! Everything tasted like charcoal fuel...so bad that you couldn't even hide it with BBQ sauce. And the fries...lets just say that they looked like they needed some Viagra...I'm just not into limp fries! I should probably try it again, just to give it another chance but for right now it barely gets two stars.
author: Reza E.

description: I am becoming a regular of this place. Their BEEF BRISKET is consistenly excellent, and I also like the pot licking greens and the corn muffin. It is a good place to take visitors that like meat or perfect for a day where you need soul food. The only downside is that it might take some time to find parking, but definitely worth the effort
author: Candido B.

description: I think I've never had a bad meal here...except I've learned that the mac n cheese is not as good as it used to be...so I've moved on to the potato salad and sweet potatoes, which are both good, as well as their tasty cornbread. I like their sandwiches, you can get a couple of the bbq sauces to dip them in. The NC bbq sauce has grown on me and I do believe is the best one with chicken or turkey. The pork and beef items are a bit lost on me, but I hear the beef brisket is pretty good. You can also pair your bbq with sake and it actually suits it quite nicely.
author: Gina R.

description: If you're in the mood to head south of the Mason Dixon...this is your place!  Best fast BBQ in the city...it can be a little spendy for quick eats, but it's worth it!
author: Sarah D.

description: Yes, this place rocks.  Get it with the sake sampler.  I've only had the beef brisket, the meat just melts off the bone.  They don't serve it with sauce, the right way, but the hot sauce they have on the side is fantastic.  It has the flavor and the ambience of what a bbq place should be like.  Mac 'n Cheese with the ribs is a phenomenal combo.  And the collard greens are good, too.
author: T. F.

description: I really enjoy the BBQ here, I especially like the fact that they don't smother everything in sauce in order to disguise lower quality meat...I also like to sauce each bite to taste (Yeah, I know I am a freak)...A little mustard sauce, maybe some vinegar sauce...yum!...The sides are ok, but I come here for the meat!...Oh,and the lil flying pigs!
author: Lara D.

description: Ordered the St.Louis ribs and the brisket-both were considerably dry and tasteless.  You really needed to pour on the sauce so the meat wouldn't stick to the roof of your mouth!  The greens and slaw were heavily laced with vinegar-a bit too acidic for my taste.  Prices are on the high side-spent over $34 for lunch for two and that's without a drink!  The staff gets a star for their friendly attitude but I won't be back.
author: Al L.

description: Good god and they call this barbecue?!  Okay I am from Texas so I know I am prejudice when it comes to barbecue.  None the less, so maybe the barbecue it self can lack, but please must we kill the sides as well?  The mac and cheese was terrible, tasteless and to wet if you will.  It feel apart, the corn bread lacked and the slaw had a ton of pepper and not to much on the bite of vinegar.  Not great.  On the up side the meat was tender, yet not flavorful.  My vote, go else where as it is nothing to write home about.  Better yet, find a nice southern girl like myself who can cook!
author: Nicole F.

description:
give me an f'ing break. (can i swear on here?) this place sucks. the only reason i gave it one star is 'cuz it beats eating out of a garbage can (actually, i know some good garbage cans that serve better food). i've eaten there twice and was severely underwhelmed both times. the owner's "no extra sauce 'cuz i want people to taste the rub & smoke in the meat" policy is a load of crap as far as i'm concerned. also, you'd think with 3 or 4 "various styles" of "regional sauces" at least one would be good, as opposed to all of them toeing the line between bland & unpalatable. the sides are decent, but what's the point if the main course is so dry and bland.

i hate to be so negative, but considering how hyped up this place is, it NEEDS to be taken down a notch. ugh. i've been to chain restaurants with better bbq.
author: bad k.

description: Dry meat, mediocre sides, dank decor. The only thing giving this place 3 stars is the sauces. I heard one patron say that he'd traveled all the way from the east bay to check this place out, man would I be pissed if I'd made that trip. One thing that made no sense to me, it's called Memphis Minnie's, but doesn't have a sweet sauce option, just Texas, North and South Carolina styles, that seems odd. Anyway, the meat lacked any smoky flavor, the brisket barely had a pink ring. In general the meat was as dry as a bone. 18 hours my ass, it must of spent another 18 sitting in a warming tray. I might give this place 1 more try in case i caught it on a bad day, Sunday afternoon, but otherwise I won't bother going back.
author: Ross M.

description: Awesome place with some kickass smokey flavored ribs. Pity that when we got there that night, they were out of most of the items so we did not get to try those Pork Ribs but we will make another visit for that next time. We did manage to get our hands on the pulled pork and also the big beef ribs. The meats tasted succulent on their own but if you needed more flavor, just slather on those sauces they provide on the tables. My favourite is the vinegar one which pairs perfectly with that juicy meaty flavor! I was soo looking forward to the banana pudding since everyone was raving about it but guess we will have to be back for that once again! So the meal was well worth the hunt for the parking spot and well worth that long wait outta the door
author: Topazskye L.

description: My favorites were the brisket and the pork ribs.  The meats were quite tender, no knives necessary.  The sweet smoked pork was a bit dry and odd tasting to me so I had to drown it in their red sauce.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
being from the south, sort of, every so often i get a craving for that most ingenious of southern inventions (are there others?) - sweet tea.  i know, i know, this makes me sound like white trash.  what can i say.  

the food is decent.  i mean, i'm reading all these reviews and i get it, the place where you grew up in texas is better, but  i mean, really.  this is SF.  northern california.  not exactly the land of barbecue.  i think they do a decent job, i wouldn't say the food is great, but it gets me my fix when i need it.   though i have to say, the idea of sake in a barbecue joint is just a little too SF for me.  it's like wifi at giants stadium.  call me old fashioned, but barbecue joints should not serve sake, and ballparks should not have wifi.
author: brian g.

description:
I came home one night, late from work and the gym, starving for nourishment.  I walk in and smell burnt animal.  Was there an accident with her dog perhaps.  Nope, My girlfriend had Ribs from M.M. for dinner, (defeat) and saved a few for me (success).  She's great, and I owe her or kharma a lot for those things.  I had only 2 ribs, but they were by far the best I've had in the bay, and the sauces were succulent.  
It immediately reminded me of a David Cross bit about a service for Jewish people.  "I have a few business ideas (that I'm going to advertise in High Times, amongst other places), and one of them is for a nominal fee, I provide a service where I will eat and describe pork to Kosher people.  And it goes something like this...  MMMmmmmmmmM,  dude ooooooohhh,  MmmmMmm. dude.  Falling off the bone... succulent, juicy meat.  ooooh, so good.  Why doesn't your God let you eat this?  Oh, really, no idea.  Sucks for you!"  -(David Cross)
And thats how good memphis minnies bbq is.  It makes me laugh, food doesn't normally do that.
author: Christian W.

description:
really good barbeque and the sides are quality as well.  not much more u can ask for.  just be ready to leave with a food baby in your stomach because it ain't light fare.  but it's really, really delicious.

all the pig paraphernalia is pretty awesome and hilarious too.
author: Looey P.

description: I love ribs and pulled pork sandwiches so I had high hopes for Memphis Minnie's.  Alas, this place just doesn't do it for me.  Its pretty average. The brisket usually looks pretty good, but alot of times the other meat is too dry.  To compensate, you'll need to use alot of their bbq sauce which is just ok.  The little corn bread muffins are a pretty good side.  The greens on the other hand are a pretty disgusting side.  They're so overwhelmingly drenched in their mustard sauce that its almost inedible.  Stick to the brisket and you'll probably be fan.  The rest is a bit of a crapshoot.
author: Zach J.

description: As close to Memphis BBQ as you are going to get here in SF. I'll start from the least impressive to the most. The rib tips, overcooked and not very good. Might as well not even bother with the sides, but since we got the three meat platter, they came with it. The cole slaw was barely edible and the mac n cheese was boring. Now to the good stuff. The Pork ribs were good. The Pulled pork was even better, nice and tender. The beef brisket was the best, perfectly cooked. The SC/NC/Texas sauces options were odd, but I guess they want to let the customer choose the sauce flavor for themselves...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Dry, dry & tasteless... Mac & cheese cold didn't even taste like cheese. Fries cold. I really wanted to like this place.
author: p t.

description: One of my favorite BBQ places in the city. They have one of the best coldslaw I ever had :) Their pork is amazing......
author: ji k.

description: The two standout meats on the menu are the beef brisket (Texas-style) and the pulled pork (Memphis-style). Both are served with the sauce on the side, so you know it's not hiding the pitmaster's mistakes.  Secret Tip: They now serve brunch on the weekends! A terrific collection of Southern-style dishes, including three different hashes that are out of this world.
author: Michael A.

description: Love Minnie's. The bbq is terrific, especially the brisket and the sausages. My only complaint is that I don't love the sauces. I prefer something thicker and spicier. The greens and beans are great too.
author: Mike B.

description: Damn good brisket with delicious carolina style sauce (it's vinnegar based). The smoked ribs are good too!
author: Peter S.

description: It's a rough call between slathering your meat with the Texas red, the South Carolina mustard, and the North Carolina vinegar sauces and they're all great, but damn, they don't fool around with their BBQ here.
author: G B.

description: BBQ dives are so missing in SF, even for a no-chunky-meat eater.  ...Addicting cornbread muffins and sweet tea, ...and a shocking great sake menu (?! yippee !), ....what a dining adventure, how can anyone say no?  Believe it or not, sake really goes great with homeade fried peach pie.  The baked beans could use work, but i'm hooked on the lay-low grunge and still have plenty more sides to try (mac&cheese is calling...)
author: Today Y.

description: This place was pretty good but some of the meats were dry and the beans were hard. Table was dirty and I had to clean it myself before sitting down. I ordered the mixed meat combination which included pork ribs and brisket and something else. Two of the three meats were dry and not so good but one of them was incredible and tender and juicy. I don't know for sure but I assume that was the brisket. They serve sake which was a nice suprise. A good solid place and I enjoyed some of the meal but can't give more than 3 stars.
author: Eater S.

description: What happened to this place?  I used to really enjoy their food, but my dinner last night was disappointing.  I always appreciated the care they put into preparing their meat; they don't just dump a bunch of sauce on it and call it a day.   But everything we ordered last night-brisket, pork, chicken, tri-tip - was really bland and dry.  And the sides just tasted tired.  Maybe Minnie is too.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Now that Brother-in-Laws is gone (or morphed for the worse), i think this is the best BBQ in SF. that's somewhat faint praise, but still, it's pretty tasty. we were there this weekend at a very busy moment and the guy working the floor was working his ass off --- it was still a little crazy, but no fault of his. i like the brisket and the pulled pork. tie between 3 and 4 stars goes up because of the hard-working kid who got us extra beers.
author: Erica W.

description: I must admit that they know my name here. It's not that it's the best BBQ in San Francisco, but it is really damn good comfort food. The sauces are all stand outs in their own right. I usually go for a chicken sandwich with coleslaw (think vinegar and tang, not mayonnaise) and macaroni cheese (topped with yummy cornbread crumbs). The iced tea is a must. And if you have a sweet tooth, I whole heartedly suggest the pecan pie.
author: Angela K.

description: I love BBQ but found this place to be only okay. The sauces (I think there were four) were all average. The pulled pork was pretty tender but nothing special. I'm hoping to find some better BBQ around here.
author: Raj T.

description: I am glad I found this place, it is a quick meat fix and playing with the sauces in an attempt to create perfection is pretty fun. I have only had the tri tip, but that was enough for me to want this place to be a regular eatery when I come back home. Words of wisdom right here, but dont use their "stupid hot " sauce by itself unless you want fireass, its a burner. It is actually called stupid hot.
author: Ray H.

description:
love the atmosphere! 
don't even feel like i am in san francisco, like i warped to  atascadero ha ha.

the sides are incredible. love the mac & cheese, cheezy fried grit sticks, & tata salad!

my bf said the ribs are better than roadside, although the price is much pricier than gorilla (you can get double the amount for same price)

don't get it twisted; mos definitely coming back....i'm a fan!!!
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
im not gonna claim to be a bbq expert but i definitely like the bbq here, i always order the memphis one, since i go with friends i have tried the others as well.

ceejay who introduced me to this joint some years back told me that its close to the bbq in memphis...and there are customers who have been to memphis who attest to this to.

i brought gessa here today, she ordered the st louis ribs and again judging by the plate after im sure she liked it. i like that the side orders are in small bowls too, its just enough sides for the serving of meat they give you.

for those who want to try a different bbq (other than those served at tgifridays and chilis) i recommend this.
author: Malou C.

description: For years, I thought this was a chain and never patronized the joint. It may not have the authentic and dingy feel of Brother-In-Law's but it's twice as good. For true bbq conoisseurs, it probably won't measure up to local joints in Houston, Memphis, or the Carolinas. But even so, they are still purists although offering a great variety of bbq options. I love the Southern Star sandwich (1/2 memphis pork 1/2 texas brisket). They don't like you to use bbq sauce (so you can experience the flavor of the meat) but their sauces are too good not to use. I could seriously drink a pint of their S. Carolina mustard sauce. The sides and desserts are awesome especially the beans, mac & cheese, banana pudding, and pies. I even had their burger today for lunch and it was great. Pretty cheap too. Love having this in the neighborhood.
author: Bill R.

description: it is a staple place for me since it is right around the corner.  it is definitely tasty, but at times inconsistent.  sometimes the brisket is too fatty.  sometimes the mac and cheese doesn't have the wonderful bread crumb crust it should.  but over all it is a solid choice.
author: Patrick M.

description: I tried...really I have. I LOVE BBQ and it's such a cute little place...but the meat is dry and the BBQ sauces aren't that good.  I mean, it's okay, I think  their briskett is kinda popular. I'm happy to eat the food when it's set in front of me, but let's just say I never have a craving for Memphis Minnies.
author: Hella M.

description: Who knew Lower Haight would have such a great BBQ place? I ended up here after the recommendation of my partner who had been before with a friend. Having been spoiled by Armadillo Willy's in the south bay for so long, I had no idea I'd ever be able to find something even close to what they delivered but Memphis Minnie's fit the bill! I had the tri-tip plate with potato salad and mac & cheese for the sides. After I orderded I was shocked to find they even have frito pie (a reason to come back for sure). I easily could have eaten an entire plate of their mac & cheese; it was that good. The place isn't huge however it can accomodate a large group (say 12 people). The atmosphere is pig kitsch with every pig figurine, pig t-shirt, or pig memoribilia available plastered all over the place.
author: Don O.

description: Being one of the very few dedicated BBQ joints already earns it some stars, but the food does fall short. No service to speak up, but some funny guys behind the counter. The pork is not bad, but not tasty enough on its own, yet I wasn't into their BBQ sauces, so overall didn't provide for the best meal. There are a couple of the standard BBQ sides, but they also are not that great. The cornbread was a little too sweet with out the balancing salt for my taste. Their breakfast menu seems promising, gotta try it sometime. It's not inexpensive, but BBQ rarely is. I just order the meat in pounds and get sides to make my own plate of food. It is a good place if your craving southern BBQ and don't have hours/days to grill your meats.
author: B C.

description: Happy is a platter of meat. And Memphis Minnie's delivers the happiness. The desserts ain't bad either - just order the fried peach pocket pies at the end of your meal so they're still warm.
author: hunter w.

description: Excellent EXCELLENT brisket.  Ribs were a little fattier than I like (I like baby back), but good flavor.  Highly recommend the brisket.
author: Rachel W.

description:
So app-on much recommendation from friends and seeing as this place is in my neighborhood I finally decided to take a walk and find out what all the hype was about. I love bbq and soul food and am always looking for a new place to call comfort town.
This place however did not live up to the hype.
Sides were unbelievably small and not that tasty. There was no fried chicken. I had the spicy pulled chicken sandwich and it was less than  desirable. Dry and not at all seasoned. There was absolutely nothing on the sandwich which would've been fine had the meat been all that it was cracked up to be but in this case not so much. The sauces were alright at best watery and not really all that interesting when it came to taste. I found myself drenching the damn sandwich in the mustard sauce to choke it down.
Its a bit pricey for what you get and I suggest ordering the tri-tip or pork ribs with like ten sides if your going to check this place out.
The one cool thing is that they do have brunch, the atmosphere is delightful...with brightly colored tablecloths and lots of chatchki on the walls to look at. Unfortunately it doesn't distract you from the fact that their BBQ was less than I expected. But hey thats what I get for expecting the best!
author: Charlie B.

description: Ummmm...catfish, sweet potatoes, mac n cheese and sweet tea.  If you know what Texas sweet tea is you can get it here.  Everything I had was good.  The guys were really nice behind the counter too.  I brought my Texas BBQin' relatives here and they enjoyed it.
author: Amanda A.

description:
4.5 stars

Every meal I've had here has been enjoyable and well executed.  Today I had an andouille sausage sandwich and Liz had the Memphis style pork (pulled pork) and both were excellent, as were the sides of cole slaw and potato salad.  There really isn't better BBQ to be had in the Bay Area - at least not that I've found.  Having spent 10 years in Texas and 4+ in Tennessee, I've had my fair share of BBQ.  Though I'm fond of a few places in these far away states, my meals at Memphis Minnie's have been pretty close in comparison.  I've sat with the owner for a while discussing BBQ, and can really appreciate his method for learning the technique of the different styles on offer.  He's travelled to all of these areas on several occasions to understand and emmulate them, and I think he does a hell of a job.  My only complaint on this visit was the consistency of the pork - there wasn't quite enough texture.  I like to have some slightly chewy or at least stringy bits in my pulled pork, and this was fairly soft and pillowy.  Perhaps that's what he was going for.  The flavor is pretty spot on, but the smoky intensity of the pulled pork I've had a hunudred times in Nashville and Memphis was also sort of missing.   Ok, I guess that's two things.

The andouille was also very good, the only drawback being that it was overly salty.  It was certainly still edible, and enjoyable, but if the salt were turned down a bit it would have been heavenly (and the heat turned up a tad). 

I have to add that this is the first time I've tried the sambos there, and I was very impressed.  They arrive as just meat and bread, which looks a bit sparse, but with your three choices of BBQ sauce on the table (Texas style (cumin and tomato driven), South Carolina style (mustard base) and North Carolina style (vinegar base)) you're all set.  The bread is a sweet french roll, and very moist and complimentary to the meat.  I was expecting these to be dry, but the whole combo is very enjoyable.  

Try it!
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description:
my ex loved this place.  since im not into bbq, i got the ribs.  theyre pretty damn tasty.  so are the fries.  and the pulled pork sammich.  

be sure to get the sweet tea. and no it's not just reg tea w/ sugar added.  just ask anyone from the south!
author: Dorothy L.

description: I have never been to the South, but this is the best barbeque that I've had in the city.  The staff are friendly, too.
author: Kelvin K.

description: I love the Memphis Sweet Smoked Pork Sandwich! The only thing about most of the meat that I've had here is that it tends to be dry. I end up using a lot of the vinegar and sauce thats on the tables, but it makes the sandwich so good. The Chick is really good too, also a bit dry but when you add the sauce, it's perfect.
author: James E.

description: Pretty good BBQ, also some pretty good sides.   The mustard and the texas red sauce are both really good.   Prices are very reasonable.  I have had better, but given that those places are located in the Central Standard Time Zone I really can't complain.  I am sure I will be eating here again in the future.
author: Alured P.

description: You in the need of BBQ but do not know anybody that is throwing a party or just too lazy to fire up the grill? No problem,  Memphis Minnie's is the place for you.  When you first go in here, you probably notice the awards this place has for best BBQ in the city and to me, their is no lying about that.  We started out with the pork egg rolls and it was pretty damn good.  For the main dish, I had the beef brisket and the pork ribs dipped it with some Carolina Mustard and Texas Red Sauce and you have yourself one good old BBQ.  Parking in the lower haight area is kinda tough so you may have to be patient to get your hands on some good BBQ when you go here.
author: Kris A.

description:
Not very much to look at while walking Haight street, the que here is more than worth the trip through the doors. First you are hit with the delicious smells that fill the smallish dining/kitchen area. Then comes the tough part deciding what to get, recommend trying the sake also, yes it is still weird to me that a BBQ restaurant with Memphis in the name serves sake, it was quite delicious, try one of the samplers if you can't decide.
  Now comes my favorite part the actual food, the ribs are cooked to perfection and fall apart in your mouth. Don't be afraid of the bottles of sauce on the table not sure if these are different around the restaurant we had SC, NC and TX but TX was the hands down favorite with my squad. If you are lucky you ordered some rib tips, spicky pulled chicken, or pulled pork to go along with your ribs, that is if you still have room after hammering a mini-rack of baby back ribs. Taking a back seat to the meat are the sides, I would only get at these if you can't take any more or in my case finish all your que, they were pretty solid, can't really go wrong with southern style mac and cheese.
 Go here, eat, and you decide it hasn't won best BBQ in SF numerous times for nothing... how often will you have ribs, mac&cheese, and sake on purpose.
author: Sean W.

description: Had the "Pulled" Spicy Chicken Sandwich and the BBQ Seasoned Fries. Both were very tasty. Definitely use the sauces they give you on the side for dipping the sandwiches and fries. Yum. Bit pricey - $8 for a sandwich.
author: Erik B.

description: Yah go for the meat. it's amazing. the beef is incredibly tender. The sides aren't the best but then again, you're going for the meat or did you forget already? It's a small place so you end up taking your dinner to go with some last minute changes to your plans. the Staff is very friendly. a great place to go for what? yep you guessed it meat.
author: Pierre C.

description: The brisket and Memphis pork here are both very good.  The sauce is given in separate containers from the meat.  The mustard and vinegar sauces are good, even better when mixed with the hot sauce.  Now for the sides.  The potato salad is much better than standard BBQ joint issue, better than many deli versions I've had.  The greens are quite tasty with a vinegar tang.
author: Scott B.

description: Having grown up in Texas, I am serious about barbecue.  It's pretty good here, probably better than most in the Bay Area.  We got take-out right before closing and the staff was great.  The sausage was pretty good, the brisket was decent.  Sides were so-so.  I only liked the Texas sauce and it was decent.  Was like a shadow of good barbecue.
author: Michelle C.

description: I love Memphis Minnie's! I'm hooked on the spicy chicken sandwich and also love love love the mustard sauce (South Carolina) and spicy-vinegary one (North Carolina). I buy the bottles to go and pour them on everything at home too. :-) It's a fun, kitschy place to grab a bite, but I usually get food to go. This is a "bring a friend who can wait in the car while you double park and run in" kind of situation, since parking is usually impossible.
author: Alexa G.

description:
yum! nom, nom, nom, nom, nom!

must've had on off day since the cornbread we got tasted funny but boy, oh, boy, the briskets made up for it...this place will make a vegeterian succomb to the barbeque!
author: Spooky E.
