description: OK, not amazing.  Maybe I'm too hard to please, BBQ-wise.  Had the pulled chicken BBQ sandwich and mac'n cheese.  Mac'nCheese was not good.  Pastey to say the least.  The chicken was ok. I think the sauces left much to be desired.
author: cece S.

description:
I just moved out of the Lower Haight and this place is one I will certainly miss. I have not tried all items but theSouthern Star combo sandwich (half BBQ brisket, half pork) is amazing. The BBQ fries that come with it too.
I love the ambiance too.
author: Jose C.

description: I'm from Alabama, so I know what good BBQ is all about and this place is as close as you are going to get to real Southern BBQ.  The atmosphere is perfect, the waiters are really personable, and the room is decorated in cute pig decor.  Seating is small, so I recommend going at off hours when there is a better chance of getting a table.  I always get either the BBQ pork platter or the pulled pork sandwich.  The meat has a great flavor and is cooked really well.  They have a variety of different BBQ sauces from different regions of the South, so you have a good selection.  The macaroni and cheese is just about the best I've ever put in my mouth.  I just wish that the serving was a bit bigger.  They put it in a very small little cup.  The fries are really tasty too.  The one thing that really pushed this place over the edge for me is the fact that I can get very good sweet tea here.  I can't find any better in California.
author: Susan F.

description: I love BBQ, I do NOT love Memphis Minnie's. I find the name ironic considered that all the sauces they offer are South Carolina style.  The food was nothing memorable in the slightest.  We order about 4 or 5 different items to get a full idea of the spectrum of the menu. EVERYTHING was dry and tasteless. Our BBQ pork rolls were cold in the center, my side of mac n cheese was cold, and the fries were cold. After I took one bite from everything and after there was nothing I wanted to take another bite of.  It is a lot of hype about crummy food.
author: Alesha K.

description:
LOVE, LOVE, LOVE... this place. crave it and go there again and again. Love the fact that they have great bread and juicy meat. Love that I  can put the sauce if I want, and might not put any sauce at all. It is the place for me since chicken sandwich has  mayo dressing....Love, Love love.
I lived in Oakland for a few years - Had a taste of excellent BBQ still crave Minnies.
Love sake tasting with brisket - may sounds crazy but I feel it is a good fit.
Would recommend brisket, rib tips and  potato salad as my favorites. I enjoy this San Francisco approach to the BBQ.
author: Sashie G.

description: ehhhh. . . I'd heard great things about this place, but was a little disappointed. The food was good, but the sauces - and we know bbq is all about the sauce - were mediocre.
author: Michelle O.

description: They andoullie sausage here is so spicy and greasy, it doesn't get much better than this.  The slow smoked pork is to die for.  And the mustard sauce is unbeatable.  So that is just the best entree's, oh how can I forget the smoked turkey, healthy and delicous.  The sides: collard greens out of this world, if the sweet potatoes have been sitting around for a while in there own juice, they are perfectly mushy.  Great fries as well.  On to dessert, two words, PECAN PIE.  I haven't had pie this good since my mothers, god damn i get exicted just thinking about it.  A great place for a filling meal and all under 20 bucks.
author: brian m.

description: this place sux, the staff has very bad attitude and the sauce is not very good. The ribs and beans were in fact decent, but the beef was not very good or anywhere near bbq. The staff has a problem... very bad service/help. Oh yeah, I am sure there is a sake that could possibly go with bbq, but i drink beer or ice tea with bbq. I went once and will never go back.
author: Burne D.

description: I have been looking for good BBQ in SF for a while.  Memphis Minnie's delivers!  We had the 1/2 pulled pork, 1/2 brisket sandwich.  Throw on a little BBQ sauce and it was just what the Dr. ordered.  My boyfriend had the ribs with beans and fries on the side.  He's a rib connoisseur and he liked it.  His one qualm is that he thought the ribs were reheated.
author: Tory Q.

description: I got the pork ribs and beef brisket with some potatote salad and cold slaw.  The food was mediocre at best.  The meats lack character and was not as tender as I thought it was going to be.  By drenching the meat into the BBQ sauce, I was able to finish my dinner.
author: Moe S.

description: Don't know if it's "real" BBQ. Or, what that even means. Don't know if the right kind of people are making it. Or if this place is too damned cheerful for it's own good.  Seems to be kind of a badge of honor to swear that you know real BBQ and this ain't it (about almost every BBQ in town not just this one). I've eaten BBQ all over the planet. And all I want to know is 1). Does it taste good hence 2). do I want to eat it again? Memphis Minnie's = yes and yes.
author: Michelle B.

description: out of all the adjectives I could use to describe their bbq... I think blah would be most fitting.  The sides were rather tasty.  Seasoned fries is a good choice and I might even return to for the banana pudding.
author: Kirstie R.

description:
chicken was dry, the sauce on the greens was too tangy and overpowering - they tasted pickled, potato salad was comparable to the tub you get at safeway, mac n cheese was tasty, beef ribs were good, pork ribs were by far the best thing, tender and tasty, the corn bread was delicious -  but they should serve it with butter, and the sweet tea was hella good. 

the bbq sauces could have been better. the texas red was good and sweet, mustard was aiight, and the vinegar one was not good

it would have been nice if they had hot sauce available at the tables, and if they served you water. this place tends to get crowded with a lot of white people too.

overall, it was okay, but im looking forward to trying other bbq places in sf before coming back here.
author: erica b.

description:
macaroni and cheese is not exactly the hardest thing to make and make well, but MM seemed to miss the obvious. the mac was liquidy and lacking in cheesiness, and was utterly bland. the cornbread had an odd texture and was dry and grainy. 

i also had the sweet pork and the pork ribs. the sweet pork was kind of dry and probably could have been cooked in a sauce to make it better--like they do in the south. the ribs were overcooked. 

i really wanted my fix of bbq, but i guess i'll have to ask my dad to make me some ribs for the fourth of july. his beat MM by about a thousand times.
author: Stephanie R.

description: Food is up fast; big portions. The sauces really make the meal. The meats aren't made to be enjoyed sauceless.I would recommend going with the two way combo or taster so you get a few meats.
author: Scott F.

description: This place has good Barbeque. The brisket is soft and juicy. It's a small place so I would take it to go. The pulled port was also good. The ribs were not the best. They were okay. They also ran out of stuff while ordering so try to get there a bit early.
author: Larry V.

description:
I shared a mini lunch plate with a friend.
We loved the cole slaw, sweet potatoe and the corn muffin.
I thought the brisket was the best.
The chicken was delicious.
The ribs was a bit dry.
The sweet potatoe pie wasn't too sweet.
I would go back again.
author: Craftylady S.

description: Beggars cannot be choosers, and this place receives high marks mainly because the BBQ scene in San Francisco is very, very limited. However, the mustard based BBQ sauce is quite good and makes for a great gift or souvenir!
author: Dave M.

description: It's all about the meat here; the brisket and the pulled pork are great half the time, disappointing maybe 10% of the time, and frickin transcendental the rest of the time.  Seriously one of my all time favorites of the Bay Area.
author: Dave S.

description:
Their Brisket is their best dish. I recommend this place just for that dish. AND you have to try the beezlebob's hot sauce, it is muy caliente.

Sides are ok. Everything else is ok. Tough to find great bbq in SF. Every place in SF that does BBQ has a specialty....one place for ribs, one place for fried chicken, one place for brisket....Memphis Minnie's for brisket. But don't get me wrong, their food is quality.
author: DT l.

description: Don't get me wrong, the food is fantastic... but their sauces (honey mustard and BBQ) are epic.
author: Roman N.

description:
I had a hard time giving in to the superiority of memphies minnies because I grew up in tennessee.  Memphis Minnies is a postmodern bbq experience.  It's quite a bit different than traditional southern places, and in the end, is more of a combination from many styles of bbq, as well as other styles of cuisine period (like their bbq pork egg rolls).  

Memphis minnies has taken the things I typically don't like at a bbq joint and made them good again.  I am a huge fan of their greens, bbq turkey, macaroni, and of course, sweet tea.  I think the price is pretty reasonable for the portions.  My only complaint is that they don't have a tennessee sauce.
author: Jay G.

description: I've been spoiled by living in Austin and falling in love with Texas brisket, so my expectations run a bit high.  Minnie's was pretty good-- nice crust, tender, if a little on the fatty side.  Their sides were just alright.  Mac n cheese was tasty if a bit too gooey for my liking, and the sweet potatoes were nothing at all.  They literally took a sweet potato, chopped it up, and blanched it for not-long-enough.  The BBQ sauces, both the red TX style and the mustard (Memphis?  Carolina?) style were very good.  I would definitely go back for some brisket, but I'd run w/different sides.
author: sunny d.

description:
Really good barbecue food that comes in large portions. I love barbecue and getting a large food/price portion, so this place meets both of my needs. The barbecue sauces on the table come in 3 different flavors and having lived in each of the three areas, i can attest that they are fairly authentic. 
Very mouthwatering and definitely a place to return when you need that barbecue fix.  The 5th star is missing because it doesn't quite have the down home cooking feel and taste perfected, but with 4 stars, you should go.
author: Greg T.

description: I've eaten here a few time for lunch.  I like the brisket.  It has a good smoky flavor to it, and is much more tender from long smoking than other places around town.  I usually alternate between the mustard and the texas bbq sauces.  The beans are tasty, although I don't go for sweet style greens.
author: John T.

description: Okay, let me preface this by saying that I'm from Georgia and my Fiance is from North Carolina, and we crave southern food from time to time.  So we were thrilled to find a place that served sweet tea!  But we were completely let down.  If you are going to do southern food, do it right.  The sweet tea tasted like it had been sweetened with honey!?  And the sides were all awful.  The greens were way over vinegared and even the mac and cheese (how do ya mess that up?) was blah.  I would love to have a place in the city that was a home away from home for us southerners... but we will not be going back here.  We were very let down.
author: Nica W.

description: YUM!  Their BBQ Beef sandwiches  rock.. the only thing that sux.. is that they run outta fry's sometimes
author: Georgio S.

description:
Great BBQ...love the ribs, rib tips, pork shoulder, andouille sausage & cornbread. Not into the sauce, but sauce is not what BBQ is all about.
I tend to buy by the lb & bring it home.
I go to lots of BBQ places looking for the shit....they have it!
author: neil a.

description: I'm a Bar-b-q addict....and Memphis Minnies hits the spot every time.  Mac and Cheese is Delicioso!!! However...the portions are getting smaller and smaller...What's up with that??!!!
author: Francis T.

description:
hit or miss.

i do know bbq. and when mm is on, their brisket & ribs stand up to the best i've had. 

when they are on!

sometime's, maybe it's busy, maybe it's cranky, maybe it's just that time of the week, month, year, whatever ... they are not on.

but when they are on - whew - it is on baby!
author: Lawrence K.

description:
I've been there twice, and often they are sold out of popular items. The restaurant could use a good cleaning.  Everything is within view, and most surfaces in the kitchen were coated in an inch of burned on grease and grime.The dust and grime clinging to the t-shirts on the walls don't help much either.

The food must be inconsistent, since I read all the reviews I could,before going there, and most people stated that the meat was moist. My brisket was dried out completely. Nearly inedible. I imagine after 18 hours of smoke, it got 18 hours of fridge time. I laugh when I see the reviews that state that this BBQ is better than the big boys in the midwest ( Gates, Arthur Bryants etc.) I don't think this place is consistent enough to be considered in the same league. 

The pork ribs were very good. And the pecan pie is probably the best anyone will ever have. But the pork butt was so bland, flavorless, it was necessary to drown it in bbq sauce just to eat it. I honestly thought it was accidently switched with turkey, cause it had the same mealy texture, and no pork flavor what so ever. It actually had little flavor at all.

Places that take pride in their BBQ usually have a pit man checking on the final product going out. Alot of the brisket that doesn't get sold, either because its too dry or whatever, usually goes into the chili pot. My brisket I had was bone dry. There wasn't anyone doing much for quality control here, and I imagine you only get lucky if you are there when someone pulls some fresh meat out of the smoker. Otherwise the quality goes down from there.
 

The worst thing there was their corn muffins. They had an odd smokiness, not like smoke from the bbq, but smoke from the burned on grease that hasn't been cleaned from the pans in a long time. It actually permeated thrughout the muffin, The thick crunchy bits of corn meal are  odd to chew, but likely up to the individual if they like that sort of thing. 

The mac n cheese was not all that memorable. It had the taste of artificial cheese sauce, with a scoop of that odd corn meal mixed in just to irritate me again

Overall, it was nice to try their ribs. And their pecan pie was worth it, but I dont plan on going back. The parking is horible.
author: T C.

description:
Awesome awesome awesome! Good spot for some quick food. I used to work down by the Hall of Justice and Big Nate's is right around the corner. Now Nate's is legitimate barbecue and well known but God is it overpriced and unsatisfying. 

So we would call down to Memphis Minnie's and order a bunch of sandwiches etc. My favorite by far is the southern star, the brisket is a close second . The pork and chicken is always flavorful and never dry. Fries on the side were never soggy. If you do drop by this place ask for extra red sauce! It's soooo good!
author: Vince F.

description:
I was torn whether to give MM four or five stars, because their barbecue IS delicious AND they have South Carolina mustard sauce--nothing makes me happier. However, they've really been cutting their pork too big for comfort lately, which is a tiny bit sloppy. I think a barbecue sandwich should have pulled pork, not three-inch hunks. 

That said, great flavor, fun atmosphere. Don't forget the fried peach pie!
author: Sarah Y.

description:
First, I really wish there were more choices for ratings...
This is definitely only 3 1/2*
BUT, as far as the bay area so far, and BBQ, it IS 4...
First.... had pretty low hopes, on the basis of YELP ratings (learning to not always trust that!) and the location (super-hip, not generally a good sign for BBQ)
But, the menu looked good, and overall it did not disappoint.
This was carryout, and the hubby picked it up, so can'ts says anything about the place, though he said it looked nice....
Start with the ribs, always the ribs... GOOD to very good... if anything, a bit overcooked (but better than undercooked imho). Flavor, good. Asked for the sauce on the side (finally realized that here in the bay they DROWN bbq in sauce - what are they hiding?!)
Sauce was good, but a bit too sweet, fruity and oddly spiced... but not bad. Can't say the same for the other sauce, the mustardy one.... we didn't like it. Too much like honey mustard dressing.
Next: brisket. Very good, but a bit fatty ( I can't believe I just said that! Fat is SO my friend! But it's true!) tender and good flavor.
Wings - good, but definitely overcooked. Dry, dry, dry... not easy do that to wings, either!
So, the sides: Potato salad was 3* easily. Coleslaw was NOT what I wanted (like it creamy) but it was GREAT, if a bit on the sweet side (like everything). Well, 3 1/2* for sure. Fries...Surprisingly good! 3 1/2*.
corn muffins: too sweet, but actually very corny! 3 1/2*.... I sense a trend with this 3 1/2* thing!
So, all in all, Memphis Minnie would warrant a return! For sure... And I could easily be persuaded to LOVE this place, if it were a little less sweet! :)
author: Vincent D.

description:
The line was long, but the ribs were worth the wait.  Small place with a cow decoration theme throughout.  We were there with a group of 7 but we managed to find a table to squeeze into all together.  I had the St. Louis Pork Ribs, with the mac 'n' cheese and sweet potato sides.  A couple of my friends had the brisket and said it was a bit dry. 

This place didn't really blow my mind like E&J in Oakland did years ago, but I will say this... 6 out of the 7 of us had the "Hot Sauce" that was supposed to be "stupid hot", and when we got back to the house, 6 out of 7 of us waited patiently for our turn on the bathroom rotation.  I don't think I've ever seen a bathroom occupied for 2 hours straight like that before. Bad times.
author: J M.

description:
My favorite BBQ place in the city!   I still stop by here after work even though I've moved out of the Fog.  Anyone who doesn't like this place doesn't know a thing about BBQ, or is secretly a vegatarian trying to spoil BBQ places in general for us carnivores.  The brisket is definitely the best, but the pulled chicken is great too.  I just coat my entire plate in a mixture of the three sauces and go to town.

Sectertly delicious menu item: the wings!  Yes, it may sound wierd ordering wings at a BBQ joint, but trust me they are great.

AND, you can take this great BBQ into a great beer hall, Toronado, right across the street.
author: James G.

description: Some of the best BBQ in the city.  I love the beef brisket there.  So much flavor in just the meat, and with either the red or the mustard sauce, good, just good.  And the french fries are good too!
author: Shane Y.

description: HORRIBLE FOOD POISONING. Beware.  I ate at Memphis Minnie's and became horrible sick with food poisoning, had the side of mac n cheese and a pork and beef sandwich.  I called the manager the next day and I quote, "never had a complaint in 3 years."  He never asked me what I ate what date, didn't seem to even care.  I ate there with my girlfriend January 2011.  NEVER AGAIN. PLEASE BEWARE.  I also called and left messages with the SF Public Health Department, to report the food poisoning.  If I could give it zero stars I would
author: James M.

description:
One word - disappointing. I love BBQ and after reading some of the stellar reviews I was really anticipating indulging at Memphis Minnies.  Four of us went and ordered a variety of items. Everything but the brisket was dry and tasteless. My daughter ordered the ribs which were so tough and dry she refused to eat them. I had ordered the sweet pork which was equally dry.  The fries and mac n cheese were cold.The slaw was good but hey I didn't go there for slaw. 
There are plenty of joints offering succulant BBQ. I won't be coming back here.
author: Shelley M.

description: This is my favorite place to eat...in the whole freaking world.  Get the Brisket sandwich with a side of Mac'n Cheese.
author: mundavelli d.

description:
I've lived across from this place for about a year and finally ate there a few weeks back. Let's just say that I was not impressed. The establishment felt a little bit unclean (as is the rest of Lower Haight, go figure). The workers were friendly, and suggested I order the briskett sandwich...so I did. 

I ordered my meal to go and when it was ready I snatched it up, coated it in several of their sauces and ran out the door. It smelled great soI assumed that nothing could ruin this meal. Upon my first bite into it, I knew something wasn't quite right. The bread was dry, not sweet and moldy or anything, but seemed like it had been frozen and thawed via microwave. How dissapointing. The meat was also incredibly dry. Not cool. The fries, limp and greasy.

I went back downstairs to address the issue at hand and they were closed. So wha did I do? I gave the sandwich to the homeless guy who stays in front of my place. I guarantee you'll see this guy if you come to Lower Haight, he's a staple here in this neighborhood. 

Anyway, would I reccomend Memphis Minnies? Hmm....if they kept fresh bread on hand and didn't overcook their briskett, possibly. I'm sick of justifying to myself the dismal condition of the San Francisco restaurants. Clean the restaurants thouroughly on a daily basis and it won't be a problem. Yellowing dusty t-shirts on greasy walls is not cool.
author: Drew G.

description:
The wait for the table and then for the food made my trip to Minnie's one to forget.

The food itself is on the pricey and the portions are barely  adequate for the average appetite. Overated -- goto E&J instead
author: Jason L.

description: I'd been seriously craving some bbq since moving to SF, and have been searching for a decent Southern-style restaurant for the past several months.  I finally tried Memphis Minnie's this past weekend, and it did a good job of quelling my meat needs, but it doesn't compete with real bbq.  I got a combo of the pulled pork and brisket, and while the pork was tasty, my piece of brisket was almost all fat, and therefore chewy.  Very tasty sides, and the corn muffin was good.
author: GeneR S.

description: When the cut is right they have the best brisket I've ever had... hmmm! Also, the smoked pork egg rolls are my favorite comfort food. Strangely, I hate mayonaise and was dumbfounded to hear that the sauce for the eggrolls was about 80% mayo... the balance of flavors is beautiful!!! side a bean please...
author: David S.

description:
Oh my how you have fallen.  

How I was so excited in the early days when you first opened for great BBQ.  Over the past years the weekend brunches were a great treat.  It was always a place I took out of town guests, lunch or dinner.

But no more. 

Over the past year it has been hit or miss..quality has gone noticeably down.  Meats are dry.  Sauces just not the same. Corn bread over baked.   I have overlooked the swings chalking it up to staff differences, but what will keep me away is the recent chicken sandwich I was served.  It was full of gristle with hints of rotten meat.  Bad meat - unforgivable. 

Bob - you need to get back into this kitchen.   A SF great is very sick.
author: D S.

description: I'm not a bbq master in any way but I know good brisket when I taste it. Along with the turkey on the weekends with mac and cheese and baked beans make a perfect meaty meal after a hard day at work. If you can take it to go I recommend that over eating there. While it's a fun experience eating shoulder to shoulder to your neighbor I prefer to stretch out and enjoy food like this. Aside form that, the atmosphere is entertaining while you wait for your food and the music is always spot on. Also, I've had a few of those extra dry corn muffins but that hardly sours the experience just use it to sop up the extra red sauce.
author: greg j.

description: I ordered the beef and pork bbq dinners with greens and mac n' cheese.  Everything was good enough, but nothing amazed me.  Parking in this neighborhood is difficult and it would be great if they had a curbside take-out service
author: V T.

description: First impressions; the guy running the register was very friendly, and didn't rush my boyfriend and I while we asked him for recommendations, even though the line was long.  I also noticed that he made a point of making sure all of his customers had a place to sit as quickly as possible, since the place was packed... that was really nice.  My only complaint is that I was given a Tri Tip sandwich instead of the Minnie's Pastrami (their Wednesday special), and I didn't know until I got home with our to-go order.  The food was nonetheless delicious! My man got a half pound of pork ribs, we shared a large order of seasoned fries, and the tart-n-tangy slaw was particularly impressive.  I would definitely recommend this joint for some good BBQ, just make sure you get what you ordered!
author: Ashley D.

description: After hearing and reading such good reviews I was expecting a lot better. My friend and I drove all the way over from Oakland for, what we thought was going to be a special treat. I had the pulled spicy chicken sandwich which had good flavor but it was not warmed all the way through. The mac & cheese was halfway decent. The greens sucked! The corn muffin was too coarse! The sweet potatoes were tasteless. The fried peach pie wasn't very tasty and wasn't heated throughout. My friend had the rib tips and brisket. Some of the rib tips were overcooked and dry. The bbq sauce selection was just strange....I'm not even sure what to say about it. I'm glad they have the Haight street inhabitants fooled into thinking that they know anything about bbq and soulfood. I've traveled all over the country and had all types of bbq. This definitely isn't anyplace I would go back to. I'll stick with the bbq and soulfood that I can find in Oakland and save myself a $4 toll.
author: Tiffany N.

description: you whiny californians need to tighten up yer diapies,face it,you know nothing  of  southern  barbeque.sister neeleys the only one in the state do que right,and memphis minnies as well.you aint never put no south in yer mouth if you dissin either.just like to whine and put forth your so called understanding of something you know nothing about.
author: eamonn d.

description:
EEks!!  I think there was more fat on my brisket than meat!!  And I felt like a German SHepard trying to tear the meat off my ribs!!.  Yes they were that tough  Sauce was'nt half bad.  The beans tasted like they were out of the can!!

And would it kill the cashier to smile?!!  Not one thank you!  It's almost like they could care less we were there.  Don't worry, they won't see me THERE again
author: Mick B.

description: I make special trips to SF just to have their fare, especially with the vinegar-y sauce that is so hard to find this side of the Carolinas. One of SF's highlights, and an easy walk from the Duboce Park stop of the N-Judah.
author: douglas s.

description:
Well this seems to be really a you-mileage-may-very kind of place, so put me in the fan camp. 

I found the ribs to be tender and flavorful, and the brisket cuts with a fork and melts in my mouth, my fav is the tri-tips. Don't really like their regular barbque sauce, but the other two flavors are great. I like the corn muffins i have gotten were good but they cook them in bulk and I can see them getting dry sometimes. The mac and cheese is great, the greens are good, as is the potato salad.
author: Brian C.

description:
Heard about all of the raves about Memphis Minnie's from various sources, so decided to go there after work and bring some barbeque home.

I ordered the 3 way - pork ribs, chicken and cajun andouille sausage with mac & cheese and bbq beans; 2 way - pork ribs and chicken with mac & cheese and cole slaw; small side order of cajun fries.

The pork ribs and white meat chicken were dry.  Mac & cheese was okay.  I liked the cole slaw and beans.  I watched the guy make the cajun fries.  Its just thin cut fries and after they were fried, the guy pour a generous amount of seasoning over them and tossed which I would think was probably cajun seasoning.  The fries were overcooked unless you like crunchy fries and had no real flavor.  I told my hubby dip them in the bbq sauce.

What's up with the corn muffin.  Is this a southern thing?  The corn meal wasn't grounded very fine, so there are hard grains in the muffin.

The guy who took my order was very nice and friendly and there was a line of people when I left.  Anyways, tried it, been there... no rush to go back!
author: M. K.

description: I think Yelp reviews should be based on in-city comparisons, hence the four-star rating. I don't think it's quite fair to compare BBQ in a health-conscious state like CA and an even healthier city like San Francisco to (no offense) TX/the South. But Memphis Minnie's is good, for SF. I was a little wary because I'm not a fan of pork and was worried that MM, with a pig as its mascot and Memphis in its name, would only serve pork BBQ. But boy, was I wrong! The menu is diverse, from Andouille sausage (BBQ isn't BBQ without sausage, folks) to chicken to beef brisket to meat by the pound. You aren't allowed to sit before you order but turnover is pretty fast. I would recommend the sweet iced tea - it wasn't too watery or too sweet. I sneaked peeks and what others ordered and the amount of food you get is pretty big for the price. The Boyfriend and I shared the Taster (two or three choices of meat with two sides and a cornbread muffin) and there was no way one person, unless very large or starving, can finish all of that. We had beef brisket, St. Louis cut ribs, Andouille sausage, sweet potatoes and BBQ fries. My favorite was the sausage. The brisket wasn't the best I've had but quite decent. The ribs were tender but a little bland. That's where the sauces come in -  you have your choice of four sauces: Texas red sauce, mustard sauce, vinegar sauce and hot sauce. The hot sauce is located on the counter directly to the right of the register (from your perspective, not the cashier's). There are little cups in which to pour some in and take back to your seat. I liked mixing the Texas red mixed with the hot sauce. Don't be deceived! The first taste of the sauce is very bland with no kick but give it a bit and it'll hit your mouth. I very much wanted to try the pecan pie but was just too full at the end of the meal. I'll update this review next time with the pie.
author: Christine P.

description: I really wanted to like this place.  The divey atmosphere, the grande texan workers flipping the meat, the excessive pig paraphernalia apparently wasn't enough to sway my opinion of the food.  We had the meat sampler w/ ribs, brisket, and sausage w/ mac n cheese and cornbread.  I didn't like any of the meats.  The sides were ok.  I won't be coming back.  SF seriously is in dire need of decent bbq places.
author: LT B.

description: i like this place ok. i want to like it more, but there is so much better out there. namely rockland's bbq in DC, mmm... anyways, i like the tri-tip here. the brisket is ok. the sides are ok. fries are pretty good, greens and mac'n'cheese are meh. 5 stars for character.
author: Kate A.

description: I've been here twice.  The first time was horrible, but I thought that maybe they were just having an off day.  Both times, service was nice.  I got their smoked ribs the first time.  The second time, I got a sampler plate with the smoked ribs, rib tips, and brisket with a side of slaw and mac n cheese.  After giving Memphis Minnie's another chance, I would only come back if my taste buds changed to like bland, re-heated food.
author: Trinh N.

description: i'm glad i finally made it to memphis minnie's. i had the brisket sandwich, my wife and our friend the pork sandwich, and a rib tip appetizer. i liked them all. i probably wouldn't order the brisket again as it is fatty. but the non fatty pieces were good with a good smokey taste. the pork was excellent and the rib tip appetizer smoked to well done with crispy edges. the rolls they use are carved out a bit so you aren't eating a lot of bread and taste good. loved it. also all three sauces at the tables were tasty and they have a hot sauce bottle at the counter to add to the others or have alone that was pretty hot. loved the sauces. i'll be back. the smell alone makes me want more.
author: roger b.

description: I love this place!  First off, I grew up with sweet tea in my veins.  Moving out to Cali was prolly good for prolonging when I get diabetes b/c I no longer have to specify if I want it regular or unsweetened.  The first through maybe 7th times I came here I got the 18 hours smoked Beef Brisket.  Holy smokes is it smokey.  I swear I thought I could see smoke coming up in burps for like half a day after eating it.  Really, all the meats are done amazingly well.  The sliced pork shoulder and baby backs are moist and tasty.  All the sides are killer too.  Bread-crumbed mac-n-cheese, pot-likker greens, corn bread and french fries.  My only complaint is that their "baked beans" are more like chili than the molasses and bacon fatty ones I grew up with in the South.  About a year ago they started doing a Southern brunch on weekends too.  This is a meal not to be missed.  Low-country shrimp and grits and beef brisket chili hash just to name the ones I can't manage to go beyond b/c they rock so hard.  Wash it all down with some sweet tea and you are in heaven!
author: Chard M.

description: After traveling through Memphis on a food tour, I have to say that Memphis Minnie's is a far cry from real, authentic Southern bbq. Not to mention that the prices are probably double what you would pay if you were actually in the deep South. That being said, the food is fairly decent for the city, although if you are craving something a tad more authentic, just venture out a little farther and go to Everett & Jones (the original one) in Berkeley.
author: Michele L.

description: I just had the most disgusting lunch in probably the last 10 years.  It was at Memphis Minnie's.  The ribs were dry and tasteless, the greens tasted like straight vinegar, and the cornbread was like a rock.  It was like reno buffet bbq.  Oh yeah, and it was $16.  I got a candy bar at walgreens to get rid of the vile taste in my mouth.  Yuck!!!!
author: Cody R.

description: Decent food.  Nothing spectacular, and a tad pricey.   Probably wouldn't make much of a splash in a town that was more into great BBQ.
author: Brandyn B.

description: sorry guys, i'm from memphis and this place shouldn't have the name of my city in the title. it's not that it's gross (although i did feel sick afterwards). it's just not memphis style bbq at all-- more of a carolina sauce. i gotta stick up for the hood...
author: sarah l.

description: People who think BBQ needs to be drenched in sauce are amateurs who don't know a damn thing about real barbecue.  Real barbecue is all about how you cook and dry-season the meat.  This place has amazing dry-rub barbecue.  I always get the pulled pork or the ribs, although the brisket is super tender.  The sauces are awesome and distinctive, although the meat is delicious enough to be eaten by itself (as it should be.)  The mac and cheese with bread crumbs in it is tasty enough to be its own meal.  Best tasting BBQ in the city, but 4 stars because it's slightly overpriced.  (But not enough to stop me from eating there when I'm in the neighborhood.)
author: Jim F.

description: I heard about this place on television so I decided to take my dad there for father's day yesterday. HE doesn't like fancy restaurants for father's day so this was GREAT. Reasonable prices, cozy and warm environment nestled in the far part of Haight Street. I ordered their smoked cajun andouille sausage with a side of macaroni and cheese along with their famous pit smoked  beans. The macaroni and cheese was good, but it wasn't really cheesy, it had clumps of bread or  something in it which wasn't good. My parents both ordered the rib tip plate with a side of fries and pit smoked beans. I sampled it, it was OK.
author: Sina H.

description: Got the ribs and chicken to go.  Absolutely no complaints.   Good smoke ring on both, tender, succulent.  Would give 5 stars, but need to sample more items on the menu.  As to people complaining about the prices, this is SF . . . .
author: Happy C.

description: Grabbed lunch here for the first time and was immediately captured by the smell of  BBQ walking from a block away.  The place was packed full of people, and was unsure if we were going to nab a table.  I ordered their Southern Star with a side of Mac and Cheese.  Standing in line, my friends and I thought we'd have enough time to find an open table.  If you're eating in, it turns out they won't serve you your food until you've secured a seat.  Well... something happened where we got our food quickly, to find no available seats.  Not only were they politely apologetic, they proactively offered us some free food for their error.  I would've been fine with eating on the curb outside, but the gesture was greatly appreciated.  Ultimately, they were able to open up some tables for us.  The food was great, even better when you throw in the additional sauces they have readily available on the tables.  I definitely plan on revisiting this place!
author: R B.

description: If you're looking for good, fast BBQ, this is the place to come.  Their pork and chicken are delicious, as is their mac n' cheese.  A bit pricey for some dishes, but definitely comforting when you're in need of some comfort food!
author: Ive M.

description: no longer my favorite because i prefer baby blues BBQ in the mission but still very good
author: Deka M.

description: Very disappointing.  The operative word here is dry.  Four of us went, so we got four different meats--  brisket, pulled pork, chicken and tri-tip.  All dry as a bone.  The cole slaw was really good.
author: Nat M.

description: I looked up this place before we went there and read some of the reviews, don't know why we still went there.  I love bbq and was looking for a memorable meal before leaving Frisco and heading back to LA. It was memorable all right.......terrible!! The big guy behind the counter makes stupid jokes while you order and semi insults you. All the people there must have been scared of him and just smiled. I checked him...........and all was cool but the food still sucks. I had the brisket...........average, the mac 'n' cheese was overcooked and below average........the bbq beans were sour. My wife had the chicken and it was ok but the rest of her meal sucked too.  My meal left a bad taste in my mouth all the way back to LA. The best part of my meal was the soda.........fill in the blanks. Don't waste your money here.......not everything in the Haight/Ashbury district is good. This place charges Frisco prices for sub-par food.
author: Ed M.

description: Since I decided that my yelp moniker would be "estranged southern belle", I thought it only appropriate to write my first review on a TRUE Southern BBQ joint.  Hailing from Alabama (if you're ever there : Dreamland. You'll never have better ribs.), I'm highly suspect of BBQ places north of the Mason-Dixon line or West of the Mississippi...especially in San Francisco. That said... Memphis Minnie's is amazing.  Its enitre menu is a refreshing taste of home for any Southerner.  And it's an honest sample for anyone who isn't willing to travel 3000 miles for the original.  The first time I wandered in (skeptically), I chatted with the owner.  *Good sign of hospitality--and boding well for a good meal to come--he is always around the restaurant, checking to make sure his diners are satisfied.     I highly recommend the "melt-in-your-mouth" pulled pork and the tangy cole slaw (vinegar-based, not mayo).  And if you're not familiar with the 3 different kinds of sauce provided at the table : MIX 'EM!  All 3 tastes go really well together and you can never have too much sauce!  Go with banana pudding to finish off the meal.  The cornbread does tend to be a little dry, but overall I love it, and drop in fairly regularly to remedy both hunger and homesickness.
author: Alexis B.

description: my husband is from georgia so he comes from a long line of bbq lovers.  these guys can pull it off.  we love the brisket and the combo plates.  the sides are excellent, especially the mac 'n cheese....mmmmm.   and we love the bbq pork rolls and fried cheese grit sticks.   the fried peach pie is awesome too.  oh and they have the real deal: sweet tea!   had brunch here recently...pain perdue was tasty.  chicken hash was so-so.  and yeah, i know.  it's all soooo not good for you but it's really yummy and they're super friendly there too!  try the sake!  and ask about the "bluegrass metal" cd they like to play.
author: Cyn B.

description: happiness is a pile of wood and a pig. that's what the t-shirt  hanging on the wall says and it's pretty accurate when lunch is served here. but don't forget the beef brisket. tender and juicy and just the right amount of smoke flavor. the pulled pork shoulder that was served to me was way too fatty and just a pile of mess. it was way too difficult to find meat in this pile of fat. big disappointment, since this was a recommended meat dish. the pork ribs were meaty and savory. smoked chicken = too dry. smoked Cajun andouille sausage was tasty. don't bother with the mac and cheese (mushy pasta and not much taste); but do try the Texas beef brisket chili! spicy and good use of the tasty brisket. the deep south sweet potatoes were tasty too. this review needs to mention the three different house BBQ sauces offered. my personal favorite is the Texas red- savory not too sweet or thick and very tasty. the North Carolina vinegar sauce is good especially to cut some of the grease of the bbq meats and the mustard sauce is an acquired taste but good. my favorite decoration was the large bucket of lard can sitting right on top of the Bunn sweet tea beverage dispenser. I was too afraid to ask if they use lard here for any cooking, but it was a pleasant retro artifact either way. JYW says "check it out."
author: Jeff W.

description: sure satisfied my BBQ craving!  yum on the sweet potatoes, the mac&cheese and corn bread.  super fast service, decent prices...get your grub on here.
author: Lily C.

description: When we went the line was out the door and service is counter style ordering. If you can snag a seat you are lucky as it is pretty much standing room for all who order and a thin line of tables along one side of this narrow restaurant.  The food is good for the money and there were a variety of BBQ sauces and condiments. The deep friend peach and pecan pie are pretty decent. The beef brisket is good but a little dry.  The ribs are not impressive to me. My fries were very well seasoned but a little limp. A  place for BBQ but not for service or atmosphere. Definitely a good  choice for take-out in the future.
author: Jamie C.

description: the meat is quite alright but the sauces could use more work.  in my opinion you can judge a bbq place based on their sauce and for me, this place uses way too much vinegar in their sauce.
author: Swarup B.

description: go with friends and order by the pound. ribs. brisket. get the sweet tea. and a side of fries - they're seasoned and perfectly fried. i like the grit sticks but that might just be me. are you still reading this review? go already!
author: Kevin C.

description: About as close to authentic barbecue as you can get in California. A bit pricey for what you get, but the food is great... As a former North Carolinian, their pulled pork with vinegar brings back wonderful memories of eastern carolina barbecue.
author: Michael H.

description: to be honest this spot is my least favorite of the SF bbq spots food wise. i feel the portions are small and that the food just isnt all its cracked up to be. but the place for sure has a fun atmosphere and the people who work there are very friendly.
author: Andrew D.

description: So far, I've only had an andouille sausage sandwich and the brisket as main dishes on two different occasions and personally I have to say that both were excellent. I actually liked the fact that the brisket was served dry because often barbecue joints dump way too much sauce on the plate to the point were it drowns out the natural smoked meat flavour and/or disguises the inferiority of the meat. Plus, they had a half dozen different styles of homemade sauce (including mustard, vinegar, and a sauce that was is supposed to be insanely hot but didn't really make me tear up until after about 6 tablespoons) on the table that I had fun mixing up different combinations of them on my plate. The brisket was so tender that I had a hard time keeping it on my fork. The mac and cheese and potato salad side dishes are seasoned and prepared with the same dedication as these their succulent, slow cooked barbecue.  The cornbread was moist and tasty without tasting too sugary like cake.  My only caveats would be their prices and the small portions of the side dishes; barbecue is historically inexpensive food and after spending about $18 on an entree, two side dishes, and a soft drink, I would at least expect the sides to come in breakfast cereal-size bowls instead of small cups that are more suitable for holding condiments. However, with the love that I've tasted in this food, I am intrigued enough to go back and sample the rest of the menu.
author: Rick E.

description: Smoked cajun andouille sausage, memphis sweet smoked pork, pit smoked beans, deep south sweet potatoes = Awesome, great, great, great.
author: Jason H.

description: while the meat was tender enough, the "smoked pork sandwich" wasn't very smoky at all (nor was it even salty enough).  in fact, the sandwich was so unsmoky that i think it actually sucked any existing smoke OUT OF MY LUNGS to fill in the vacuum where there was supposed to be smoke.  but perhaps i judge too quickly based on a poor sandwich.  next time (if there is a next time), i will try some proper barbeque menu items like the brisket or ribs.
author: Katherine K.

description: brisket, beef ribs, corn muffins, and mac and cheese. just a few of my favorite things from here, actually it's the only things i get here. everything is very good, the brisket is tender and melts in your mouth and corn muffins have that slight crunch when biting into them, and moist inside. the three sauces they have at each table are very distinct to each region. i cant say i been to each region and tried the real deal because i haven't, but they each is very different, distinct, and good.
author: Victor W.

description: the bbq is very tasty.  the sauce could use a little more texture, but it's still damn good!
author: Jill k.

description: I can't say that I ever really tried beef brisket...but when I saw this was #14 on the sf list of 100 things to try before you die, I had to try it.  Being that my other 1/2 is from the south I figured he'd be a good judge anyhow.  It was pretty crowded for a weeknight @ 8pm.  In fact, there was only 1 table left and the line to order was 4 deep but it went quickly.  I ordered a 2 way plate w/ beef brisket  & sweet pork.  With a plate you get  a cornbread muffin-soo good, and a choice of 2 sides.  I chose the mac & cheese and southern fries or something like that.  They call your order for pick up within mins of ordering.  Everything was REALLY good.  And the boy thought it was pretty close to the real, authentic thing.  Next time I'd probably try something else or just order the beef brisket plate.  I did feel it was a bit pricey - for 2 plates although I ordered a 2 way, and 2 beers = $48.   I still give it my thumbs up.
author: Meredith K.

description: This Bar b Que is super expensive! $35 plus dollars for small portions of meat (chicken, sausage, brisket); three small sides (cole slaw, beans, sweet potatoes) and ONE corn bread! The meat was very bland; however it was tender! The sides were not so good either. The beans had no seasoning; the sweet potatoes were hard and were NOT sweet--what happened to southern type of sweet potatoes that are usually SWEET. And ONE cornbread! I couldn't get over this one "ONE" piece of cornbread for a meal that was supposed to serve up to 3 people!  One look at the cole slaw, and I decided not to even try it! It didn't look too good. Besides the unappealing food, the customer service was not so good either. I stood and waited while they chatted with another customer who had already ate. The finally took my order! This was not very professional even for a place of business that is a dive! I won't be going back
author: Violet J.

description: great southern bbq. order the brisket; you'll thank me later. and the best mac & cheese i've had since i was 4 and i remember eating mac & cheese.
author: Dean E.

description: Everett & Jones in Oakland still gets my vote for ultimate BBQ brisket but Minnie's cooks up some mean meat too. I also the pleasure of sampling their pecan pie which was semi-sweet -- not how I like my women (who wants a semi-sweet woman??) but definitely how I like my pecan pie.
author: Salil A.

description: Yum!  I am not a BBQ expert and I do not know the difference between this BBQ and that BBQ.  What I do know is that Memphis Minnie's is tasty!
author: Kris B.

description:
good
- decent BBQ for SF (I know, that's not saying much... but it's better than having to live in Texas)
- my usual is the two-way combo with brisket & St. Louis ribs, with the beans (with nice bits o' meat!) and mac & cheese
- you can never go wrong with sweet potato pie for dessert
- try the crazy hot sauce

bad
- the chicken was a little dry
- I didn't love the slaw
author: Anthony W.

description:
There was nothing right with this place.  Just the beer selection, which was acceptable.
This falls under the dry bbq category, with the sauces on the table for you to pick.  So you're thinking ok, this might bring my sorry a$$ ribs back to life.  Except all the sauces were terrible.  The mustard sauce tasted like heinz yellow mustard, the vinegar sauce was just straight up vinegar, the tomato based sauce tasted like leftover indian food, and the hot one was way too hot to taste anything else.  So now you're debating whether dry chewy bland meat is a better bet than the sauce alternative.  So you try the baked beans, just to find they're undercooked.  So you go for the hardest thing to mess up, the potato salad, and guess what, those were undercooked too !
$20 bucks for bad food and rude service - congratulations, you made it on the FT List: F*** That.  Go to Big Nate's, they will hook you up.
author: Mattman J.

description: mediocre service. really good food, collard greens notwithstanding (why all the vinegar?)
author: Mr G.

description: every now and then, this place hits the spot like none other.  their sauces are great.  sf needs more great bbq places.
author: Tim G.

description: Hole in the Wall BBQ at its finest. Its reputation definitely proceeds itself in most City circles. This is going to be the closest thing to true BBQ that the City has to offer, just expect to pay City prices. The food is good in my opinion but there are better BBQ places throughout the Bay Area (See Big Nates or E&J in Oakland). The cornbread muffins are a little dry if you don't get them fresh from the oven (which is rare). One perks of this place is the variety of sauces you can use to spice up our choices (This is really a true sign of  a good BBQ joint in more historically significnt BBQ areas of this country). Beware of the Super Hot Sauce though, it will put a hole in the side of your mouth (among creating other problems) if you don't use it sparingly. The biggest problem here is the seating. There really is no room for a large party or any party of more than four people (I really recommend parties of two max). Parking is a problem as well which is why its best to send someone in with the order, circle the block for a few minutes and then take it home. They take credit cards too which always makes things easier.
author: Ryan M.

description: Easily the best brisket in SF proper. The greens have a fruity flavor that I love but it's not to everyone's taste.
author: Josh B.

description:
Alright, since moving to San Francisco, one of my main food goals has been to find a bbq restaurant that could hold up to what I know as good (half my family is from the south, so I'm pretty damn picky). And, for a while, Memphis Minnies did this for me. The meats are always cooked just right, the sides are excellent, the sauce options let you have some fun, the fries are seasoned well, and even sweet tea!! 
The first night I attempted this dining establishment, this was my experience: the food was good, the person at the register was kind and answered our questions and even joked around with us (I think he was the owner). I thought I had found my place.
But. I went in a couple weeks later, on a Sunday, and had an experience to just knock the good one over. The food was still good, and arrived quickly, but the man at the counter WAS AWFUL. He rushed us through ordering, was rude to every customer in the restaurant, and even put his own staff on edge. There was no pleasant chitchat, but a tense, whispering silence, not only among those working, but hovering over the customers as well. Several people walked out before ordering as a result of his attitude and demeanor. We finished our meals quickly and thought, "hey, maybe he was having a bad night, we'll give it another try next week."
And I did, I brought my mother, who was in town visiting, after she had driven four hours or so through stop and go traffic. I thought this would provide us with the cozy atmosphere I remembered from my first night. EXACTLY THE OPPOSITE. The same man was working the register, and he was just as bad, if not worse. The situation was so stressful and unpleasant that we ended up leaving before our meals were finished. Several people walked out, mid-meal or before ordering. One group even canceled their orders. 
I glanced through reviews and didn't see anything similar to my experience, and was wondering if others had encountered this as well. Memphis Minnie's could be a perfectly decent bay area bbq restaurant, but it won't be getting my business until some serious customer service work is done.
author: Brittany B.

description:
after reading a review from yelp...i decided to visit here with a friend.  the place is easy to spot b/c it's painted in red.  when we went inside....i was little bit taken back....and almost walked out.  the place is tiny and it's down right hole in the wall. me being from atlanta, i've been to some hole in the wall places but this place beats them all.  i stayed and ordered brisket sandwich with mac & cheese and my friend ordered brisket sandwich with french fries.  the sandwich was a good sized and it was actually very good.  the brisket was sliced and not chopped so i was happy with the style (some places are chopped even in atlanta).  flavor was definitely there (smokey but not over powering).  there are 4 sauces and i tried all of them.  if u like vinagar base sauces u will like it.  i just don't like vinagar base.  there was a spicy one that i liked but it really burns ur tongue so be careful.  the mac & cheese? hmmm....comes in a little cup  and it looks horrible visually.  it's very runny.  but once u take a bite to it....it wasn't bad.  it wasn't excellent by any means but it was good.  my friend's seasoned french fries was better way to go.  it was very good.  

overall, i enjoyed my experience there.  it was good food and it was cheap...$24 for 2 brisket sandwich with one side each and two soft drinks...not bad.  would i go back there? hell yeah!!!
author: donald c.

description: Went here after reading my old friend Alexis B.'s review. The cab ride ($25) may have cost as much as the food ($23), but it was well worth the trip. Probably the best BBQ I've had in the city (definitely better than Nate's although I hear great things about the Houston's ribs). Had the tri-tip and ribs, both excellent. Sauces were all good and the mac n cheese was legit. Cornbread was mediocre (as noted elsewhere) but the banana pudding is worth getting if you have room (and maybe even if you don't). Will definitely head back next time I find someone with a car
author: Pfeif E.

description: This place is decent and does not live up to the heavy hype. I had the BBQ chicken plate and it wasn't as smokey and juicy as I had hoped. Without the sauces (which I thought were watery), the chicken was dry and tasteless. The corn muffin was also dry and a little hard and the greens were nothing to write home about. I'm not that picky of a BBQ eater and I honestly found it to be just an ok joint.
author: Mama L.

description: my friend told me about this place and have gone back multiple times for a quick fix on my bbq cravings.  i always order their ribs w/ mac & cheese, seasoned fries and corn bread.  oh and their spicy bbq sauce is awesome... taste explodes in your mouth!!!  i also love their banana pudding!!!  A MUST HAVE!!!
author: Kae B.

description: Excellent food, good sauces, seating is a little limited.
author: Arlo J.

description: i go to this place at least once a week. cant go wrong with the tri-tip steak sandwich.  staff is extremely prompt and friendly! you guys are dope!!!!
author: Tony P.

description: good eats! besides the meat, try the bbq fries
author: anette d.

description: I am so glad that not everyone has been duped into thinking MM is the best BBQ west of the Mississippi. For some reason, all of my friends love this place. Maybe it's because I'm from Texas so I'm a BBQ snob, but this place is...meh. They charge a lot and give you like 3 ribs. The BBQ sauce is bland. The meat kind of tender but I've had better. It's true there's not great BBQ in the bay area...although there's a pretty good place up in Tahoe...
author: Luke F.

description: i'm from ny, so i don't know what "real" bbq is, but i know that every thing at memphis minnies rocks!  the best mac and cheese ever!  and it has mustard in it, and i HATE mustard.  beef ribs, pork ribs, brisket, pulled pork, chicken, fried catfish, all delish.
author: eeeee d.

description: Great meats and side dishes, but the portions were too small for the price. I had the beef brisket at 15 bucks and a only received 4 small slices. The sides are small as well. The meal did include 1 small cornbread muffin though. In a nutshell- Great meat and sides, small portions, very little seating, overpriced,  smart-assed staff in my experience.
author: doug j.

description: memphis rocks. the pulled pork is amazing along with the brisket. other great things are the fries, cornbread and dont forget the mac and cheese, it's off the mantle. get yourself some minnies and dont forget the texas red sauce....ahhhhhh heartburn.
author: Chris R.

description: this be fine southern cookin. is worth driving to from the Town? hmmm helll yaaaa.
author: Adriano M.

description: The sauces are really good, but the meats tend to the mediocre.  Perhaps mediocre is too strong a word, but for the price, I was hoping for something better.  Brother-in-law is cheaper and tastier.
author: Michael L.

description: I'm a big BBQ brisket fan. Connosieur if you will. Memphis usually has outstanding brisket. However I have gotten some that's more fatty than usual.  But 75% of the time the brisket is excellent. When I get the excellent stuff it's 5 stars all the way. But I'm giving them 3 stars because of their inconsistency.I don't know about their other BBQ offerings. I always stick with the brisket.
author: David L.

description: I'm not from the south, nor pretend to be, but when I go with my southern friends (yes, I admit to having some), they say this is about as close to Southern cooking as you can get for not living down der in the boonies. Good meats (ahh, the shredded pork) and filler up on the barbQ sauces.
author: mike g.

description: I had the Southern Star (half texas brisket, half memphis sweet pork sandwich). Pretty good & a nice collection of sauces to experiment with.  My mac & cheese side was pretty great.
author: Horrible H.

description: All the people who have been giving this place high marks must be smoking crack. I will admit that the brisket is pretty good, but the St. Louis ribs are okay at best and the chicken was bland and dry. The sides were nothing to write home about and the corn bread was chewy (and not in a good way, in an old, stale way.) The worst is the sauce. Thank goodness I had some bottled bbq sauce at home to mask the dryness of the chicken and add a little kick.
author: E M.

description: It's okay if you can't get the real thing (and we know you can't get the real thing in San Francisco anymore)..  The greens have a strange sweet taste, the potato salad is okay. Don't eat the sweet potato cubes.   The meats are fair.  Where Minnie's really falls down is on the sauce. The sauce is watery and does not have that full rich robust flavor of a good prepared sauce.    If your in the neighborhood and you can find a place to park  and your hungry ,it is okay.  I would not go out of my way for this BBQ.
author: ahsal a.

description: I'm from Georgia so I know what good BBQ tastes like and it's not this place.  Some of the meat is ok but the sides suck donkey balls.  The macaroni and cheese may honestly be the worst mac and cheese ever.  I think they took some from the KFC and put it under a fat dude for about a month.  The collard greens are awful as well.  I think they are some kind of old currency soaked in hot old man spit.  One star for the pecan pie.
author: Dirk C.

description: This place is amazing! The meat falls off the bones and the people are very friendly! Shiner Boch is an added bonus!
author: Emily C.

description: i had the st. louis rib plate. the ribs were good, really tender and juicy plus the mustard sauce was amazing! but the sides were just ok. the mac and cheese and potato salad were bland and forgettable, while the cornbread was super dry...good meat, but for the price I dont know if I'd go back
author: Heather P.

description: ok bbq, not great.  nice selection of sides and non bbq items.  brisket is done well, ribs and chicken i had were sub-par.  I am not a fan of any of their bbq sauces as i prefer mild traditional sauces.  A  little on the expensive side for modest portions.  Lily's bbq on divisadero has much better bbq except the chicken which is also sub-par, but has less sides than minnies.  Minnies if you want all the fixings with the bbq.  Lilys purely for brisket and ribs.
author: david w.

description: if someone things this is great barbecue then they've never eaten great barbecue. Meat is too dry and the sauce is nothing special. Good fires though. of the meats the brisket is the best. ribs are def second rate.
author: craig k.

description: In my opinion, serves one of the best BBQ in town.  The beef brisquet is absolutely wonderful -- very tasty and smoky.  I didn't like the ribs as much but still pretty good, especially if you like them dry.  Don't forget to order the BBQ fries -- very yummy.  The interior isn't much to die for so I tend to just order to go.
author: Amy V.

description: I was introduced to this place by my grandfather, who is from the boonies of Tennessee. He claimed this is the best BBQ he has ever had outside of the south. I thought it was great and after having tried the alleged best BBQs outside of Dixieland (e.g. R.U.B. in NYC), I'm settling on this as my favorite. All of the sauces are gold and the mesquite fries redefine. I noticed there were a bunch of negative reviews for this place and it seems like most people are squeamish about the cleanliness or just ordered chicken. Why would you go to a BBQ place and eat meat that hasn't been cooked for at least 14 hours? I recommend the brisket and the pulled pork and to quit being such crybabies.
author: Nick G.

description: This place has atmosphere. Don't expect luxury, just the basics at decent price.
author: Peter J.

description: its good, bbq not quiet as good as texas, but Im a lone star state fan,
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.

description:
i really can not believe all the positive reviews this place has.  i mean i am really dumbfounded.  you have got to be kidding me.
1st of all i do much better BBQ.  2nd of all i make better corn bread.  3rd of all are you kidding me?????????????
i took the future Mrs. out to the lower haight for some good old fashioned BBQ.  i used to live in this neighborhood and it was one of those places that was always right there but you never go to, you know what i mean?  and then your life changes and you are no longer in the neighborhood or the state for that matter, and you put it in the back of your mind and say to yourself i really want to go there.
we were very disappointed in the results of my lower-haight fantasies that had been fermenting in the back of my mind since my not so lucid lower haight days.  acid? OK. wow!
but i have now matured and i now have a job and i now pay taxes and acid is now something i use as a cleaner.
so i guess my culinary palate has evolved somewhat.  
this place is awful.  we got a st. louis plate and the ribs were as dry as 4 dollar laundry.  i was sooooooooooooo disappointed you could not imagine.  i had the sweet smoked pork sandwich which as you could imagine was dry and bland.  both of us were flabbergasted.  the BBQ was so dry it was criminal.  i really wanted a a BBQ place i could call my home away from home but this is not it.  in terms of BBQ i have had the privilege of growing up on a little place by the name of Emil villa's.  now way back then before they sold the joint they smoked those fucking ribs right there in front of you and when you ordered ribs they pulled them right out of the "hick'ry pit."  which is what the restaurant was called.  
this wasn't my first attempt at finding BBQ in the city and it wont be my last attempt.  however i will not go here again.  i have yet to find one worth mentioning but when i do i will write about it.
now i must say this the 1 saving grace of this place was the collared greens.  damn fine.  some of the best Ive had.  other than that, id leave it alone.  and i really mean that.  2 stars is generous.
author: Anthony Y.

description: "BBQ is like sex, the worst is GOOD"  That's what one sign says at Memphis Minnies...I thought so too until I came to this craptacular joint!  I think this place is over rated just because of the lack of southern BBQ foods in San Francisco.  Let's start with the seating, it sucks.  The place is small and you may have to share a table with strangers.  Now for the crappy "BBQ" food.  My beef rib came over burnt yet the inside was still red.  A good BBQ rib would have slightly red inside with a nice glazed outside.   I'm pretty sure they cook the foods after you order it.  Good BBQ food is always slowly cooked for hour+.  This give it a nice tender juicy texture that falls off the bone when you bite into it.  Maybe I'm wrong...maybe they do cook their foods for hours?  If they do, they sure aren't doing it right.  My memphis sweet pork cuts were DRY DRY DRY.  BBQ Chicken was also DRY.  So now you think...ok it's dry, let's make the most of it by using BBQ sauce.  WAIT??  What BBQ sauce??  That's right...Memphis has none.  They have three other non BBQ sauces which I disliked.  Good BBQ places that I've gone to have at least 3 different BBQ sauces at the table to choose from.  Corn muffin is hard to mess up.  But they messed that up too.  It was hard and dry.  Hardly any moisture in it.  Yup.  I definately wouldn't go back.
author: Nelson W.

description: I ordered a pulled pork sandwich, a staple at BBQ places. Where I'm from in Georgia, this means pork cooked for probably 12-18 hours which is then saturated in barbecue sauce - one should question where pork ends and sauce begins.  Anyway, I received my sandwich, and it was pork, alright.   It was served on a deli roll instead of the traditional hamburger bun which I supposed was questionable, but ultimately okay, as I wasn't really there for bread anyway. But it was completely devoid of sauce.  At first I thought there must have been some sort of mix up in the kitchen, or this was someone's cruel idea of a joke.  I had to sauce my own sandwich with cold, flavorless, runny BBQ sauce that was sitting in a squeeze bottle on my table.  And there was a disgusting amount of fat in the sandwich.  As someone else mentioned,  properly cooking the pork (slowly and for great duration) will eliminate most of the fat.  I shouldn't see huge globs of white gunk, nor should there be burnt bits on the meat.  Let's not even talk about the off-color macaroni and cheese.   I definitely did not trust this place to cook greens properly.   Another 'Southern' place in the Bay fails to impress, what else is new.
author: Karthi X.

description: i like memphis minnies. not sure how "authentic" this place is, but it's definitely good. i've eaten here quite a few times. it's been consistently tasty. bbq pork sandwich.......mmm mmmmmmm.
author: CaliGirl X.
